{"uri": "8242930032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:16:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:16:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:15:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/07/25/canada-womens-football-coach-to-skip-match-vs-nz-following-drone-incidents/", "title": "Canada women's football coach to skip match vs NZ following drone incidents | The Associated Press", "body": "CANADA women's football coach Bev Priestman said Wednesday she'll step away from the team's opening game against New Zealand at the Paris Olympics in the wake of a drone scandal.\n\nNew Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after it said drones were flown over closed practice sessions earlier in the week. Canada, the defending Olympic champion, was set to open the Paris Games on Thursday against New Zealand in Saint-Etienne.\n\nIn the fallout of the complaint, two staff members -- assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi -- were sent home, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\nPriestman said she was voluntarily removing herself from the opener \"with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nIn a statement, Priestman also apologized to New Zealand.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nAssistant coach Andy Spence will lead Canada in the opener.\n\nPriestman also spoke briefly in person to reporters after training.\n\n\"By no means did I direct the individuals,\" she said. \"I'm still learning the details and obviously this is all unfolding. But again, I think the important thing right now is to look forward, put the actions in place and take the sanctions.\"\n\nFIFA, football's international governing body, said its disciplinary committee had opened hearings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander. Canada Soccer announced late Wednesday that it would conduct an independent review.\n\nThe COC confirmed Tuesday that a nonaccredited member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities after a drone was spotted above training.\n\nA French court on Wednesday sentenced a 43-year-old Canadian man to an eight-month suspended sentence for filming two of New Zealand's closed training sessions with an aerial device.\n\nThe man, who was not named, admitted to the charges and identified himself an independent sports analyst for the Canadian federation, according to the Saint Etienne prosecutor David Charmatz.\n\nThe COC also apologized to the New Zealand Olympic Committee and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games -- at this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian football team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. {"uri": "8241885017", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:06:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:06:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:05:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/canada-womens-soccer-coach-bev-priestman-paris-olympics-spy-drone-new-zealand/", "title": "Canadian women's soccer coach won't be at first Olympic game following drone incidents", "body": "The Canadian women's soccer coach Bev Priestman said Wednesday that she will not appear at the team's first game against New Zealand at the Paris Olympics, after two incidents where people affiliated with Canada's team appeared to fly drones over the opponents' practice sessions.\n\nTwo staff members -- Canada's assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi -- were also sent home, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\nNew Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after it said drones were flown over practice sessions earlier in the week.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said that it had accepted Priestman's decision not to coach the team's opening match against New Zealand on Thursday. In a statement, the coach apologized to members of the New Zealand team and personally took responsibility for the drone incidents.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said in the statement. \"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe Canadians are the defending gold medalists.\n\nThe COC confirmed Tuesday that a non-accredited member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities in Saint-\u00c9tienne after a drone was spotted above training.\n\nThe COC also apologized to the New Zealand Olympic Committee and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games -- at this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 in Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. {"uri": "2024-07-432424038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:50:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:50:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:48:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/canada-womens-soccer-coach-will-step-aside-for-the-teams-opener-because-of-drone-incidents/article_49b85d66-f175-5ddd-9cc3-969902504848.html", "title": "Canada women's soccer coach will step aside for the team's opener because of drone incidents", "body": "SAINT-ETIENNE, France (AP) -- Canada women's soccer coach Bev Priestman said Wednesday she'll step away from the team's opening game against New Zealand at the Paris Olympics in the wake of a pair of drone incidents.\n\nNew Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after it said drones were flown over practice sessions earlier in the week.\n\nTwo staff members -- assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi -- were sent home, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" Priestman said in a statement. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe Canadians are the defending gold medalists. In her statement, Priestman also apologized to New Zealand.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nThe COC confirmed Tuesday that a nonaccredited member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities after a drone was spotted above training.\n\nThe COC also apologized to the New Zealand Olympic Committee and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games -- at this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. An assistant coach and a team analyst have also been removed from the Games after a spying scandal swirled around the tournament.\n\nThe sports governing body FIFA said on Wednesday that it has initiated disciplinary action after the New Zealand women's team reported this week that a training session was disrupted by a drone operated by a Canadian team member.\n\nCanada and New Zealand will play each other in the opening match of Group A on Thursday.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) also said it had taken steps to remove two staff members from the Olympic roster who won gold at the Tokyo Olympics.\n\nJoseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, has been removed from the Canadian Olympic team and will be sent home immediately, COC said in a statement.\n\nJasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Lombardi reports, has been removed from the Canadian Olympic team and will be sent home immediately.\n\nLombardi, 43, was also given an eight-month suspended prison sentence for flying the drone over the New Zealand training session in Saint-Etienne on Monday.\n\nIn a statement, Priestman, the Canadian national team coach, said she had decided to voluntarily withdraw from Thursday's match against New Zealand.\n\nOn behalf of our entire team, I would first like to apologize to the players and staff of New Zealand Football and to the players of Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for, Priestman said.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) reported the incident to police and the International Olympic Committee's {"uri": "8241508190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:15:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:15:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:14:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://talksport.com/sport/1980557/canada-drone-beverly-priestman-paris-olympics-2024-spygate/", "title": "Ex-England coach in Olympics drone 'Spygate' as two Canada staff sent home", "body": "Canada coach Beverly Priestman has withdrawn from their opening match against New Zealand amid a spying scandal.\n\nIt comes amid a dramatic drone debacle which saw a member of Canada's support team detained by French authorities.\n\nThat followed allegations from New Zealand, who are facing Canada's women team in the opening Paris Olympics football match, that a drone had been used to record them in training.\n\nPriestman, who worked as Phil Neville's assistant to the Lionesses from 2018 to 2020, has taken responsibility and voluntarily withdrawn herself as head coach from Thursday's match against New Zealand.\n\nThe Canada coach's No. 2 Jasmine Mander has also been sent home, as well as analyst Joseph Lombardi.\n\nIt comes after the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said a scouting report was filed by Lombardi and sent to Mander.\n\n\"I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\"\n\nThe COC further revealed that a 'non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team' was detained by authorities.\n\nA statement read: \"The Canadian Olympic Committee was made aware that a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team was detained by French authorities in Saint-Etienne following a complaint by New Zealand Football on July 22nd.\n\n\"The staff member is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\n\n\"We are reviewing next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer, and FIFA. {"uri": "8241546521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:41:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:41:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:40:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://time.com/7002564/canada-assistant-soccer-coach-removed-olympic-team-drone/", "title": "Canada's Assistant Soccer Coach  Kicked Off Olympic Team", "body": "An assistant coach and an analyst have been removed from the Canadian women's soccer Olympic team after New Zealand said a drone operated by a Canadian team staffer was flown over its team's practice session, just days before the two Group A teams are set to face each other.\n\nJasmine Mander, an assistant coach on the Canadian women's soccer team, and Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with the team, \"will be sent home immediately,\" the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said in a press release on Wednesday. Head Coach Bev Priestman also said she would remove herself from coaching the match against New Zealand on Thursday \"to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said in a statement. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nThe decision comes after the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) said in a press release Tuesday that a drone was flown over the New Zealand women's soccer team training session in Saint-\u00c9tienne, France, on Monday. Staff members reported it to the police, and the drone operator was identified as a \"support staff member\" of the Canadian women's soccer team and was detained, NZOC said.\n\nNZOC said Tuesday it has \"formally lodged the incident\" with the integrity unit of the International Olympic Committee (IOC), and that Team Canada issued an apology and is investigating the situation.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" NZOC said.\n\nCOC said Wednesday that it learned of a second drone incident at a New Zealand team practice on July 19. COC said it is \"in contact with the IOC and in contact with FIFA,\" and \"will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary.\" Soccer team staff will also undergo a Both will be sent home immediately, the COC said.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe Canadian women's soccer team is scheduled to take on New Zealand in a group A match on Thursday.\n\nHead Coach Bev Priestman, who has voluntarily withdrawn herself from coaching that particular game, also issued an apology.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our drone to spy on NZ soccer team at the Olympics revealed", "body": "New Zealand and Canada play each other at 1am on Friday morning (AEST).\n\nThe Canadian women's soccer team have sacked an assistant coach and another staff member after New Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) that a drone was used to spy on their training session.\n\nHead coach Bev Priestman also removed herself from coaching the team against New Zealand.\n\nStaff from New Zealand's team -- the Football Ferns -- noticed a drone flying above their training session in St Etienne on Monday.\n\nReporting it to police, the operator was identified as a supporting staff member of Canada's team.\n\nABC Sport will be live blogging every day of the Paris Olympics from July 27\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) later confirmed that assistant coach Jasmine Mander and an analyst were kicked off the Games team following the incident.\n\nCanada are the reigning Olympic champions and New Zealand's first opponents at the Paris Games, on Friday morning (AEST).\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" the COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi, who had been detained by police, was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said they had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander due to a potential breach of the body's disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement.\n\nA statement issued by the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) said they were \"deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident\" and wanted answers.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review,\" the statement read.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games.\"\n\nPriestman apologised for the offence.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and {"uri": "2024-07-432496310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:25:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:25:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:09:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/24/canadas-womens-soccer-coach-analyst-tossed-from-ol/", "title": "Canada's women's soccer coach, analyst tossed from Olympics after using drone to spy on New Zealand", "body": "An assistant coach and an analyst for Canada's women's soccer team used a drone to record and disrupt a practice by the New Zealand women's team and have been sent home from the Paris Olympics.\n\nThe two teams are slated to play Thursday as part of Group A, which also includes France and Colombia.\n\nJoseph Lombardi, an \"unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer,\" and assistant coach Jasmine Mander, to whom Lombardi reported, were removed from the Canadian team and sent back over the Atlantic, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\nOn Monday, a drone was flown over New Zealand's practice facilities in Saint-\u00c9tienne. Team personnel reported the drone to police, who found the drone operator and detained them. The drone pilot was a support staffer for the Canadian team.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident,\" the New Zealand Olympic Committee said in a statement.\n\nIn addition to Monday's incident, there was also a drone incident at a New Zealand practice on Friday, The Canadian Olympic Committee said.\n\nBev Priestman, the head coach of Canada's women's soccer team, has removed herself from Thursday's match, and all of Canada Soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training, the Olympic committee said.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. ... I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw ... In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld,\" Ms. Priestman said.", "source": The drone was found to be operated by a member of the Canadian team's support staff.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) said in a statement Tuesday.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee announced its discipline on Wednesday and revealed it learned of a second drone incident that occurred on July 19.\n\nThe organization said \"unaccredited analyst\" Joseph Lombardi and assistant coach Jasmine Mander were sent home from Paris over the incident.\n\nCanadian soccer head coach Bev Priestman will not be on the sidelines for the team's match against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said in a statement.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nCanada is the defending gold medal winners. session.\n\nHead coach Bev Priestman also removed herself from coaching the team against New Zealand despite declaring she \"did not direct\" the individuals.\n\nStaff from New Zealand's team -- the disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement.\n\nA statement issued by the New Zealand Olympic The New Zealand women's soccer team said its training session was disrupted Tuesday by a drone - a drone operated by a staff member of the Canadian's women's soccer team.\n\nIn a statement, the Canadian Olympic Committee acknowledged there have been two incidents of drone flying in the city of Saint-\u00c9tienne, where the two teams are set to play Thursday. The COC has removed assistant coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi from the team.\n\nThe COC also said it accepted head coach Bev Priestman's decision to not coach the team in Thursday's game. Canada Soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nWhat happened with the drone at soccer training?\n\nAfter the incident involving the drone July 22, the drone operator was detained by police, according to the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC).\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a the Football Ferns - noticed a drone flying above their training session in St Etienne on Monday.\n\nReporting it to police, the operator was identified as a supporting staff member of Canada's team.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee later confirmed that assistant coach Jasmine Mander and an analyst were kicked off the Games team following the incident.\n\nCanada are the reigning Olympic champions and New Zealand's first opponents at the Paris Games, on Friday morning (AEST).\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" the COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi, who had been detained by police, was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said they had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander due to a potential breach of the body's disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement.\n\nA statement issued by the New Zealand Olympic Committee said they were \"deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident\" and wanted answers.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review,\" the statement read.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games.\"\n\nPriestman apologised for the offence.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. {"uri": "2024-07-433203683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:19:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:19:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:00:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.syracuse.com/tv/2024/07/olympics-canada-vs-new-zealand-live-stream-72524-how-to-watch-womens-soccer-online.html", "title": "Olympics: Canada vs. New Zealand LIVE STREAM (7/25/24): How to watch women's soccer online", "body": "Defending Olympic champs Canada face New Zealand to open the 2024 Paris Olympics women's soccer tournament on Thursday, July 25, 2024 (7/25/2024) at Stade Geoffroy-Guichard in Saint-Etienne, France.\n\nCanada women's soccer coach Bev Priestman said Wednesday she'll step away from the team's opening game against New Zealand at the Paris Olympics in the wake of a drone scandal.\n\nNew Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after it said drones were flown over closed practice sessions earlier in the week. Canada, the defending Olympic champion, was set to open the Paris Games on Thursday against New Zealand in Saint-Etienne.\n\nIn the fallout of the complaint, two staff members -- assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi -- were sent home, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\nPriestman said she was voluntarily removing herself from the opener \"with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nIn a statement, Priestman also apologized to New Zealand.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nAssistant coach Andy Spence will lead Canada in the opener.\n\nPriestman also spoke briefly in person to reporters after training.\n\n\"By no means did I direct the individuals,\" she said. \"I'm still learning the details and obviously this is all unfolding. But again, I think the important thing right now is to look forward, put the actions in place and take the sanctions.\"\n\nFIFA, soccer's international governing body, said its disciplinary committee had opened hearings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander. Canada Soccer announced late Wednesday that it would conduct an independent review.\n\nThe COC confirmed Tuesday that a nonaccredited member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities after a drone was spotted above training.\n\nA French court on Wednesday sentenced a 43-year-old Canadian man to an eight-month suspended sentence for filming two of New Zealand's closed training sessions with an aerial device.\n\nThe man, who was not named, admitted to the charges and identified himself an independent sports analyst for the Canadian federation, according to the Saint Etienne prosecutor David Charmatz.\n\nThe COC also apologized to the New Zealand Olympic Committee and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games -- at this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nWhat is Peacock Premium?\n\nPeacock Premium is a video streaming service from NBC that includes complete event-by-event coverage of the 2024 Summer Olympics, plus a huge library of content, including episodes of \"The Office,\" \"Parks & Recreation,\" and more hit NBC TV series. It also includes exclusive channels like the WWE Network, live sports including Premier League soccer and next day access to the latest episodes of hit TV series. Peacock is available on most web browsers; Android and iOS devices; Android, Apple, Roku and LG TVs, XBox, PlayStation and more devices. {"uri": "8241303641", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:08:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:08:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:08:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/soccer/news/paris-2024-olympics-scandal-canada-womens-soccer-caught-spying-on-opponents-practice-using-drones/", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics scandal: Canada women's soccer caught spying on opponent's practice using drone - CBSSports.com", "body": "Head coach Bev Priestman won't lead Canada in their opener following the revelations Getty Images\n\nThe assistant head coach and an analyst for the Canada women's soccer team have been kicked off the roster after a spying scandal erupted at the Paris Olympics. Head coach Bev Priestman will also miss her side's opening game against New Zealand on Thursday, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) confirmed, after her staff were caught hovering a drone above their opponents' training session.\n\nOn Monday, a little over 72 hours before their matchup with the Canucks, the drone was spotted above the New Zealand squad's base in Saint Etienne. The incident was subsequently reported to police, who uncovered the the operator of the spy craft as a member of the Canadian support staff. An investigation by the COC uncovered a further drone incident three days earlier, leading to them removing two staff members from their setup. Canada Soccer staff are also due to undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" said a COC statement. \"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nPriestman, who coached Canada to gold medals in Tokyo three years ago, will also play no part in the Group A opener at Stade Geoffroy-Guichard.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said. \"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nCanada remain heavy favorites to take the win against the Football Ferns, who have won just two of their 13 Olympic matches and were eliminated at the group stage of last year's World Cup, for which they were co-hosts. Per multiple reports, Andy Spence will lead Canada from the sidelines in their opener.\n\nA statement from the New Zealand Olympic Committee on Tuesday said they had \"formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and asked Canada for a full review. Team Canada has issued an apology and is investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024. At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nHosts France and Colombia make up the remainder of Group Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had been detained by French authorities in St Etienne following a complaint by New Zealand Football on July 22.\n\nFollowing the COC's review of that incident it said it had learned of a \"second drone incident\" on July 19.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed. It's also emerged that a similar flight took place three days earlier, on Friday.\n\nRecommended Videos\n\nAfter news of the reported reconnaissance missions broke, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) issued an apology, insisting in a statement that it \"stands for fair-play,\" and felt \"shocked and disappointed\" by what had happened.\n\nIt added: \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee. We are reviewing next steps with the IOC [International Olympic Committee], Paris 2024, Canada Soccer, and FIFA.\"\n\nTwo members of the Canadian Olympic Team linked to the scandal have been sent home, with one of them believed to have been the alleged drone operator and the other an assistant coach for the Canadian team who reportedly received information that was gathered during the drone flights.\n\nThe COC has also confirmed that it has accepted the offer of Canada's team coach, Bev Priestman, to stand down from coaching duties for the New Zealand game.\n\nIn a statement, Priestman, who denied playing any role in the incident, said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\"\n\nResponding to the scandal, the New Zealand Olympic Committee said it was \"deeply shocked and disappointed\" by what had happened. \"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained. The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nFIFA's disciplinary committee has now launched an official investigation into the {"uri": "8241705446", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:34:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:34:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:33:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3028939-canada-womens-soccer-coach-steps-down-amid-drone-controversy", "title": "Canada Women's Soccer Coach Steps Down Amid Drone Controversy | Sports-Games", "body": "Canada women's soccer coach Bev Priestman announced Wednesday that she will step away from the team's opening game against New Zealand at the Paris Olympics following a pair of drone incidents.\n\nNew Zealand lodged a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit, alleging that drones were flown over their practice sessions earlier this week.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi have been sent home, according to the Canadian Olympic Committee.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" Priestman stated. \"To emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure the integrity and sportsmanship of the game.\" Canada, the defending gold medalists, has also issued an apology to New Zealand.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to our own Team Canada players. This incident does not reflect our team's values,\" Priestman added. French authorities detained a nonaccredited member of Canada's soccer team staff after a drone was seen above a training session.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee has offered heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, affected players, and the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\n\n\"We are shocked and disappointed,\" the committee stated. \"We stand for fair play and apologize to all involved parties.\" New Zealand's Olympic Committee reiterated its commitment to integrity and fairness, emphasizing their support for the women's football team as they begin their Olympic campaign.\n\nInterestingly, this isn't the first instance of a Canadian soccer team being involved in a drone controversy during international training. In 2021, Honduras halted a training session in Toronto before a men's World Cup qualifier against Canada due to a similar drone sighting. {"uri": "8242336966", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "04:26:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T04:26:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T04:25:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/sports/football-news/olympics-2024-canada-football-coach-analyst-removed-from-paris-games-heres-why-13796720.html", "title": "Canadian football coach, analyst booted from Paris Olympics: Here's why", "body": "Canada women's football team head coach Beverly Priestman will not be part of their first game in Paris Olympics. AP\n\nThe Canada women's football team assistant coach and a team analyst have been booted out of the Paris Olympics 2024 on Wednesday after a spying scandal broke out. Canada's head coach Bev Priestman has also removed herself from the Group A opening match against New Zealand on Thursday. The New Zealand women's team claimed that their training session on Monday was disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of Canada.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said on Wednesday it had taken action to remove two members of staff from their Olympic squad, who were gold medallists at the Tokyo Games, while Priestman would not take charge against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA opens proceedings\n\nFIFA said on Wednesday it had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander due to a potential breach of the body's disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement.\n\nPriestman apologised for what had happened and said ultimate responsibility lay with her.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nCanada launches independent external review\n\nCanada Soccer said on Wednesday it would launch an independent external review that will not only address the circumstances of the matter but also look into the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of its programs.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians,\" Canada Soccer President Peter Augruso and CEO Kevin Blue said in a statement.\n\n\"We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\"\n\nThe incident was reported by the NZOC to the police and to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-07-431831049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:55:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:55:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:55:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://mb.com.ph/2024/7/23/new-zealand-olympic-soccer-team-complains-after-canadian-team-drone-flown-over-its-training-session", "title": "New Zealand Olympic soccer team complains after Canadian team drone flown over its training session", "body": "New Zealand says it has complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after a drone flown over a New Zealand women's soccer team training session was found to be operated by a member of the Canadian team's support staff.\n\nWELLINGTON (AP) -- New Zealand says it has complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after a drone flown over a New Zealand women's soccer team training session was found to be operated by a member of the Canadian team's support staff.\n\nDefending Olympic champion Canada and New Zealand meet in their opening match at the Olympic tournament on Thursday, July 25. The drone incident occurred earlier this week, the New Zealand Olympic Committee said Wednesday, July 26.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee has apologized to the NZOC and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games -- at this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Canada's head coach Bev Priestman said in a statement. \"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\nPriestman voluntarily removed herself from the opening match on Thursday, where the defending Olympic champions were to play against New Zealand. {"uri": "8241088429", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:22:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:22:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:58:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13667441/Olympics-Canadian-assistant-coach-kicked-Games-drone-incident.html", "title": "Olympics-Canadian assistant coach kicked out of Games after drone...", "body": "PARIS, July 23 (Reuters) -\n\nThe Canadian women's soccer team assistant coach and an analyst have been kicked out of the Olympic squad after New Zealand said its team had their training session disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of their Group A opponents, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said on Wednesday.\n\nHead coach Bev Priestman has also removed herself from coaching the team against New Zealand in Group A on Thursday, the COC added.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nPriestman apologised for the offence.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team\u00b4s commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe drone was flown on Monday and the incident was reported by the NZOC to the police and to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\" (Reporting by Martyn {"uri": "8240332667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "01:07:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T01:07:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T01:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://santamariatimes.com/ap/sports/new-zealand-olympic-soccer-team-complains-after-canadian-team-drone-flown-over-its-training-session/article_a8bc6f0c-0018-5968-be8d-419ff4608df3.html", "title": "New Zealand Olympic soccer team complains after Canadian team drone flown over its training session", "body": "WELLINGTON, New Zealand (AP) -- New Zealand says it has complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after a drone flown over a New Zealand women's soccer team training session was found to be operated by a member of the Canadian team's support staff.\n\nDefending Olympic champion Canada and New Zealand meet in their opening match at the Olympic tournament on Thursday. The drone incident occurred earlier this week, the New Zealand Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said in a statement it was \"shocked and disappointed\" over the allegation and apologized to the NZOC and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident.\"\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "santamariatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Santa Maria Times"}, Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\n\n'2. Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi report sent, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\n\n'3. COC has accepted the decision of Head Coach Bev Priestman to remove herself from coaching the match against New Zealand on July 25th.\n\n'4. Canada Soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\n'The COC is in contact with the IOC and in contact with FIFA. Canada Soccer has been transparent and cooperative throughout the process. The COC will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary.'\n\nAdditionally, Priestman issues her own statement: 'On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada.\n\n'This does not represent the values that our team stands for. {"uri": "8241411700", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:14:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:14:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:14:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.nbcdfw.com/paris-2024-summer-olympics/canadian-soccer-team-assistant-coach-analyst-olympics-drone/3600269/", "title": "Canadian soccer team's assistant coach, analyst out of Olympics after drone controversy", "body": "The head coach also removed herself from coaching against New Zealand\n\nThe assistant coach of the Canadian women's soccer team was kicked off the country's Olympic squad after a drone flown over a New Zealand women's soccer team training session was believed to have been operated by someone from Canada's support staff, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\nAlso out in the drone foul is a Canadian analyst.\n\nIn addition, the head coach, Bev Priestman, has removed herself from coaching the team against New Zealand on Thursday, the Canadian committee said.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" the committee said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" it said.\n\nPriestman apologized to the players and staff of New Zealand soccer, and to the players on her Canadian team.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said. \" I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\"\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said it also had learned of a second drone incident at a July 19 New Zealand practice.\n\nThis is the second Olympic controversy of the week. Three-time Olympic gold medalist Charlotte Dujardin of Britain withdrew from the Paris Games after a video emerged that she says shows her behaving inappropriately while coaching other riders.\n\nDujardin said in a statement that the video from four years ago \"shows me making an error of judgment during a coaching session.\" It wasn't clear what video Dujardin referred to or what specifically the video shows.\n\nDujardin said the International Federation for Equestrian Sports, or FEI, is investigating.\n\n\"What happened was completely out of character and does not reflect how I train my horses or coach my pupils; however, there is no excuse,\" Dujardin said in a statement on Instagram. \"I am deeply ashamed and should have set a better example in that moment.\n\nDefending Olympic soccer champion Canada and New Zealand meet in their opening match at the Olympic tournament.\n\nNew Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit about the drone, which occurred on Monday.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the New Zealand Olympic Committee said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review,\" it said.\n\nThe committee said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games -- at this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" the COC wrote in a statement.\n\nThe Canadians had already sent home two staff members, analyst Joseph Lombardi and assistant coach Jasmine Mander.\n\nPriestman yesterday acknowledged her responsibility for the affair.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nBev Priestman is a former England assistant coach (Mike Egerton/PA)\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had been detained by French authorities in St Etienne following a complaint by New Zealand Football on July 22.\n\nFollowing the COC's review of that incident it said it had learned of a \"second drone incident\" on July 19.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld,\" Priestman said in an apology to New Zealand Football.\n\nThe Canadian team will play New Zealand in a Thursday group match at Geoffroy-Guichard Stadium in Saint-Etienne.\n\nParis 2024 will officially start with Friday's opening ceremony on the River Seine.\n\nThe football, archery and rugby events have begun before the ceremony.\n\nThe Paris Games are being held at 35 venues including Stade de France, Parc des Princes and Stade We are reviewing next steps with the IOC (International Olympic Committee), Paris 2024, Canada Soccer, and FIFA.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it was \"deeply shocked and disappointed.\"\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian women's football team, to be detained,\" it said in a statement.\n\nOlympic champions Canada are set to play New Zealand in a group-stage game in Saint-\u00c9tienne.\n\nTullio M. Puglia/Getty Images\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review. {"uri": "8241855510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:38:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:38:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:38:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.nbcolympics.com/news/canadian-womens-soccer-coach-analyst-kicked-out-olympics-after-drone-incident", "title": "Canadian women's soccer coach, analyst kicked out of Olympics after drone incident", "body": "Canada coach Bev Priestman removed herself from their opening match duties at the Paris Olympics while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games on Wednesday after a spying scandal engulfed the women's soccer tournament.\n\nGlobal soccer's governing body FIFA said it had begun disciplinary proceedings after New Zealand's women's team said their training session on Monday had been disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of their opening Group A opponents Canada.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said on Wednesday it had taken action to remove two members of staff from their Olympic squad, which were gold medalists at the Tokyo Games, while Priestman would not take charge against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said on Wednesday it had \"opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Ms. Beverly Priestman, Mr. Joseph Lombardi and Ms. Jasmine Mander due to the potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA Disciplinary Code and article 6.1 of the Regulations Olympic Football.\"\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA explained in a statement.\n\nPriestman apologized for what had happened and said ultimate responsibility lay with her.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe incident was reported by the NZOC to the police and to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcolympics.com", {"uri": "8241955767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:10:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:10:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:08:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.northernirelandnews.com/news/274468668/canadian-soccer-coach-analyst-out-of-olympics-for-drone-incident", "title": "Canadian soccer coach, analyst out of Olympics for drone incident", "body": "PARIS -- Canada coach Bev Priestman removed herself from their opening match duties at the Paris Olympics while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games on Wednesday after a spying scandal engulfed the women's soccer tournament.\n\nGlobal soccer's governing body FIFA begandisciplinary proceedings and Canada Soccer said it would launch an independent review after New Zealand's women's team said their training session on Monday had been disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of their opening Group A opponents Canada.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said on Wednesday it had taken action to remove two members of staff from their Olympic squad, who were gold medalists at the Tokyo Games, while Priestman would not take charge against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said on Wednesday it had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander due to a potential breach of the body's disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement.\n\nPriestman apologized for what had happened and said ultimate responsibility lay with her.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nCanada Soccer said on Wednesday it would launch an independent external review that will not only address the circumstances of the matter but also look into the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of its programs.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians,\" Canada Soccer President Peter Augruso and CEO Kevin Blue said in a statement.\n\n\"We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\"\n\nThe incident was reported by the NZOC to the police and to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"At this time {"uri": "8242314198", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "04:04:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T04:04:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T04:03:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.rediff.com/sports/report/canadian-coach-analyst-kicked-out-of-paris-olympics-after-drone-incident/20240725.htm", "title": "Canadian coach, analyst kicked out of Olympics after drone spying incident", "body": "IMAGE: New Zealand's women's team said their training session on Monday had been disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of their opening Group A opponents Canada. Photograph: Benoit Tessier/Reuters\n\nCanada coach Bev Priestman removed herself from their opening match duties at the Paris Olympics while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games on Wednesday after a spying scandal engulfed the women's soccer tournament.\n\nGlobal soccer's governing body FIFA began disciplinary proceedings and Canada Soccer said it would launch an independent review after New Zealand's women's team said their training session on Monday had been disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of their opening Group A opponents Canada.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said on Wednesday it had taken action to remove two members of staff from their Olympic squad, who were gold medallists at the Tokyo Games, while Priestman would not take charge against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said on Wednesday it had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander due to a potential breach of the body's disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement.\n\nPriestman\n\napologised for what had happened and said ultimate responsibility lay with her.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nCanada Soccer said on Wednesday it would launch an independent external review that will not only address the circumstances of the matter but also look into the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of its programs.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians,\" Canada Soccer President Peter Augruso and CEO Kevin Blue said in a statement.\n\n\"We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\"\n\nThe incident was reported by the NZOC to the police and to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\" THE OLYMPICS, 2024", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nFollowing the COC's review of that incident it said it had learned of a \"second drone incident\" on July 19.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" the COC said in a statement.\n\nThe COC said it was in contact with the International Olympic Committee and football's global governing body FIFA.\n\n\"The COC will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary,\" it added.", "source": {"uri": "8241857546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:42:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:42:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:39:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.tricitynews.com/highlights/richmond-born-canada-soccer-assistant-coach-sent-home-from-olympics-9261783", "title": "Richmond-born Canada Soccer assistant coach sent home from Olympics", "body": "Mander, a Delta resident, was removed from the Canadian Olympic Team following an alleged drone incident.\n\nTwo Canada Soccer staff were sent home after an alleged drone incident just days before the 2024 Paris Olympics are set to begin.\n\nRichmond-born Jasmine Mander, assistant coach of the Canadian women's soccer team, was sent home from France on July 24 along with Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, according to a Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) media statement.\n\nMander is currently a Delta resident and Lombardi is from Brampton, Ont.\n\nOn July 22, the French authorities detained a \"non-accredited member\" of the Canada Soccer support team in Saint-\u00c9tienne after receiving a complaint from New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The staff member is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice,\" reads the COC in an initial media statement on July 24.\n\nHowever, it is unclear which staff member was detained.\n\nThe committee added they \"stand for fair-play\" and described the incident as shocking and disappointing.\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" said the COC.\n\nThe COC proceeded to work with the International Olympic Committee, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer and FIFA.\n\nAfter a review of the incident, the COC said they learned of a second drone incident that had also allegedly taken place on July 19 during New Zealand's practice.\n\nBoth Mander and Lombardi were removed from the Canadian Olympic Team while Bev Priestman, head coach of Canada Soccer's Women's National Team, voluntarily stepped down from coaching the July 25 soccer match against New Zealand, according to the COC.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" said Priestman.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nAll Canada Soccer staff are undergoing mandatory ethics training.\n\nGot an opinion on this story or any others in Richmond? The NZOC promptly reported the incident to the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) integrity unit.\n\nThe NZOC said that a drone was flown over the training session on July 22 and the incident was immediately reported to the police. This was followed by the detention of a support member of the Canada team, who was the operator of the drone.\n\n\"On July 22, a drone was flown over the New Zealand women's football team training session in St Etienne,\" the NZOC said on Tuesday. \"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained.\"\n\nFollowing this, Team Canada issued an apology and launched an investigation into the matter.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee acknowledged the incident, specifying that it involved \"a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team.\" They stated that they are currently \"reviewing next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer, and FIFA.\n\nIn a statement they released, the Canadian Olympic Committee said they stand for fair-play and are shocked and disappointed with what has happened.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" they said in a statement.\n\nCanada and New Zealand will lock horns during the Olympics on July 25 in their opening match. Canada Soccer has been transparent and cooperative throughout the process,\" a statement issued Wednesday by the COC reads, adding that further action may be taken as review of the incident continues.\n\nEarlier in the day, the COC released a brief statement acknowledging that a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team\" had been detained by local authorities in Saint-\u00c9tienne, a small city 400 kilometres south of Paris, near Lyon, France.\n\n\"The staff member is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice,\" the earlier statement reads, acknowledging that the competing team lodged a complaint two days earlier, on July 22.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the COC said.\n\nThe COC statements echoed a July 23 release from the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) announcing the formal complaint to the IOC's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" the statement reads.\n\nHead coach sidelined\n\nAs part of the announced measures to address the incident, the Canadian team's head coach will remove herself from an upcoming match against New Zealand on Thursday morning, Paris time.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" said Bev Priestman, head coach of Canada Soccer's women's national team, in a statement.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nIn addition, Canada Soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training, the COC said.\n\n\"The actions of those involved do not reflect Canada's values or the values of sport,\" wrote Carla Qualtrough, Canada's minister of sport and physical activity, in a post to X Wednesday.\n\n\"I support the sanctions being imposed by the Canadian Olympic Committee, their apologies to New Zealand, and the decision of Head Coach Bev Priestman ... These decisive actions will help ensure that individuals are held accountable and preserve the integrity of the game and fair play for all athletes.\"\n\nCanada and New Zealand's women's soccer teams
