{"uri": "8242461521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:14:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:14:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T06:13:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.stabroeknews.com/2024/07/25/sports/canadian-coach-analyst-kicked-out-of-games-after-drone-incident/", "title": "Canadian coach, analyst kicked out of Games after drone incident - Stabroek News", "body": "(Reuters) - Canada coach Bev Priestman removed herself from their opening match duties at the Paris Olympics while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games yesterday after a spying scandal engulfed the women's soccer tournament.\n\nGlobal soccer's governing body FIFA began disciplinary proceedings and Canada Soccer said it would launch an independent review after New Zealand's women's team said their training session on Monday had been disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of their opening Group A opponents Canada.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said yesterday it had taken action to remove two members of staff from their Olympic squad, who were gold medallists at the Tokyo Games, while Priestman would not take charge against New Zealand today.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said yesterday it had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander due to a potential breach of the body's disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement. Priestman apologised for what had happened and said ultimate responsibility lay with her.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nCanada Soccer said yesterday it would launch an independent external review that will not only address the circumstances of the matter but also look into the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of its programs.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians,\" Canada Soccer President Peter Augruso and CEO Kevin Blue said in a statement.\n\n\"We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\"\n\nThe incident was reported by the NZOC to the police and to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"At this time {"uri": "8241258263", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:41:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:41:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:41:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.the42.ie/canada-5-6444853-Jul2024/", "title": "Controversy hangs over Olympic football champions Canada after drone 'spying' incident", "body": "Two staff members have been sent home ahead of tomorrow's opener against New Zealand.\n\nTHE CANADIAN WOMEN'S football squad is in turmoil ahead of their Olympics gold medal defence.\n\nThe reigning champions are in the spotlight amidst a training ground drone incident ahead of their opening fixture against New Zealand tomorrow.\n\nTwo staff members have been sent home for flying a drone over New Zealand training sessions and recording practice.\n\nAFP are reporting that one has been detained by French authorities.\n\nThe incident in question occurred on Monday 22 July in Saint-\u00c9tienne, with details of further prohibited drone activity on Saturday 19 July emerging afterwards.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA statement via the Canadian Olympic Committee [COC] says that unaccredited analyst Joseph Lombardi and assistant coach Jasmine Mander -- whom Lombardi reports to -- have been removed from the team and will be sent home immediately.\n\nHead coach Bev Preistman, meanwhile, will step aside for the New Zealand game, while the Canada soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training. The COC is in contact with the IOC and Fifa on the matter.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nSeparately, the COC said it was \"shocked and disappointed\" by the incident on Tuesday in Saint-Etienne and was investigating.\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" it said in a statement Wednesday.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee said team support members reported the incident to police, with the drone operator detained.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review,\" it added.\n\nFrance and Colombia are the other teams in the group.\n\nCanada defeated Ireland at last summer's World Cup, but failed to The team immediately reported the incident to the police, which traced it to their opponent: Canada, which squares off with New Zealand on July 25.\n\n\"The New Zealand Olympic Committee [NZOC] and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident,\" says the NZOC.\n\nThe police detained a support member of the wider Canada coaching staff believed to be flying the drone. The Canadian team issued an apology and launched an investigation.\n\n\"The staff member is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice,\" says the Canadian Olympic Committee. \"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play, and we are shocked and disappointed.\"\n\nThe investigation then revealed that a member of the wider coaching staff also flew a drone over the New Zealand practice three days earlier, on July 19.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" says head coach Bev Priestman. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nCoach Priestman fired two members of the coaching staff, including Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, and assistant coach Jasmine Mander. Priestman also chose to remove herself from coaching the match against New Zealand.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" says Priestman. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe FIFA Disciplinary Committee is also investigating the incident as a potential breach of its policies, according to The Athletic.\n\nUnauthorized drones are banned at the Olympics, though French air defense staff say they have {"uri": "8241870177", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:52:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:52:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:51:48Z", "dataType": "news", Canada Football Coaches Caught Using Drone To Spy On Rivals, Sent Home", "body": "The incident occurred during New Zealand's training session in St Etienne, disrupting their preparations for the tournament.\n\nCanadian women's football team coach Beverly Priestman will not be present at the dugout during the team's opening match against New Zealand at the Paris 2024 Olympics due to allegations of flying a drone over a rival's training session.\n\nTwo coaching staff members, Joseph Lombardi and Jasmine Mander, have been sent back home by the Canadian Olympic Committee after being accused of involvement in the drone incident, Reuters reports.\n\nThe incident occurred during New Zealand's training session in St Etienne, disrupting their preparations for the tournament.\n\nFIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings against Canada Soccer, Beverly Priestman, Joseph Lombardi, and Jasmine Mander, while the Canadian Olympic Committee has apologised and promised a review of the incident.\n\nBeverly Priestman has apologised and taken responsibility for the actions of her staff, emphasising the importance of integrity and fair play.\n\n\"On July 22, a drone was flown over the New Zealand women's football team training session in St Etienne.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" NZOC said.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said they were informed of the incident involving \"a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team,\" adding at the time that they were \"reviewing next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer and FIFA.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" they said in a statement.\n\nPriestman later added a statement of her own and confirmed she would step aside for the first game, apologising again to New Zealand.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" the coach said.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the {"uri": "8241423136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:21:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:21:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:20:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.westernjournal.com/spying-scandal-rocks-olympics-games-even-get-underway-team-staffer-detained-law-enforcement/", "title": "Spying Scandal Rocks Olympics Before Games Even Get Underway - Team Staffer Detained by Law Enforcement", "body": "The Paris Summer Olympic Games haven't even started yet, but the foul play has.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee was forced to apologize on Tuesday, and discipline its delegation, after a drone flown by \"a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team\" for the Canadian women's soccer team was spotted over the practice of an upcoming rival, according to CNN.\n\nIn the statement, the Canadian Olympic Committee said it was \"shocked and disappointed\" that the drone had been flown over a practice session by the New Zealand women's team -- which Canada is due to face on the field on Thursday, CNN reported.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play, and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said, according to The Canadian Press. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nBut the fallout didn't stop with just apologies.\n\nHead Canadian coach Bev Priestman will sit out the match against New Zealand, according to CNN.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee also sent home two members of its delegation associated with the women's soccer team, according to CNN: Joseph Lombardi, described as an \"unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer\" and assistant coach Jasmine Mander.\n\nThe flyover took place Monday in Saint-\u00c9tienne , about 250 miles south of Paris, according to CNN.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee issued a statement denouncing the spying effort, saying it was \"deeply shocked and disappointed.\"\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian women's football team, to be detained.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nIn her own statement, Priestman took responsibility for the incident.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" the statement said, according to CNN.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThis isn't the first spot of bad publicity for the Games. {"uri": "8241593682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:12:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:12:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:11:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.theverge.com/2024/7/24/24205155/drones-olympics-soccer-canada-spying", "title": "Olympic drone spying scandal lands Canadian coach a red card", "body": "A member of the Canadian Olympic women's soccer team was caught using a drone to spy on New Zealand's practice session on Monday. It's said to be the second \"drone incident\" at a New Zealand practice over the past week.\n\nAs a result, the Canadian Olympic Committee has announced that soccer coach Bev Priestman will not coach the Olympic team's opening match tomorrow. Two other staffers have been removed from the team and are being sent home from the games.\n\nThe Canadian women's soccer team are the defending Olympic champions after winning gold at the Tokyo games in 2021. According to TSN, the New Zealand team is currently ranked 28th. Taking Priestman's place as head coach during tomorrow's match will be the team's assistant coach, Andy Spence.\n\nAn existing ban on flying drones around Paris is being strictly enforced by security during the 2024 Summer Olympics, which officially start tomorrow. French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday that security forces are intercepting an average of six drones each day using equipment such as electronic signal jammers, according to France 24.\n\nOn Monday, a drone was spotted flying over a practice session held by the New Zealand women's soccer team in Saint-\u00c9tienne, France, a city located about six hours south of Paris. The incident was reported to French authorities who located and detained the drone's operator, described by the COC as a \"non-accredited\" support member of the Canadian soccer team's staff, according to the CBC.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee \"formally lodged the incident with the [International Olympic Committee] integrity unit\" and asked the COC for a full review, according to a statement released by the New Zealand Olympic Committee yesterday.\n\nThe COC and head coach Priestman apologized to the NZOC and announced several disciplinary actions after reviewing Monday's events and a previous drone incident during a New Zealand practice on July 19th.\n\nIn addition to accepting Priestman's decision to be removed from coaching the team's opening match against New Zealand, two other members -- Joseph Lombardi, an \"an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer,\" and Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach -- are being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and being sent home. {"uri": "8241710394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:38:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:38:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:37:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://petapixel.com/2024/07/24/canadian-olympic-soccer-team-caught-spying-on-opponent-with-a-drone/", "title": "Canadian Olympic Soccer Team Caught Spying on Opponent with a Drone", "body": "The defending Olympic champion Canadian women's soccer team has become embroiled in a drone spying scandal that will see its head coach not present for the team's match tomorrow and two staffers have been sent home.\n\nCanada is set to kick off the women's soccer tournament against New Zealand tomorrow but will have to do so without their coach. Yesterday, New Zealand lodged a formal complaint to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) alleging that a Canadian soccer \"support staff member\" flew a drone over their training session on Monday, ESPN reports.\n\nThe individual flying the drone was detained by French authorities and Canada's team did issue an apology. the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said it was \"shocked and disappointed\" by the news and would launch its own investigation.\n\nThe spying incident is violates rules on two fronts. Firstly, drones are banned around Paris already and that law is being strictly enforced during the Olympics, The Verge reports. Secondly, spying is obviously a violation of Olympics rules.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Canada Soccer's Women's National Team Head Coach Bev Priestman says.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC issued a statement today highlighting four sanctions and consequences it will enforce as a result of the news. First, Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately. Next, Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi report sent, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately. Thirdly, Priestman removed herself from coaching the match against New Zealand on July 25th. {"uri": "8242683621", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "08:46:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T08:46:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T08:46:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/2-canadians-being-sent-home-immediately-removed-from-olympic-team-after-drone-incident-1.6975458", "title": "2 Canadians being 'sent home immediately,' removed from Olympic team after drone incident", "body": "An analyst and an assistant coach with Canada Soccer are being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and \"sent home immediately\" from the prelude to this year's Paris games, according to the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC).\n\nIn a statement released Wednesday, the COC announced Joseph Lombardi, whom they called \"an unaccredited analyst with Soccer Canada,\" and assistant coach Jasmine Mander, have been \"removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nThe COC also said they're in contact with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) and FIFA, and have been transparent and cooperative throughout the process, adding that further action may be taken as a review of the incident continues.\n\nOn Tuesday, the COC released a brief statement acknowledging that a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team\" had been detained by local authorities in Saint-\u00c9tienne, a small city 400 kilometres south of Paris, near Lyon, France.\n\n\"The staff member is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice,\" the earlier statement reads, acknowledging that the competing team lodged a complaint two days earlier, on July 22.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the COC said.\n\nThe COC statements echoed a July 23 release from the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) announcing the formal complaint to the IOC's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" the statement reads.\n\nAs part of the announced measures to address the incident, the Canadian team's head coach will remove herself from an upcoming match against New Zealand on Thursday morning, Paris time.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" said Bev Priestman, head coach of Canada Soccer's women's national team, in a statement.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nIn addition, Canada Soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training, the COC said.\n\n\"The actions of those involved do not reflect Canada's values or the values of sport,\" wrote Carla Qualtrough, Canada's minister of sport and physical activity, in a post to X Wednesday.\n\n\"I support the sanctions being imposed by the Canadian Olympic Committee, their apologies to New Zealand, and the decision of Head Coach Bev Priestman ... These decisive actions will help ensure that individuals are held accountable and preserve the integrity of the game and fair play for all athletes.\"\n\nThis week's incident isn't the first time suspicions of surveillance have shadowed a Canadian match.\n\nIn 2021, Honduras' men's soccer team was visiting Toronto for the two countries' 2022 FIFA World Cup qualifier match. Prior to the game, the visiting team held a training session that stopped abruptly after a drone was spotted hovering over the pitch, according to reports from The Associated Press citing Honduran media.\n\n\"I'd imagine there's probably a lot of people in Canada that fly drones, I'm sure ... And when a big team like Honduras turn up I'm sure people are probably interested in what they're doing when they come into our country.\" Canada's then-coach John Herdman was quoted to say in a report published the day before the match.\n\n\"So I know for sure we won't be heading into people's countries too early because with drones these days, people can obviously capture footage. You've got to be really careful.\"\n\nThe 2021 men's qualifier ended in a 1-1 draw, and Canada went on to qualify for the World Cup for the first time in 36 years. The team was later eliminated in the group stages of the tournament, falling to Morocco, Croatia and Belgium.\n\nCanada and New Zealand's women's soccer teams will face off Thursday at 11 a.m. Central European Time (5 a.m. EDT), their opening tournament match for the 2024 Paris Olympic Games.\n\nWith the Olympics starting this week, punishment for Canada Soccer could be announced in the coming days. When it comes to using drones as a form of cheating, Mount Allison University women's soccer coach Derek O'Keeffe says this could be a learning experience.\n\n\"I think it's important that as coaches, staff, directors, I think it's important you educate your staff in terms of the use of drones, and obviously the use of fair sports and play,\" O'Keeffe said. \"We're educating our coaches about all those things regarding fair play, sportsmanship and just being honest.\"\n\nSoccer journalist John Molinaro says expulsion from the tournament wouldn't fit the crime.\n\n\"I think kicking Canada out of the tournament would be an extreme measure and I can't seem to see it happening,\" Molinaro said, adding that Priestman could be suspended or there might be financial penalties levelled against Soccer Canada.\n\n\"I don't think we've heard or seen the last of this.\"\n\nFormer professional soccer player and longtime Nova Scotia coach Costa Elles says spying on a practice can clearly give a team an advantage.\n\n\"I think you'll be able to handle the pressure and hopefully they'll get through it but it doesn't make them feel good walking on a pitch and get ready to compete.\"", "source": {"uri": "8241597987", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:14:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:14:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:14:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/olympic-soccer-spygate-canada-staffer-detained-coach-sent-home-after-drone-incidents-081212983.html", "title": "Olympic soccer spygate: Canada staffer detained, coach sent home after drone incidents", "body": "PARIS -- A Canada soccer staffer was caught flying a drone over New Zealand training earlier this week as the two teams prepared to meet on opening day of the women's soccer competition here at the 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee acknowledged in a statement Wednesday that a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team was detained by French authorities\" following the incident.\n\nThe COC, which said it was \"shocked and disappointed,\" then added in a follow-up statement that there had been a \"second drone incident\" last week at a New Zealand practice.\n\nIt said that the non-accredited staffer, Joseph Lombardi, and his boss, assistant coach Jasmine Mander, would be removed from the Canadian delegation and sent home from the Games as punishment. Head coach Bev Priestman also self-imposed a one-game suspension.\n\nPriestman and the COC also apologized to New Zealand's soccer federation, to the New Zealand Olympic Committee and to \"all the players affected.\"\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for the conduct in our program,\" Priestman said in a statement. She said she would \"voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match\" against New Zealand \"to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity,\" and \"with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nNeither she nor Canada soccer, though, clarified whether or not she had knowledge of the drone operation.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee initially raised the issue with a Tuesday statement. When team members noticed the drone at a Monday session, they \"immediately reported the incident to police,\" the NZOC said.\n\nFrench authorities are on high alert this week ahead of Friday's Opening Ceremony, an open-air extravaganza on the River Seine. Amid security concerns, they have been strictly enforcing a ban on drones at and around Games venues throughout France. French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday that authorities were intercepting an average of six drones per day.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept [drones] and arrest their operators,\" Attal said. \"We can't allow anything to slip past us.\"\n\nThey have taken down drones flown by tourists, presumably unaware of the restrictions, Attal said.\n\nWhat they likely didn't anticipate was needing to police the reigning Olympic women's soccer champions ahead of a matchup with an underdog.\n\nCanada won gold in Tokyo. It opens its title defense Thursday in Saint-\u00c9tienne, several hours south of Paris, against New Zealand, the least-fancied team in a four-team group also featuring France and Colombia.\n\nBoth Canada and New Zealand have been training in the region ahead of the opener. After reporting the drone to police, the NZOC also said that it lodged a formal complaint with the International Olympic Committee, and \"asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe IOC said in a Wednesday statement that it \"welcomes the actions announced today by the Canadian Olympic Committee,\" that it received the complaint, and that it \"is looking into it.\"\n\n\"At the Olympic Games,\" the IOC concluded, \"we expect all the teams to behave and compete with respect.\"", "source": {"uri": "sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8240468766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "03:44:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T03:44:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T03:42:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://keyt.com/sports/national-sports/cnn-sports/2024/07/23/canada-olympic-chiefs-apologize-for-drone-flight-over-new-zealand-soccer-teams-training/", "title": "Canada Olympic chiefs apologize for drone flight over New Zealand soccer team's training", "body": "By Kevin Dotson, James Legge and Sahar Akbarzai CNN\n\n(CNN) -- Canadian Olympic chiefs have apologized after a member of staff for their women's soccer team allegedly flew a drone over a New Zealand team training session, three days before they face each other at the Paris Games.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) acknowledged that \"a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team was detained by French authorities\" after a complaint was made by New Zealand Football.\n\nDefending Olympic champions Canada are set to play New Zealand on Thursday in a group-stage game.\n\nNew Zealand's team spotted the drone flying overhead Monday during their training session in Saint-\u00c9tienne, a city 400 kilometers (250 miles) south of the French capital, where the match will be played.\n\nIn its statement, the COC said it \"stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed.\"\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee. We are reviewing next steps with the IOC (International Olympic Committee), Paris 2024, Canada Soccer, and FIFA.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it was \"deeply shocked and disappointed.\"\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian women's football team, to be detained,\" it said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review. Team Canada has issued an apology and is investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident.\"\n\nCanada Soccer spokesperson Paulo Senra told CNN his federation \"is working closely and cooperatively with the Canadian Olympic Committee on the matter involving the Women's National Team.\"\n\nNew Zealand Football, soccer's world governing body FIFA, the IOC and Paris 2024 have not replied to CNN's requests for more information.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8241853725", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:37:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:37:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:36:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://tnc.news/2024/07/24/canada-womens-soccer-staff-sanctioned/", "title": "Canada women's soccer staff sanctioned after getting caught spying on rival team", "body": "As the Canadian women's soccer team gears up for the Paris Olympics, two staff members, including an assistant coach, have been implicated in a scheme to spy on the New Zealand national team's practices.\n\nTeam Canada have removed assistant coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi from the Olympic team and have sent them back to Canada.\n\nOn Tuesday, French authorities were notified of a drone that was seen flying over the New Zealand women's soccer training session, which led to the drone operator's detainment.\n\nThe drone operator was identified as Joseph Lombardi, a non-accredited member of the Canadian women's team's support staff.\n\nLombardi is believed to have attempted to record the New Zealand women's team practicing on July 19th, and on July 22nd ahead of Canada's July 25 game against New Zealand.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said that they were shocked by the incident and apologized to the New Zealand soccer team.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" reads the COC statement.\n\nHead Coach Bev Priestman offered to sit out of Canada's game against New Zealand on Wednesday, a decision that the COC accepted.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" said Priestman.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nTrue North reached out to Team Canada for comment, though no response was received.\n\nThe Liberal government's minister of sport and physical activity Carla Qualtrough emphasized that the spying scandal does not reflect Canadian values and supported the sanctions placed on Lombardi and Mander.\n\n\"Fair play is the highest principle of sport. The actions of those involved do not reflect Canada's values or the values of sport,\" said Qualtrough on X.\n\n\"When rules are broken, there must be consequences. I support the sanctions being imposed by the Canadian Olympic Committee, their apologies to New Zealand, and the decision of Head Coach Bev Priestman.\"\n\nThe Canada women's soccer spying scandal throws a wrench into the team's attempt to repeat as Olympic gold medalists.\n\nCanada's women's soccer team placed first at the Tokyo Olympics in 2021, beating out the competitive American team who Team Canada has issued an apology and is investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident.\"\n\nFrench security forces Paris 2024 sites are intercepting an average of six drones every day, On Monday, days before Canada and New Zealand would play their Olympic opener, a drone was spotted flying over the New Zealand women's soccer team's training session in Saint-Etienne, France.\n\nNew Zealand staffers reported the drone to French authorities, who later detained the operator, Joseph Lombardi, a non-accredited analyst working with Canada Soccer.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee confirmed Lombardi had used a drone to record New Zealand's training session and issued an apology on Wednesday. The Committee added that Lombardi and Jasmine Mander, the assistant coach who oversees Lombardi, were being removed from the team and sent home. The rest of Canada Soccer's staff will undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nCanada head coach Bec Priestman also self-imposed a one-game suspension and will sit out of Thursday's opener against New Zealand.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said in a statement. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\n\nCanada and New Zealand are in Group A along with France and Colombia. But on Monday, just three days before the two teams are set to meet, New Zealand's Olympic Committee (NZOC) said their women's football team had their training session disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of the Canadian team.\n\nThe NZOC subsequently reported the incident to the police, leading to the drone operator being detained. The NZOC added that it was \"shocked and disappointed\".\n\n\"On July 22, a drone was flown over the New Zealand women's football team training session in St Etienne,\" the NZOC said on Wednesday. \"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained.\"\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee later apologised for the incident and said they were informed of the incident involving \"a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team.\" They added that they are \"reviewing next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer and FIFA.\"\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" the COC said in a statement.\n\nCanada's women's national team won gold in Tokyo in 2021 after they defeated Sweden on penalties. Led by British manager Beverly Priestman, Canada won the gold medal after claiming back-to-back bronze medals at the 2012 and 2016 Olympic Games respectively.\n\nCanada and New Zealand's Group A opponents include France and Colombia. The United States, Zambia, Germany and Australia compose Group B, while Spain, Japan, Nigeria and Brazil are in Group C. The top two teams from each group along with the two best third-placed teams progress to the quarterfinals.\n\nReigning world champions Spain, embarking on their Olympic debut, are favourites to win gold. Their surprise came when they found out the operator was a member of Team Canada's support staff.\n\nTeam New Zealand complained\n\nAccording to the Associated Press, New Zealand announced that it has filed a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) integrity unit over a drone that flew over one of their training sessions earlier this week.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) published a statement in their official web page regarding this matter:\n\nOn July 22, a drone was flown over the New Zealand women's football team training session in St Etienne.\n\nTeam support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained.\n\nThe NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\n\nTeam Canada has issued an apology and is investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident.\n\nThe NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024.\n\nAt this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\n\nDesire to clarify the facts\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee denied any connection with this incident stating that the person detained does not belong to the Canada's Soccer support team. They also expressed they feel shocked and disappointed by this allegations.\n\nThe COC is currently investigating the matter and would address the ending of the story as soon as possible. Canada Soccer has been transparent and cooperative throughout the process,\" the COC said.\n\n\"The COC will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary.\"\n\nIt named the staff members sent home as Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, and Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Lombardi reported.\n\nPriestman said she did not think it would be appropriate to be on the bench for the clash against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. {"uri": "8241352233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:38:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:38:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:37:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://ici.radio-canada.ca/rci/en/news/2090784/canada-soccer-drone-july-24", "title": "Canadian soccer coach Priestman to miss Olympic opener after staffers alleged to have spied on opponent | RCI", "body": "Canadian women's soccer coach Bev Priestman removed herself from Thursday's Olympic Games opener against New Zealand and two team staff members were sent home after two drone incidents.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi were ousted from the soccer team's staff, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday in a statement in which it accepted Priestman's decision to not coach the opener in Saint-Etienne, France.\n\nThe shakeup came after the COC's review of drone incidents in Saint-Etienne. There were reports that drones flew over New Zealand's practice sessions both Monday and last Friday.\n\nI am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program, Priestman said in Wednesday's statement. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\n\nOn behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\n\nThe COC also said that Canada Soccer staff will be required to undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nNational team assistant coach Andy Spence will lead Canada against New Zealand, Priestman confirmed to reporters on Wednesday. Spence was with the team last year at the World Cup.\n\nThe match begins at 11 a.m. ET and will be carried live on CBC TV, including live stream coverage on CBCSports.ca (new window) and CBC Gem.\n\nCanada is the defending Olympic champion in women's soccer after capturing gold three years ago in Tokyo. New Zealand is ranked 28th in the world.\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee alerted police after a drone was flown over the women's soccer team practice Monday, and the COC confirmed Tuesday that a non-accredited member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities.\n\nThe NZOC also registered a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit and had asked Canada for a full review.\n\nThe COC apologized to the NZOC and that country's soccer federation, stating it was shocked and disappointed over the conduct.\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nFrench security forces guarding Paris 2024 sites are intercepting an average of six drones per day, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday.\n\nAttal added the drones are often operated by individuals, maybe tourists wanting to take pictures.\n\nThat's why it's important to remind people of the rules. concern", "body": "New Zealand's Olympic team has lodged a complaint with the IOC after discovering a drone belonging to soccer rivals Canada seemingly spying on their training session.\n\nStaff from New Zealand's women's soccer team - the Football Ferns - noticed a drone flying above their training session in St Etienne on Monday.\n\nReporting it to police, the operator was identified as a supporting staff member of Canada's women's team.\n\nThe person was detained by French police.\n\nCanada are the reigning Olympic champions and New Zealand's first opponents at the Paris Games, on Friday morning (AEST).\n\nA statement issued by the New Zealand Olympic Committee said they were \"deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident\" and wanted answers.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review,\" the statement read.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games.\"\n\nIn their own statement, Team Canada apologised and said they'd opened their own investigation into a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nCanada's Olympic Committee is liaising with Canada Soccer, the IOC, the Paris Games organising committee and FIFA over \"next steps\" from the The drone incident occurred earlier this week, the New Zealand Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe NZOC statement said Canada had apologized over the incident and is investigating.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" the NZOC said.\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been accused of using a drone to film an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\n___\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games", "source": {"uri": "seattletimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Seattle Times"}, reigning Olympic champions", "body": "New Zealand's Olympic team has lodged a complaint with the IOC after discovering a drone belonging to soccer rivals Canada seemingly spying on their training session.\n\nStaff from New Zealand's women's football team -- the Football Ferns -- noticed a drone flying above their training session in St Etienne on Monday.\n\nReporting it to police, the operator was identified as a supporting staff member of Canada's women's team.\n\nCanada are the reigning Olympic champions and New Zealand's first opponents at the Paris Games, on Friday morning (AEST).\n\nA statement issued by the New Zealand Olympic Committee said they were \"deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident\" and wanted answers.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review,\" the statement read.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games.\"\n\nIn their own statement, Team Canada apologised and said they'd opened their own investigation into a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team\".\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" it read.\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nCanada's Olympic Committee is liaising with Canada Soccer, the IOC, the Paris Games organising committee and FIFA over \"next steps\" from the incident.\n\nNew Zealand and {"uri": "8241692298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:24:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:24:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:23:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/jul/24/canada-shocked-after-spying-scandal-hits-olympic-womens-football-champions", "title": "Canada 'shocked' after spying scandal hits Olympic women's football champions", "body": "Drone was used to record New Zealand training sessionsTeam staff member admits spying on opponents\n\nCanada's Olympic women's football team is in turmoil after officials were \"shocked and disappointed\" to learn drones were used to spy on their opponents. As part of the collateral damage, two staff with the women's team have been \"sent home immediately\" and their head coach will be absent when Canada take on New Zealand in their Olympic opener on Thursday.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team\" had been detained by French authorities in Saint-\u00c9tienne, a city 250 miles south of Paris, for improperly using a drone. The arrest follows a separate incident in which a drone was used to record New Zealand's training sessions.\n\nHead coach Bev Priestman, who led the Canadian team to gold three years ago in Tokyo, denied any involvement in the scheme - but said she would voluntarily \"step aside\" for the first game.\n\n\"Irrespective of the details, I'm ultimately accountable for this team,\" Priestman said on Wednesday afternoon following a team practice. \"By no means did I direct the individuals ... I'm still learning the details and obviously this is all unfolding. But again, I think the important thing right now is to look forward, put the actions in place and take the sanctions.\"\n\nThe COC said staff at the football team had been \"transparent and cooperative throughout the process\". Assistant coach Andy Spence will be in charge of the defending champions when they face New Zealand.\n\nThe dramatic shake-up came after New Zealand's Olympic Committee told the IOC that suspicious drones flew over team practices on two occasions.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" the sports body said in a statement.\n\nFollowing the allegations, the COC investigated and subsequently removed assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi from the team's staff and said they were \"immediately sent home\".\n\nLombardi admitted to using the drone to capture New Zealand players carrying out instructions given by their coach. Mander was also interviewed by officials but denied any involvement in the recordings and was cleared of wrongdoing.\n\nThe COC said that football staff will be required to undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\n\"Fair play is the highest principle of sport. The actions of those involved do not reflect Canada's values or the values of sport,\" Carla Qualtrough, Canada's minister of sport and physical activity, wrote in a post on social media. \"I support the sanctions being imposed by the Canadian Olympic Committee, their apologies to New Zealand, and the decision of Head Coach Bev Priestman ... These decisive actions will help ensure that individuals are held accountable and preserve the integrity of the game and fair play for all athletes.\"\n\nThe scandal has dampened spirits as Canada look to defend their Olympic title.\n\n\"Obviously it's not ideal, especially with such a big tournament on the horizon,\" Canadian centre back Vanessa Gilles told reporters. \"But at the end of the day we're all professionals. We're all going to make the most out of the situation we're put in. {"uri": "8241724872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:50:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:50:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:49:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://frontofficesports.com/canadian-soccer-analyst-drone-spying/", "title": "Canada Soccer Analyst Admits to Spying on Opponent", "body": "Canada won the gold medal at the Tokyo Games in 2021. Head coach Bev Priestman won't coach against New Zealand.\n\nThe Canadian women's soccer team will begin its gold medal defense with a scandal.\n\nAt least one Canadian soccer staffer flew a drone over New Zealand's practices in Saint-Etienne this week ahead of their game Thursday.\n\nJoseph Lombardi, an analyst with the team, and Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach, were both removed from the Olympic team and sent home, the Canadian Olympic Committee said in a statement; Lombardi reported to Mander. Head coach Bev Priestman has removed herself from coaching against New Zealand in the Group A opener Thursday.\n\nPolice saw the drone and arrested Lombardi on Monday, and he admitted to spying on the New Zealand team that day and over the weekend. Cops also interviewed Mander, who denied having anything to do with it. Lombardi pleaded guilty to a charge related to flying an illegal drone and accepted an eight-month suspended sentence and a 45,000-euro fine, according to the CBC.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee confirmed Lombardi operated the drone \"to record the New Zealand women's football team practice.\"\n\nThe COC said Team Canada's staff will undergo \"mandatory ethics training,\" and apologized to New Zealand's players, federation and the International Olympic Committee expressing its shock and disappointment.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said in a statement. \"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\"\n\nPriestman denied overseeing the drone scheme, but dodged questions about what she knew about it. \"By no means did I direct the individuals,\" she told the CBC.\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee filed a formal complaint with the International Olympic Committee and asked for a \"full review.\" The IOC said it \"welcomes the actions announced today by the Canadian Olympic Committee,\" and that it \"is looking into it,\" in a statement released Wednesday.\n\n\"At the Olympic Games,\" the IOC added, \"we expect all the teams to behave and compete with respect.\" FIFA said it is investigating.\n\nDrones have been an early story of the Olympics as French prime minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday that six drones per day have been intercepted at Olympic sites, mostly from tourists.\n\nWomen's soccer starts play Thursday, with Canada and New Zealand opening Group A play at 5 p.m. local time/11 a.m. ET. The drone incident occurred earlier this week, the New Zealand Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe NZOC statement said Canada had apologized over the incident and is investigating.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" the NZOC said.\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been accused of using a drone to film an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. {"uri": "8242309637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "04:00:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T04:00:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T03:59:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/sports/olympics/story/paris-olympics-2024-womens-football-canada-coach-steps-down-bev-priestman-drone-incident-2571521-2024-07-25", "title": "Paris Olympics 2024: Canada head coach steps down for opener after drone incident", "body": "Priestman was sidelined from coaching the team in Canada vs New Zealand\n\nCanada's women's soccer team faced controversy at the Paris Olympics when head coach Bev Priestman stepped down from her duties for the opening match after a spying scandal emerged. The incident involved a drone reportedly flown by Canadian staff over New Zealand's training session, disrupting their preparations. This led to FIFA initiating disciplinary proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, and the implicated staff members.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) responded by removing two staff members from their Olympic squad, who were previously gold medalists at the Tokyo Games. Additionally, Priestman was sidelined from coaching the team in their upcoming match against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nThe fallout continued as a French court handed an eight-month suspended jail term to one of the staff members involved, identified as Lombardi, and confiscated the materials associated with the incident. FIFA announced that it had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi, and another staff member, Mander, for a potential breach of the organization's disciplinary code.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA said in a statement.\n\nPriestman apologized to the New Zealand football team and its staff and took responsibility for the incident.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nIn response to the scandal, Canada Soccer stated it would conduct an independent external review. This investigation aims not only to understand the specific circumstances of the incident but also to examine the historical culture of competitive ethics across all its programs.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians,\" Canada Soccer President Peter Augruso and CEO Kevin Blue said in a statement.\n\n\"We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\"\n\nThe incident had come to light after the New Zealand Olympic Committee had The COC said it will provide an update Wednesday.\n\n\"Canada Soccer is working closely and cooperatively with the Canadian Olympic Committee on the matter involving the Women's National Team,\" Canada Soccer communications chief Paulo Senra said it a statement. \"Next steps are being reviewed with the IOC, Paris 2024, and FIFA. We will provide an update (Wednesday).\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been accused of using a drone to film an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nFrench security forces guarding Paris 2024 sites are intercepting an average of six drones per day, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday.\n\nAttal added the drones are often operated by \"individuals, maybe tourists wanting to take pictures.\"\n\n\"That's why it's important to remind people of the rules. There's a ban on flying drones,\" he said, according to multiple news outlets.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept (drones) and arrest their operators.\"\n\nThis report by who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe NZOC statement said Canada had apologized over the incident and is investigating.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are {"uri": "8241214045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:14:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:14:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:13:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/olympic-soccer-spygate-canada-staffer-detained-coach-sent-home-after-drone-incident-081212651.html", "title": "Olympic soccer spygate: Canada staffer detained, coach sent home after drone incident", "body": "PARIS -- A Canada soccer staffer was caught flying a drone over a New Zealand training session earlier this week as the two teams prepared to meet on opening day of the women's soccer competition here at the 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee acknowledged in a statement Wednesday that a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team was detained by French authorities\" following the incident.\n\nThe COC then added in a follow-up statement that the analyst, Joseph Lombardi, and his boss, assistant coach Jasmine Mander, would be removed from the Canadian delegation and sent home from the Games.\n\nThe COC said that the staffer \"is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice.\"\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee said in an earlier statement that, when they noticed the drone, \"team support members immediately reported the incident to police.\"\n\nFrench authorities are on high alert this week ahead of Friday's Opening Ceremony, an open-air extravaganza on the River Seine. Amid security concerns, they have been strictly enforcing a ban on drones at and around Games venues throughout France. French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday that authorities were intercepting an average of six drones per day.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept [drones] and arrest their operators,\" Attal said. \"We can't allow anything to slip past us.\"\n\nThey have taken down drones flown by tourists, presumably unaware of the restrictions, Attal said.\n\nWhat they likely didn't anticipate was needing to police the reigning Olympic women's soccer champions ahead of a matchup with an underdog.\n\nCanada won gold in Tokyo. It opens its title defense Thursday in Saint-\u00c9tienne, several hours south of Paris, against New Zealand, the least-fancied team in a four-team group also featuring France and Colombia.\n\nBoth Canada and New Zealand have been training in the region ahead of the opener. After reporting the drone to police, the NZOC also said that it lodged a formal complaint with the International Olympic Committee, and \"asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe IOC has not yet commented, and did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. It's unclear if Canada might be punished.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said it was \"shocked and disappointed\" after learning of the incident.\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" the COC said in its statement. \"We are reviewing next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer, and FIFA [soccer's global governing body]. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Canadian head coach Bev Priestman said in a statement on Wednesday.\n\nThe Canadians also confessed \"of a second drone incident at a July 19th New Zealand practice,\" in the statement.\n\nPriestman, accordingly, stepped down along with \"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer\" and \"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to.\"\n\n\"I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld,\" Priestman wrote.\n\n\"Canada Soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training,\" the statement added.\n\nHowever, the Canadians were not the first committee to illegally fly drones around the practice area.\n\nMembers of French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal's team told Agence France-Presse that the communications director of the Brazilian delegation was also apprehended for operating a drone.\n\nAttal also said that French authorities have intercepted an average of six drones every day near Olympic sites.\n\nHowever, he qualified that the drones are being used by \"individuals, maybe tourists wanting to take pictures.\"\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. {"uri": "8240289663", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "00:11:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T00:11:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:10:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5654570/2024/07/23/new-zealand-soccer-spy-canada-olympics/", "title": "Canada's Olympic Committee apologizes after alleged spying attempt", "body": "The Olympic women's soccer tournament is starting with some unexpected drama, following a complaint from New Zealand's Olympic Committee concerning a potential attempt at spying on a training session ahead of the Paris Games.\n\nA drone was flown over a Ferns training session in Saint-\u00c9tienne on July 22, New Zealand's Olympic Committee (NZOC) said in a statement Tuesday in France. Ferns staffers reported the drone to police, who detained the operator, identified as a staff member of the \"wider Canadian Women's Football team,\" according to the statement. The NZOC logged the incident to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) integrity unit and asked Canada's Olympic Committee for a review.\n\nNew Zealand and Canada are in Group A for the Olympic tournament, along with France and Colombia.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) issued its own statement Wednesday, clarifying that the drone operator was a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team\" but confirming that that staff member \"is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice.\"\n\nThe COC apologized to New Zealand's players, federation and the Olympic Committee, saying it was \"shocked and disappointed.\"\n\nAs of early Wednesday in France, it's unclear what consequences there could be for the alleged attempt to record another team's training session. The COC said it plans to discuss next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer and FIFA, and would provide an update later Wednesday.\n\nDrones have been a story across Paris 2024, with French prime minister Gabriel Attal saying Tuesday that an average of six drones per day have been intercepted at Olympic sites.\n\nThe women's football tournament begins play on July 25. Canada and New Zealand open action in Group A at 5 p.m. local/11 a.m. ET in Saint-\u00c9tienne. The allegations come ahead of Thursday's opening match at the tournament between defending Olympic champions Canada and New Zealand.\n\n\"On July 22, a drone was flown over the New Zealand women's football team training session in St Etienne,\" the NZOC said. They reported that the support members quickly reported the incident to the police. This led to the drone operator, identified as a support member of the broader Canadian Women's football team, being detained.\n\nNZOC has formally complained to the IOC integrity unit and have notified Canada for a full review and that the whole situation is about \"integrity and fairness.\" Team Canada, in response, have issued an apology and are themselves investigating the events that led such a bizarre situation.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee have said that they are aware that a \"non-accredited\" member of its support was using a drone to record the Silver Ferns' practice. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThis won't be the first time that the Canadian football team have been embroiled in a drone-related controversy involving an opponent's training session. In 2021, in Toronto, Honduras had to stop their training session before their men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to media reports. {"uri": "2024-07-432100006", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:42:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:42:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:59:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/sports/olympics-and-paralympics/soccer-coach-priestman-to-miss-olympic-opener-two-staffers-sent-home-after-drone-incidents/article_f35312e6-2212-5271-9ea0-3ae1abf252b4.html", "title": "Soccer coach Priestman to miss Olympic opener, two staffers sent home after drone incidents", "body": "SAINT-ETIENNE, France - Canadian women's soccer coach Bev Priestman removed herself from Thursday's Olympic Games opener against New Zealand and two team staff members were sent home after two drone incidents.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi were ousted from the soccer team's staff, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday in a statement in which it accepted Priestman's decision to not coach the opener in Saint-Etienne, France.\n\nThe shakeup came after the COC's review of a drone incidents in Saint-Etienne. There were reports that drones flew over New Zealand's practice sessions both Monday and last Friday.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" Priestman said in Wednesday's statement. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nThe COC also said that Canada Soccer staff will be required to undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nCanada is the defending Olympic champion in women's soccer after capturing gold three years ago in Tokyo. New Zealand is ranked 28th in the world.\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee alerted police after a drone was flown over the women's soccer team practice Monday, and the COC confirmed Tuesday that a \"non-accredited\" member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities.\n\nThe NZOC also registered a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit and had asked Canada for a full review.\n\nThe COC apologized to the NZOC and that country's soccer federation, stating it was \"shocked and disappointed\" over the conduct.\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nFrench security forces guarding Paris 2024 sites are intercepting an average of six drones per day, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday.\n\nAttal added the drones are often operated by \"individuals, maybe tourists wanting to take pictures.\"\n\n\"That's why it's important to remind people of the rules. There's a ban on flying drones,\" he said, according to multiple news outlets.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept (drones) and arrest their operators.\"\n\nThis report by final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.'\n\nThe statement went on, 'The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.'\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their 'unequivocal disapproval' in a joint statement announcing that their organization would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\n'On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials,' they said in a statement.\n\n'Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\n\n'As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\nTwo team members have been sent home from the Olympics for spying with a drone\n\nNew Zealand's Football Ferns noticed a drone flying above their training session on Monday\n\nPriestman has removed herself from coaching the team during the Paris Olympic Games\n\n'The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.'\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo 'mandatory ethics training'.\n\nPriestman said, 'On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,' Priestman said.\n\n'This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n'In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.'\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had of Games after drone incident", "body": "PARIS: Canada coach Bev Priestman removed herself from their opening match duties at the Paris Olympics while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games after a spying scandal engulfed the women's football tournament.\n\nGlobal football's governing body FIFA said they had begun disciplinary proceedings after New Zealand's women's team said their training session on Monday had been disrupted by a drone flown by a staff member of their opening Group A opponents Canada.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said on Wednesday they had taken action to remove two members of staff from their Olympic squad, who were gold medallists at the Tokyo Games, while Priestman would not take charge against New Zealand.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said on Wednesday they had \"opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Ms Beverly Priestman, Mr Joseph Lombardi and Ms Jasmine Mander due to the potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA Disciplinary Code and article 6.1 of the Regulations Olympic Football\".\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA explained in a statement.\n\nPriestman apologised for what had happened and said ultimate responsibility lay with her.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe incident was reported by the
