{"uri": "2024-07-432699822", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:32:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:32:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:50:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/au/fifa-takes-action-against-canada-soccer-and-coach-bev-priestman-over-olympics-spying-incident-with-drones/", "title": "FIFA takes action against Canada Soccer and coach Bev Priestman over Olympics spying incident with drones - Internewscast Journal", "body": "FIFA is investigating allegations about the Canadian women's soccer team's head coach Bev Priestman regarding the use of a drone to spy on Olympic opponents, specifically New Zealand.\n\nFIFA's disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, along with Priestman and two other members of the team.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and unaccredited analyst Joseph Lombardi from Canada Soccer have been sent home due to their involvement in potential drone usage during Football Ferns training sessions, as suggested by the Canadian Olympic Committee.\n\nBev Priestman, previously an assistant to Phil Neville, will not be leading the defending Olympic champions in their opening match against New Zealand. Andy Spence will serve as the interim coach for this important game.\n\nIn a statement issued on Wednesday, FIFA confirmed it has opened proceedings against Priestman, Lombardi and Mander.\n\nIt cited a 'potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA disciplinary code and article 6.1 of the regulations Olympic football tournaments games of the XXXIII Olympiad Paris 2024 - final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.'\n\nThe statement went on, 'The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.'\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their 'unequivocal disapproval' in a joint statement announcing that their organization would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\n'On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials,' they said in a statement.\n\n'Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\n\n'As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n'The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.'\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo 'mandatory ethics training'.\n\nPriestman said, 'On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,' Priestman said.\n\n'This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n'In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.'\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had been detained by French authorities in St Etienne following a complaint by New Zealand Football on July 22.\n\nFollowing the COC's review of that incident it said it had learned of a 'second drone {"uri": "8241415875", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:17:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:17:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:16:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/soccer-coach-priestman-to-miss-opener-two-staffers-sent-home-after-drone-incidents-5692833", "title": "Soccer Coach Priestman to Miss Opener, Two Staffers Sent Home After Drone Incidents", "body": "Canadian women's soccer coach Bev Priestman removed herself from Thursday's Olympic Games opener against New Zealand and two team staff members were sent home after two drone incidents.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi were ousted from the soccer team's staff, the Canadian Olympic Committee said on July 24 in a statement in which it accepted Ms. Priestman's decision to not coach the opener in Saint-Etienne, France.\n\nThe shakeup came after the COC's review of drone incidents in Saint-Etienne. There were reports that drones flew over New Zealand's practice sessions both July 22 and July 19.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" Ms. Priestman said in the July 24 statement. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on July 25. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nThe COC also said that Canada Soccer staff will be required to undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nCanada is the defending Olympic champion in women's soccer after capturing gold three years ago in Tokyo. New Zealand is ranked 28th in the world.\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee alerted police after a drone was flown over the women's soccer team practice on July 22, and the COC confirmed on July 23 that a \"non-accredited\" member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities.\n\nThe NZOC also registered a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit and asked Canada for a full review.\n\nThe COC apologized to the NZOC and that country's soccer federation, stating it was \"shocked and disappointed\" over the conduct.\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nFrench security forces guarding Paris 2024 sites are intercepting an average of six drones per day, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said on July 23.\n\nAttal added the drones are often operated by \"individuals, maybe tourists wanting to take pictures.\"\n\n\"That's why it's important to remind people of the rules. There's a ban on flying drones,\" he said, according to multiple news outlets.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept (drones) and arrest their operators.\"", "source": {"uri": "8241838358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:24:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:24:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:22:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.cp24.com/news/soccer-coach-priestman-to-miss-opener-two-staffers-sent-home-after-drone-incidents-1.6975468", "title": "Soccer coach Priestman to miss opener, two staffers sent home after drone incidents", "body": "Two staff members on the outs. A head coach taking herself off the sideline. Now FIFA's disciplinary committee is involved and more developments could be coming.\n\nThe Canadian women's soccer team's Olympic title defence is off to a rocky start due to a drone scandal on the eve of the Paris Games.\n\n\"Obviously it's not ideal, especially with such a big tournament on the horizon,\" said Canadian centre back Vanessa Gilles. \"But at the end of the day we're all professionals. We're all going to make the most out of the situation we're put in.\n\n\"We're going to lean on each other.\"\n\nIn a statement, the Canadian Olympic Committee announced a list of \"sanctions and consequences\" after reviewing a drone incident Monday and learning of another last Friday at a New Zealand team practice.\n\nIt's believed a \"non-accredited\" staff member used an aerial device to record the New Zealand team during practice, the COC said.\n\nCanadian assistant coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi were \"sent home immediately,\" the COC said, adding that it had accepted the decision of coach Bev Priestman to remove herself from coaching the opening match against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\nPriestman held a brief media availability after guiding her squad through a one-hour practice session at Stade Auguste Dury.\n\n\"My reaction was you feel like this program has let the country down,\" she said. \"That, for me, that's why I took the proactive step to do what I felt was the right thing. Irrespective of the details, I'm ultimately accountable for this team.\"\n\nFIFA, the sport's governing body, said later Wednesday that it had opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the (coming) days,\" the release said.\n\nThe COC said that Canada Soccer staff will be required to undergo mandatory ethics training. The committee added it has been in contact with the IOC and FIFA and further action may be taken if necessary.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said in the COC release. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nBoth Mander and Lombardi were included on the team's six-member coaching staff list at the Games. Lombardi, who the COC called an unaccredited analyst, reports to Mander.\n\n\"By no means did I direct the individuals,\" Priestman said. \"I'm still learning the details and obviously this is all unfolding. But again, I think the important thing right now is to look forward, put the actions in place and take the sanctions.\"\n\nAssistant coach Andy Spence will be in charge on the Canadian sidelines in the Group A opener at Geoffrey-Guichard Stadium.\n\nEighth-ranked Canada captured Olympic gold three years ago in Tokyo. New Zealand is ranked 28th in the world.\n\nCanadian forward Janine Beckie called the news \"definitely disappointing and shocking\" but noted the players were \"incredibly resilient.\"\n\n\"Together we are still digesting it ourselves and are just really 100 per cent focused on the game,\" she said.\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee alerted police after a drone was flown over the team's practice Monday, and the COC confirmed Tuesday that a \"non-accredited\" member of Canada's soccer team staff had been detained by French authorities.\n\nAccording to CBC Sports, a Saint-Etienne prosecutor issued a press release stating that the detainee admitted to capturing images of New Zealand players applying instructions from their coach, allowing him to learn their tactics.\n\nThe detainee accepted a suspended sentence of eight months' imprisonment and the confiscation of his drone, the release said, after he was tried under a procedure of Appearance on Recognition of Guilt and charged with maintaining an unmanned aircraft over a prohibited area.\n\nThe NZOC also registered a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit and asked Canada for a full review. The COC apologized to the NZOC and that country's soccer federation, stating it was \"shocked and disappointed\" over the conduct.\n\n\"It's ultimately compromised, I think, the integrity of our match,\" said New Zealand interim head coach Michael Mayne. \"We're controlling what we can control. It's an overwhelming feeling of disappointment and I know the players are feeling the same.\"\n\nCOC chief executive officer David Shoemaker and chief sport officer Eric Myles were scheduled to hold a virtual media availability later Wednesday.\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nFrench security forces guarding Paris 2024 sites are intercepting an average of six drones per day, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday.\n\nAttal added the drones are often operated by \"individuals, maybe tourists wanting to take pictures.\"\n\n\"That's why it's important to remind people of the rules. There's a ban on flying drones,\" he said, according to multiple news outlets.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept (drones) and arrest their operators.\"", "source": Thursday with Canada facing New Zealand and Spain playing Japan.\n\nThere has been huge controversy ahead of reigning Olympic champions Canada's opening match, following allegations they spied on their opening opponents to gain an unfair advantage.\n\nA member of Canada's support staff has been arrested by French police following the spying allegations from New Zealand.\n\nThey claim a drone was used to infiltrate a training session at their base in St Etienne ahead of the match against Canada at Stade Geoffroy-Guichard.\n\nThe Kiwis have issued a formal complaint with the International {"uri": "8241467625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:50:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:50:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:49:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.ladysmithchronicle.com/sports/coach-to-sit-out-olympic-opener-after-drone-scandal-rocks-canada-soccer-7454646", "title": "Coach to sit out Olympic opener after drone scandal rocks Canada Soccer", "body": "National women's coach Bev Priestman removes herself after drones flew over rival's practice sessions\n\nCanadian women's soccer coach Bev Priestman removed herself from Thursday's Olympic Games opener against New Zealand and two team staff members were sent home after two drone incidents.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander, from North Delta, and Canada Soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi were ousted from the soccer team's staff, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday in a statement in which it accepted Priestman's decision to not coach the opener in Saint-Etienne, France.\n\nThe shakeup came after the COC's review of a drone incidents in Saint-Etienne. There were reports that drones flew over New Zealand's practice sessions both Monday and last Friday.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" Priestman said in Wednesday's statement. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nThe COC also said that Canada Soccer staff will be required to undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nCanada is the defending Olympic champion in women's soccer after capturing gold three years ago in Tokyo. New Zealand is ranked 28th in the world.\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee alerted police after a drone was flown over the women's soccer team practice Monday, and the COC confirmed Tuesday that a \"non-accredited\" member of Canada's soccer team staff was detained by French authorities.\n\nThe NZOC also registered a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit and had asked Canada for a full review.\n\nThe COC apologized to the NZOC and that country's soccer federation, stating it was \"shocked and disappointed\" over the conduct.\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian soccer team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. The teams played to a 1-1 draw.\n\nFrench security forces guarding Paris 2024 sites are intercepting an average of six drones per day, Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday.\n\nAttal added the drones are often operated by \"individuals, maybe tourists wanting to take pictures.\"\n\n\"That's why it's important to remind people of the rules. There's a ban on flying drones,\" he said, according to multiple news outlets.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept (drones) and arrest their operators.\"\n\nREAD ALSO: {"uri": "8243491780", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:47:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:47:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:46:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/canada-beats-new-zealand-in-olympic-womens-soccer-after-getting-caught-spying-on-their-opponents-with-a-drone/", "title": "Canada BEATS New Zealand in Olympic women's soccer after getting caught spying on their opponents with a drone", "body": "Reigning Olympic champions Canada have beaten New Zealand 2-1 in their opening women's soccer match after being caught spying on their opponents.\n\nOn Monday, staff from New Zealand's team noticed a drone flying above their training session in St Etienne, with the the Canadian Olympic Committee later confirming that two coaches had been sent home.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst, were implicated in the spying while head coach Bev Priestman also removed herself from coaching the team against New Zealand.\n\nPriestman and Canada Soccer are now being investigated by FIFA's disciplinary committee as well.\n\nFollowing the COC's review of the spying incident on Monday, the organization also said it had learned of a 'second drone incident' on July 19, according to PA.\n\nCanada beat New Zealand 2-1 in the Olympics - after being caught spying on their opponents\n\nCoach Bev Priestman removed herself from coaching the team vs. New Zealand on Thursday\n\nOn Wednesday, the operator of the drone was identified as a supporting staff member of Canada's team, with the person being detained by French police and also being handed an eight-month suspended prison sentence, according to prosecutors.\n\nProsecutors also said that the drone was seized.\n\nIn a previous statement, Canada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue condemned the spying and said an independent investigation would take place.\n\n'On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials,' they said.\n\n'Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritize integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologize.\n\n'As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.'\n\nNew Zealand staff noticed a drone flying above their training session in St Etienne on Monday\n\nTwo Canada team members have been sent home from the Olympics for spying with a drone\n\nA statement issued by the New Zealand Olympic Committee also said they were 'deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident' and wanted answers.\n\n'The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review,' the statement read.\n\n'The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games.'\n\nWithout Priestman, who apologized and said she was 'ultimately responsible' for the team's conduct, Canada came back from a 1-0 deficit as Cloe Lacasse and Evelyne Viens scored to turn the game around.\n\nThey'll face face {"uri": "8242129416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:28:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:28:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:27:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5657110/2024/07/24/canada-soccer-olympic-spying-scandal-explained/", "title": "Canada's Olympic soccer spying scandal explained: Who's involved, what's next and more", "body": "Canada's women's soccer team enters the Olympics as the reigning gold medalist and No. 8 team in the world.\n\nSo it's rather perplexing, then, that its Paris Games began with an accusation of spying on New Zealand, a team ranked 28th that has won only two Olympic games in its history.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) issued a complaint Monday about a drone being flown over its women's soccer team's practice. Police tracked the drone back to a staffer with the Canadian women's soccer team, and the fallout of the incident has been fast.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) removed two staffers, shared the findings of a second drone incident and announced that coach Bev Priestman will remain in her role -- but won't coach against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\nThe two teams face off in the opening game of Group A play Thursday at 11 a.m. ET, but questions about Canada's activity won't end there.\n\nHere's what we know so far.\n\nNew Zealand team staff members noticed a drone flying above their practice in Saint-\u00c9tienne, France, on Monday and notified police. Law enforcement tracked the drone back to its operator, Joseph Lombardi, an \"unaccredited analyst\" with the Canadian women's team, the COC said.\n\nThe \"unaccredited analyst\" distinction is only important from an Olympics perspective, with the number of accreditations limited for national teams to use. Lombardi is listed on Canada Soccer's staff as the National Development Centre Ontario and Women's U-20 Director.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday that a separate drone incident at New Zealand training -- on July 19 -- had come to light. The COC confirmed Lombardi used a drone \"to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice.\"\n\nThe COC apologized to New Zealand's players, federation and the International Olympic Committee, saying it was \"shocked and disappointed.\"\n\nLombardi and Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach who oversees Lombardi, were sent home from the Olympics.\n\nWithout naming him, a Saint-\u00c9tienne prosecutor said a 43-year-old Canadian man received an eight-month suspended sentence in French court for filming the two training sessions, according to the Associated Press.\n\nOn Wednesday, COC CEO David Shoemaker said that they had offered legal support and consular services to both Lombardi and Mander, as well as offering mental health support to the entirety of Canada's Olympic delegation.\n\nPriestman said Tuesday she would remove herself from managing the team during Thursday's game against New Zealand, while Shoemaker clarified Wednesday that she will remain in her role as coach for the rest of the tournament.\n\n\"We thought about all repercussions for Bev,\" Shoemaker said. \"At the end of the day, the drone footage related to the filming of two New Zealand practices remained in the hands of the pilot of the drone.\"\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" Priestman added. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe 37-year-old has been with Canada Soccer as the women's national team head coach since October 2020, departing her previous role as an assistant coach with England. She guided Canada to their gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics. The team underperformed at the 2023 World Cup, exiting in the group stage.\n\nEarlier this year, she signed a contract extension with Canada Soccer to keep her in the role through the 2027 World Cup.\n\nThis is the biggest remaining question -- with FIFA's pending investigation the biggest hurdle for her to clear. As of right now, the only consequence is one she imposed herself: she will not be on the sidelines for Thursday's match against New Zealand.\n\nHer reputation, however, is very much at risk. She has apologized publicly multiple times already, saying that she is the one ultimately accountable as the leader of the program and responsible for the actions of her staff.\n\nDue to strict European regulations that have been in place since 2021, drone hobbyists are barred from flying the aircrafts over people and can not share images or recordings without the other party's consent.\n\nDrones have been a story across the Paris Games, with French prime minister Gabriel Attal saying Tuesday that an average of six drones per day have been intercepted at Olympic sites, mostly from tourists trying to capture footage of the spectacle.\n\nShoemaker, the COC CEO, said that after reviewing the incident, they were satisfied with the proactive measures they had taken so far.\n\n\"I, with the facts available to me, made judgments that I think properly addresses the situation,\" Shoemaker said. \"An important factor here is that we did most of this with the full and complete cooperation of Canada Soccer, who I believe also is committed to fully determining root causes as it relates to these kinds of techniques and other pressures that coaches might feel they're under. In order to give their team the best chance of winning.\"\n\nShoemaker stressed that he believed Priestman's account that she was unaware of her staff's actions. He did say that if any new information were to be presented that suggested otherwise, the COC would \"reserve the right to impose further sanctions.\"\n\nFIFA said Wednesday it would investigate all potentially involved parties in the drone surveillance, including Priestman and Canada Soccer. It did not issue a precise timeline for when this might be resolved, with Priestman due to be back on the sideline for Canada's second group-stage match against France on Sunday in Saint-\u00c9tienne.\n\nAccording to Shoemaker, New Zealand also asked FIFA to not award Canada any points if it was to win Thursday's match, but he did not provide any further details or if FIFA was considering such a sanction.\n\nOn Wednesday, Canada Soccer issued its own statement, with president Peter Augruso and general secretary/CEO Kevin Blue expressing their \"unequivocal disapproval\" over the actions of the women's national team's staff.\n\nThey also pledged the federation would proceed with its own independent, external review, separate from the one launched by FIFA's disciplinary committee.\n\n\"This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs,\" they said. \"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken.\"\n\nIn a statement Thursday morning in New Zealand, New Zealand Football CEO Andrew Pragnell called for \"urgent action\" to be taken to \"address this integrity breach.\"\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament,\" Pragnell's statement said.\n\n\"We note that there have been some admissions by the Canadian National Olympic Committee, and they have taken their own sanctions against the Canadian team, however, considering the seriousness of the situation, and the potential implications to the sporting integrity of the entire tournament, we have referred the matter to the FIFA Disciplinary Committee seeking urgent action,\" the statement continued.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243006458", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:05:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:05:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:03:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.businessupturn.com/sports/soccer/why-did-canada-womens-soccer-fly-a-drone-over-new-zealands-practice/", "title": "Why did Canada women's soccer fly a drone over New Zealand's practice? | Business Upturn", "body": "Over 15 years after the NFL's infamous \"Spygate,\" a new sports scandal has emerged, this time involving the Canadian women's soccer team.\n\nOn Monday, July 22, the New Zealand women's soccer team noticed a drone flying over their practice session. They quickly reported it to the police, who identified the culprit as a member of the Canadian women's soccer support team. Although the person behind the drone wasn't named, Canada issued a statement describing them as a \"non-accredited member of the Canada soccer support team\" and denounced the act, emphasizing their commitment to fair play.\n\nThe timing of this incident is crucial, as Canada is set to play against New Zealand in their first game of the 2024 Paris Olympics women's soccer tournament. It appears the drone was being used to gain an advantage by spying on New Zealand's training session. With Group A featuring tough competition from France, Canada, New Zealand, and Colombia, every bit of information could be seen as crucial.\n\nThe police detained the staff member responsible for the drone, and the New Zealand Olympic Committee reported the incident to the International Olympic Committee. The Canadian Olympic Committee issued an official apology, expressing shock and disappointment. They emphasized their dedication to fair play and apologized to New Zealand Football and the affected players.\n\nCanada's head coach, Bev Priestman, will not be coaching the first game against New Zealand. An investigation revealed two incidents of drones flying over New Zealand's training sessions, leading to this decision. Additionally, two staff members from Canada Soccer are being sent home, and the entire staff will undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nFIFA has opened proceedings against Bev Priestman, Jasmine Mander, and Joseph Lombardi for potential breaches of the FIFA Disciplinary Code and Regulations of Olympic Football Tournaments. The drone pilot received a suspended eight-month sentence from French prosecutors, meaning the sentence will only be served if the pilot is caught again.\n\nThe New Zealand Football Federation has referred the incident to the FIFA Disciplinary Committee, ensuring that the matter is taken seriously and addressed appropriately.\n\nThis scandal, dubbed a sequel to \"Spygate,\" has stirred significant controversy right before the 2024 Paris Olympics. With the Canadian team's reputation on the line and disciplinary actions underway, the incident serves as a reminder of the importance of sportsmanship and ethical conduct in competitive sports.", {"uri": "8241699795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:30:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:30:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:29:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/football/paris-olympics-2024-canada-womens-football-drone-incident-coach-steps-aside-for-opener/article68442980.ece", "title": "Paris Olympics 2024: Canada women's football coach will step aside for team's opener because of drone incidents", "body": "Canada women's football coach Bev Priestman said Wednesday she'll step away from the team's opening game against New Zealand at the Paris Olympics in the wake of a pair of drone incidents.\n\nNew Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after it said drones were flown over practice sessions earlier in the week.\n\nTwo staff members -- assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada football analyst Joseph Lombardi -- were sent home, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for the conduct in our program,\" Priestman said in a statement. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nALSO READ: Paris 2024 Olympics: Argentina equaliser vs Morocco disallowed, football match to resume behind closed doors\n\nThe Canadians are the defending gold medalists. This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\"\n\nThe COC confirmed Tuesday that a nonaccredited member of Canada's football team staff was detained by French authorities after a drone was spotted above training.\n\nThe COC also apologised to the New Zealand Olympic Committee and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nThe NZOC said it and New Zealand Football \"are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games -- at this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian football team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. {"uri": "8242054424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:00:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:00:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:58:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/olympics-canadian-coach-analyst-kicked-out-of-games-after-drone-incident/2189983/", "title": "Olympics-Canadian coach, analyst kicked out of Games after drone incident", "body": "The Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said on Wednesday it had taken action to remove two members of staff from their Olympic squad, who were gold medallists at the Tokyo Games, while Priestman would not take charge against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately,\" COC said in a statement.\n\n\"Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi reports to, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately.\"\n\nLombardi was handed an eight-month suspended jail term and his material was confiscated, a French court said.\n\nFIFA said on Wednesday it had \"opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Ms Beverly Priestman, Mr Joseph Lombardi and Ms Jasmine Mander due to the potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA Disciplinary Code and article 6.1 of the Regulations Olympic Football.\"\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days,\" FIFA explained in a statement.\n\nPriestman apologised for what had happened and said ultimate responsibility lay with her.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program.\n\n\"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe incident was reported by the NZOC to the police and to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and Canada apologized for the incident, which recalled a similar event with their men's team in 2021.\n\nNew Zealand has filed a formal complaint with the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) integrity unit following a controversial drone incident. The drone, found flying over a New Zealand women's soccer training session, was operated by a member of the Canadian team's support staff.\n\nThe issue arose earlier this week just days before the defending Olympic champions, Canada, are set to face New Zealand in their opening Olympic match. According to the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC), support members reported the drone to police, leading to the detention of its operator, identified as part of the Canadian Women's football support team.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee has since apologized, expressing profound disappointment and reaffirming their commitment to fair play. The NZOC emphasized their dedication to supporting their athletes and maintaining the integrity of the Olympic Games. training session was found to be operated by a member of the Canadian team's support staff.\n\nDefending Olympic champions Canada and New Zealand meet in their opening match at the Olympic tournament today.\n\nThe drone incident occurred earlier this week, the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) said yesterday.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC have formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and have asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe NZOC statement said Canada had apologised over the incident and are investigating.\n\n\"The NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024,\" the NZOC said.\n\n\"At this time the NZOC's main priority is to support the New Zealand women's football athletes and wider team as they start their campaign.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian team have been accused of using a drone to film an international rivals' training session.\n\nIn 2021 at Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of their men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media. Canada Soccer has been transparent and cooperative throughout the process,\" the COC said.\n\n\"The COC will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary.\"\n\nThe decisions come after a staff member was detained by French authorities for flying the drone in a bid to spy on New Zealand's tactics.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said it had since learned of a second incident involving New Zealand, who formally lodged a complaint with the IOC integrity unit and demanded answers from Canada.\n\nPriestman said she did not think it would be appropriate to be on the bench for the clash against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match.\"\n\nNew Zealand Football said Thursday they have referred the matter to the disciplinary committee of football's governing body FIFA seeking \"urgent action\".\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" New Zealand Football chief executive Andrew Pragnell said in a statement.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at team's support staff.\n\nNew Zealand and defending Olympic champion Canada meet in their opening match at the Olympic tournament in the early hours of Friday morning AEST.\n\nThe drone incident occurred earlier this week, the New Zealand Olympic Committee (NZOC) said on Wednesday.\n\nABC Sport will be live blogging every day of the Paris Olympics from July 27\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women's football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC {"uri": "8242007723", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:06:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:06:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://japantoday.com/category/paris-2024-olympics/canada-football-staff-sent-home-over-olympic-drone-scandal", "title": "Canada soccer staff sent home over Olympic drone scandal", "body": "An assistant coach and an analyst with the Canadian women's soccer team were on Wednesday sent home from the Olympics for their part in a spying scandal.\n\nThe analyst, 43-year-old Joey Lombardi, was also given a suspended eight-month prison sentence for flying a drone over a New Zealand training session this week in Saint-Etienne.\n\nLombardi pleaded guilty when he appeared in court in Saint-Etienne on Wednesday, the court told AFP.\n\nThe assistant coach was Jasmine Mander, to whom Lombardi reported.\n\nHead coach Bev Priestman also announced she will take no part in the opening game of Canada's gold medal defense, against New Zealand.\n\nThe decisions come after a staff member was detained by French authorities for flying the drone in a bid to spy on New Zealand's tactics.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said it had since learned of a second incident involving New Zealand, who formally lodged a complaint with the IOC integrity unit and demanded answers from Canada.\n\n\"The COC is in contact with the IOC and in contact with FIFA. Canada Soccer has been transparent and cooperative throughout the process,\" the COC said.\n\n\"The COC will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary.\"\n\nPriestman said she did not think it would be appropriate to be on the bench for the clash against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Canada Soccer has been transparent and cooperative throughout the process,\" the COC said. \"The COC will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary.\"\n\nThe decisions come after a staff member was detained by French authorities for flying the drone in a bid to spy on New Zealand's tactics.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said it had since learned of a second incident involving New Zealand, who formally lodged a complaint with the IOC integrity unit and demanded answers from Canada.\n\nPriestman said she did not think it would be appropriate to be on the bench for the clash against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" she said. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match.\"\n\nNew Zealand Football said Thursday they have referred the matter to the disciplinary committee of football's governing body FIFA seeking \"urgent action\".\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" New Zealand Football chief executive Andrew Pragnell said in a statement.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at The drone incident occurred earlier this week, the New Zealand Olympic Committee said Wednesday.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the wider Canadian Women\u00b4s football team, to be detained,\" the NZOC said in a statement.\n\n\"The NZOC has formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and has asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee has apologized to the NZOC and New Zealand Football.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nCoach Beverly Priestman of Canada takes photos on the pitch at Geoffroy-Guichard Stadium ahead of the 2024 Summer Olympics, Tuesday, July 23, 2024, in Saint-Etienne, France. the disciplinary committee of football's governing body FIFA seeking \"urgent action.\"\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" New Zealand Football chief executive Andrew Pragnell said in a statement.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our {"uri": "8242818851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:10:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:10:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:09:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/fifa-opens-proceedings-against-canada-amid-drone-spying-scandal-at-olympics-1654040.html", "title": "FIFA opens proceedings against Canada amid drone spying scandal at Olympics | BreakingNews.ie", "body": "FIFA's disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer and several individuals, including head coach Bev Priestman, amid claims a drone was used to spy on Olympic rivals New Zealand.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, have been sent home in connection with what the Canadian Olympic Committee has said it believes to be two separate instances of a drone being used to record Football Ferns training sessions.\n\nPriestman, once the assistant to former Lionesses boss Phil Neville, has announced she will not take charge of the defending Olympic champions for Thursday's New Zealand clash, their tournament opener, with ex-Everton manager Andy Spence filling in.\n\nA statement read: \"The FIFA disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Ms Beverly Priestman, Mr Joseph Lombardi and Ms Jasmine Mander due to the potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA disciplinary code and article 6.1 of the regulations Olympic football tournaments games of the XXXIII Olympiad Paris 2024 - final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.\"\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their \"unequivocal disapproval\" in a joint statement announcing that their organisation would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\nIt read: \"On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise.\n\n\"As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n\"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.\"\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nPriestman said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had {"uri": "8241927126", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:43:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:43:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:42:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://arstechnica.com/culture/2024/07/new-zealand-deeply-shocked-after-canada-drone-spied-on-its-olympic-practices-twice/", "title": "New Zealand \"deeply shocked\" after Canada drone-spied on its Olympic practices -- twice", "body": "On July 22, the New Zealand women's football (soccer) team was training in Saint-\u00c9tienne, France, for its upcoming Olympics matchup against Canada when team officials noticed a drone hovering near the practice pitch. Suspecting skullduggery, the New Zealand squad called the local police, and gendarmes located and then detained the nearby drone operator. He turned out to be one Joseph Lombardi, an \"unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer\" -- and he was apparently spying on the New Zealand practice and relaying information to a Canadian assistant coach.\n\nOn July 23, the New Zealand Olympic Committee put out a statement saying it was \"deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024.\" It also complained to the official International Olympic Committee integrity unit.\n\nEarly today, July 24, the Canadian side issued its own statement saying that it \"stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed. We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nLater in the day, a follow-up Canadian statement revealed that this was actually the second drone-spying incident; the New Zealand side had also been watched by drone at its July 19 practice.\n\nTeam Canada announced four responses to these incidents:\n\n\"Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately. Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Mr. Lombardi report sent [sic], is being removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and will be sent home immediately. [The Canadian Olympic Committee] has accepted the decision of Head Coach Bev Priestman to remove herself from coaching the match against New Zealand on July 25th. Canada Soccer staff will undergo mandatory ethics training.\"\n\nDrones are now everywhere -- swarming the skies over Ukraine's battlefields, flying from Houthi-controlled Yemen to Tel Aviv, scouting political assassination attempt options. Disney is running an 800-drone light show in Florida. The roofer who recently showed up to look at my shingles brought a drone with him. My kid owns one.\n\nSo, from a technical perspective, stories like this little spying scandal are no surprise at all. But for the Olympics, already awash in high-tech cheating scandals such as years-long state-sponsored doping campaigns, drone spying is just one more depressing example of how humans excel at using our tools to ruin good things in creative new ways.\n\nAnd it's a good reminder that every crazy example in those terrible HR training videos your boss makes you watch every year are included for a reason. So if you see \"drone ethics\" creeping into your compliance program right after sections on \"how to avoid being phished\" and \"don't let anyone else follow you through the door after you swipe your final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.\"\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their \"unequivocal disapproval\" in a joint statement announcing that their organisation would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\nIt read: \"On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise.\n\n\"As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n\"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.\"\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nPriestman said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had been detained by French authorities in St Etienne following a complaint by New Zealand Football on July 22.\n\nFollowing the COC's review of that incident it said it had learned of a \"second drone Canada staffer detained for flying drone over New Zealand training", "body": "PARIS -- A Canada soccer staffer was caught flying a drone over a New Zealand training session earlier this week as the two teams prepared to meet on opening day of the women's soccer competition here at the 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee acknowledged in a statement Wednesday that a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team was detained by French authorities\" following the incident.\n\nThe COC said that the staffer \"is believed to have been using a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team during practice.\"\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee said in an earlier statement that, when they noticed the drone, \"team support members immediately reported the incident to police.\"\n\nFrench authorities are on high alert this week ahead of Friday's Opening Ceremony, an open-air extravaganza on the River Seine. Amid security concerns, they have been strictly enforcing a ban on drones at and around Games venues throughout France. French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal said Tuesday that authorities were intercepting an average of six drones per day.\n\n\"Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept [drones] and arrest their operators,\" Attal said. \"We can't allow anything to slip past us.\"\n\nThey have taken down drones flown by tourists, presumably unaware of the restrictions, Attal said.\n\nWhat they likely didn't anticipate was needing to police the reigning Olympic women's soccer champions ahead of a matchup with an underdog.\n\nCanada won gold in Tokyo. It opens its title defense Thursday in Saint-\u00c9tienne, several hours south of Paris, against New Zealand, the least-fancied team in a four-team group also featuring France and Colombia.\n\nBoth Canada and New Zealand have been training in the region ahead of the opener. After reporting the drone to police, the NZOC also said that it lodged a formal complaint with the International Olympic Committee, and \"asked Canada for a full review.\"\n\nThe IOC has not yet commented, and did not immediately respond to an email seeking comment. It's unclear if Canada might be punished.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said it was \"shocked and disappointed\" after learning of the incident.\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" the COC said in its statement. \"We are reviewing next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer, and FIFA [soccer's global governing body]. {"uri": "8243275821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:03:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:03:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:02:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://dronedj.com/2024/07/25/paris-olympics-spy-drone-scandal/", "title": "Canada kicks out two after drone spying scandal at Paris Olympics", "body": "The Paris Olympics have become embroiled in controversy following a drone spying incident. The Canadian women's soccer team has come under scrutiny after two staff members were dismissed for allegedly using a drone to spy on New Zealand's practice sessions.\n\nThe controversy began on Monday when New Zealand Football lodged a complaint with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) about drones hovering over their closed training sessions.\n\nIn response to the allegations, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) launched an investigation and confirmed that two staff members were involved. Assistant coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi were identified as responsible parties. Both were immediately removed from the Canadian Olympic team and sent home. The COC has also issued a public apology to New Zealand Football and emphasized its commitment to fair play and sportsmanship by making its staff undertake mandatory ethics training.\n\nCanada's head coach, Bev Priestman, took accountability for the incident by voluntarily stepping down from coaching the upcoming match against New Zealand. She expressed deep regret for the actions of her team members and assured the public that such behavior does not reflect the team's values.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for the conduct in our program,\" Priestman said. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nDuring a press briefing, COC chief executive David Shoemaker corroborated that Priestman had \"no involvement, no knowledge\" of the incident. \"We thought about all repercussions for Bev. At the end of the day, the drone footage related to the filming of two New Zealand practices and it remained in the hands of the pilot of the drone and the advantage that, I guess, was intended to be obtained was not attained, at least to the best of our ability to ascertain.\"\n\nIt's worth pointing out that the Paris Olympics incident is not the first time a Canadian soccer team has tried to spy on an international rival's training session with a drone. According to media reports, in 2021, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of its men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field. {"uri": "8241561101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:49:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:49:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:49:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/sports/football/paris-olympics-2024-canada-sends-staff-home-for-spying-on-new-zealand-womens-football-team-2630033", "title": "Paris Olympics 2024: Canada sends staff home for spying on New Zealand women's football team", "body": "New Delhi: The women's football competition of the Paris Olympics 2024 will see defending champions Canada take on New Zealand. However, the pre-game drama has made headlines after a complaint from the New Zealand Olympic Committee during a training session before the games. The NZOC reported to the police that a drone was observed flying over a Ferns training session. The report led to the authorities detaining the operator, identified as a support member of the Canadian team.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee reported that a separate drone incident at a New Zealand training session on July 19 also came to everyone's attention. This has led Canadian coach Bev Prietman to remove herself from observing Thursday's game against New Zealand. COC further stated that Joseph Lombardi, an \"unaccredited analyst\" and Jasmine Mander, a coach who observes Lombardi have now been removed from the team and were being sent home. COC also mentioned that the entire Canadian football staff will undergo compulsory ethics training.\n\nCOC had already issued an apology after confirming that their staff had used a drone to record New Zealand's players during their practice session. Priestman herself reassured that they don't stand by such \"values\" and hence had decided to withdraw as the coach of the team for the game.\n\nHowever, this won't be the first time that Canada has been caught in the offensive for using drones to film their opponents during a training session. final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.\"\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their \"unequivocal disapproval\" in a joint statement announcing that their organisation would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\nIt read: \"On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise.\n\n\"As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n\"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.\"\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nPriestman said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. {"uri": "8242035908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:36:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:36:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:35:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/uk-sports/2024/07/24/fifa-opens-proceedings-against-canada-amid-drone-spying-scandal-at-olympics/", "title": "FIFA opens proceedings against Canada amid drone spying scandal at Olympics", "body": "Assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, have been sent home.\n\nFIFA's disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer and several individuals, including head coach Bev Priestman, amid claims a drone was used to spy on Olympic rivals New Zealand.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, have been sent home in connection with what the Canadian Olympic Committee has said it believes to be two separate instances of a drone being used to record Football Ferns training sessions.\n\nPriestman, once the assistant to former Lionesses boss Phil Neville, has announced she will not take charge of the defending Olympic champions for Thursday's New Zealand clash, their tournament opener, with ex-Everton manager Andy Spence filling in.\n\nA statement read: \"The FIFA disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Ms Beverly Priestman, Mr Joseph Lombardi and Ms Jasmine Mander due to the potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA disciplinary code and article 6.1 of the regulations Olympic football tournaments games of the XXXIII Olympiad Paris 2024 - final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.\"\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their \"unequivocal disapproval\" in a joint statement announcing that their organisation would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\nIt read: \"On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise.\n\n\"As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n\"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.\"\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nPriestman said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had been detained by French authorities in St Etienne following a complaint by New Zealand Football on July 22.\n\nFollowing the COC's review of that incident it said it had learned of a \"second drone and has asked Canada for a full review.\n\n\"Team support members immediately reported the incident to police, leading to the drone operator, who has been identified as a support staff member of the {"uri": "8242829613", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:16:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:16:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:15:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.meathchronicle.ie/2024/07/25/fifa-opens-proceedings-against-canada-amid-drone-spying-scandal-at-olympics/", "title": "FIFA opens proceedings against Canada amid drone spying scandal at Olympics | Meath Chronicle", "body": "FIFA opens proceedings against Canada amid drone spying scandal at Olympics RSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 25 Jul 2024, 10:54 AM Last updated: Thu 25 Jul 2024, 11:12 AM\n\nBy PA Sport Staff\n\nFIFA's disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer and several individuals, including head coach Bev Priestman, amid claims a drone was used to spy on Olympic rivals New Zealand.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer, have been sent home in connection with what the Canadian Olympic Committee has said it believes to be two separate instances of a drone being used to record Football Ferns training sessions.\n\nPriestman, once the assistant to former Lionesses boss Phil Neville, has announced she will not take charge of the defending Olympic champions for Thursday's New Zealand clash, their tournament opener, with ex-Everton manager Andy Spence filling in.\n\nA statement read: \"The FIFA disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Ms Beverly Priestman, Mr Joseph Lombardi and Ms Jasmine Mander due to the potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA disciplinary code and article 6.1 of the regulations Olympic football tournaments games of the XXXIII Olympiad Paris 2024 - final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.\"\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their \"unequivocal disapproval\" in a joint statement announcing that their organisation would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\nIt read: \"On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials.\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise.\n\n\"As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n\"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.\"\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nPriestman said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had been detained by French authorities in St Etienne following a complaint by New Zealand Football on July 22.\n\nFollowing the COC's review of that incident it said it had learned of a \"second drone incident\" on July 19.\n\nRSS Syndicated Content Published: Thu 25 Jul 2024, 10:54 AM Last updated: Thu 25 Jul 2024, 11:12 AM", "source": {"uri": "meathchronicle.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8243119534", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:17:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:17:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:16:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.balls.ie/olympics/canada-new-zealand-olympics-drone-605725", "title": "Canada Coach Steps Aside After New Zealand Olympics Drone Fiasco | Balls.ie", "body": "2020 Olympic champions Canada have begun the defence of their football crown in turmoil, after being caught spying on their opponents New Zealand ahead of their clash in Saint-\u00c9tienne on Thursday.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee reported their opponents to the IOC on Tuesday, alleging that a drone had been flone over their training session. They further alleged that they had identified the culprit as a support staff member of the Canadian women's football team.\n\nThe NZOC and New Zealand Football are committed to upholding the integrity and fairness of the Olympic Games and are deeply shocked and disappointed by this incident, which occurred just three days before the sides are due to face each other in their opening game of Paris 2024.\n\nAs the situation developed, a second incident saw a non-accredited member of the Canadian staff detained by police for improper use of a drone.\n\nThe farcical incidents have now seen head coach Bev Priestman voluntarily step aside ahead of Thursday's game, with two members of staff sent home permanently.\n\nREAD HERE: Morocco Fans Storm Pitch After Controversial End To Argentina Olympics Game\n\nREAD HERE: Irish Olympic Opening Ceremony Outfits Feature Wonderful Nod To Home County Of Athletes\n\nIn a statement ahead of the opener in Saint-\u00c9tienne, the Canadian Olympic Committee confirmed not only the resignations but that a third drone incident had occurred at last Friday's New Zealand training session.\n\nAssistant coach Jasmine Mander and Joseph Lombardi, an unaccredited analyst under Mander's remit, have been sent home from the Olympics.\n\nAdditionally, the team's English head coach Bev Priestman has voluntarily removed herself from preparations for the clash with New Zealand.\n\nIn a statement, Priestman apologised on behalf of the Canadian group and said that her decision was made in \"the spirit of accountability.\"\n\nOn behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for.\n\nI am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\nIn the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\n\nPriestman was the head coach when Canada won gold in Tokyo but there is a very disappointing feeling around the team after this week's revelations.\n\nThursday's game is set to take place in Saint-\u00c9tienne - the same venue which saw a chaotic opening to the games with the men's tournament getting underway on Wednesday.\n\nThe very first event of the Olympics saw Moroccan fans halt the game in the 16th minute of second half injury time, as they threw projectiles and invaded the pitch in response to a contentious late Argentinean equaliser. When the game finally resumed hours later, the Argentina goal was finally chalked off for offside, with Morocco winning 2-1.\n\nThe Olympic football has already served up its fair share of controversy
