suspended prison sentence over drone incident, prosecutor says", "body": "A Canada women's soccer team staff member has been given an eight-month suspended prison sentence after flying a drone to film the closed-door training session of the New Zealand women's soccer team on Monday, the Saint-Etienne prosecutor's office said in a statement.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) formally apologized Wednesday after the New Zealand Olympic Committee lodged a complaint that its women's soccer team practice was recorded by a drone in Saint-\u00c9tienne, a city 400 kilometers (250 miles) south of the French capital, where the match will be played.\n\nDefending Olympic champion Canada is set to play New Zealand on Thursday in a group-stage game.\n\nThe COC later announced that two members of the Canadian Olympic Team would be sent home immediately: Joseph Lombardi, who the COC says is an \"unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer,\" and assistant coach Jasmine Mander, who Lombardi sent his report to.\n\nAdditionally, the COC said it will accept head coach Bev Priestman's offer to \"remove herself from coaching the match against New Zealand.\"\n\nAccording to the Saint-Etienne prosecutor's office, on Monday, July 22, police on the scene \"were informed by the supervisor of the Olympic training sites located in Saint-Etienne of the presence of a drone hovering in the air above the stadium,\" after being warned by the New Zealand soccer team manager, who the prosecutor said suspended training as a result.\n\n\"The police then proceeded to detain the drone pilot who turned out to be a Canadian national, aged 43, who had actually filmed the closed-door training session of the New Zealand women's team using a drone camera,\" the statement said without naming the individual in question.\n\nIt added that after being placed in custody, the individual claimed that \"he was a sports coach for teams of young soccer players in Canada and was in France as part of other functions as an independent sports analyst, working for the Canadian football federation.\"\n\nThe prosecutor's office said that the drone was later seized along with other electronic devices in his hotel room, adding that on Saturday, July 20, there had been another drone recording of New Zealand's team practice.\n\nThe statement said that, in the presence of his lawyer, after admitting to the facts, \"he accepted his sentence of an 8-month suspended prison sentence.\" It added that the Canadian team's assistant coach - who the statement did not name - was also Police in St. Etienne apprehended the drone operator, who was identified as someone who works for Team Canada, although their exact identity is still unknown. New Zealand is Canada's first Olympic opponent, with their match scheduled for Thursday.\n\nA statement from the NZOC noted that Canada had already apologized for the incident. The Canadian Olympic Committee confirmed that it did actually happen with a statement of its own that came out later Tuesday. The COC described the person as a \"non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team\" and then reiterated its apology.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair-play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement reads. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nIt's probably for the best that Canada is distancing itself as far as possible from this little scandal. After all, when Spygate, where New England Patriots coaches and staffers were caught filming opposing team practices, broke in 2007, the Patriots denied any wrongdoing initially and went on to have the greatest regular season in NFL history but fell short in the Super Bowl. final competition, following incidents involving a non-accredited member of the Canadian delegation at the Women's Olympic football tournament, who is believed to have used a drone to record the New Zealand women's football team.\n\n\"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the disciplinary committee in the next days.\"\n\nCanada Soccer president Peter Augruso and CEO/general secretary Kevin Blue also expressed their \"unequivocal disapproval\" in a joint statement announcing that their organisation would be conducting its own independent investigation.\n\nIt read: \"On behalf of our federation, we offer our sincere apologies to the impacted players, coaches, and officials.\n\nBev Priestman is a former England assistant coach (Mike Egerton/PA)\n\n\"Canada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise.\n\n\"As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n\"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.\"\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nCanada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise Canada Soccer statement\n\nPriestman said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had {"uri": "8240230486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-23", "time": "23:01:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-23T23:01:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-23T23:00:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/sports/national-sports/2024/07/23/member-of-canada-soccer-support-team-detained-in-france-for-alleged-drone-use/", "title": "Member of Canada Soccer support team detained in France for alleged drone use - Medicine Hat News", "body": "The Soccer Canada logo is displayed on the sideline at Tim Hortons Field in Hamilton, Tuesday, May 9, 2023. The Canadian Olympic Committee says a \"non-accredited\" member of Canada Soccer's support team has been detained by French authorities in Saint-\u00c3\u2030tienne for allegedly using a drone to record New Zealand's women's soccer team during practice. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Nick IwanyshynPARIS - The Canadian Olympic Committee says a \"non-accredited\" member of Canada Soccer's support team has been detained by French authorities in Saint-\u00c3\u2030tienne for allegedly using a drone to record New Zealand's women's soccer team during practice. The organization says New Zealand Football registered a complaint on Monday. The COC said in a statement released Tuesday it is \"shocked and disappointed\" over the allegation and apologized to the New Zealand Olympic Committee and New Zealand Football. It said it is reviewing next steps with the International Olympic Committee, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer and FIFA. The COC said it will provide an update Wednesday. Canada, the defending Olympic women's soccer champion, is scheduled to open its tournament against New Zealand on Friday in Saint-\u00c3\u2030tienne. {"uri": "8241938191", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:53:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:53:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:52:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/olympics-2024/523075/olympics-2024-swift-fall-out-over-spygate-controversy", "title": "Olympics 2024: Swift fall-out over spygate controversy", "body": "New Zealand has found itself at the centre of one of the major international storylines of the Paris Olympic Games days out from the opening, as the \"spy-gate\" controversy deepened.\n\nThe scandal kicked off when it was revealed that a rogue support staffer with Canada's women's football team had flown a drone over the Football Ferns training as part of a scouting mission.\n\nFollowing internal investigations, the Canadian Olympic Committee confirmed the staffer had also filmed a second, earlier Ferns training session.\n\nThe fall-out has been swift. Canada head coach Bev Priestman has stood herself down from overseeing Friday's opening match against New Zealand, while Joseph Lombardi, an \"unaccredited analyst,\" and assistant coach Jasmine Mander have been sent home amid multiple investigations.\n\nMuch of the drama played out in a series of sternly-worded statements.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said it was \"shocked and disappointed\" with the conduct of the two members of its football team and apologised to the New Zealand team.\n\nThe COC added that the staff of Canada Soccer would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nPriestman later followed up with an apology of her own.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" she said.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on [Friday]. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nFifa then got in on the act, posting a statement on its website confirming its disciplinary committee has \"opened proceedings\" against Canada Soccer, Priestman, Lombardi and Mander to look into potential breaches of the world governing body's rules.\n\nThe incident appears to fall within a jurisdictional matrix. The New Zealand Olympic team have also logged a complaint with the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) integrity unit, while French authorities are investigating how the security breach occurred.\n\nLombardi was detained by local police on Monday night following a complaint from New Zealand Football.\n\nThe only officials to front were New Zealand chef de mission Nigel Avery and the NZOC's public affairs director Ashley Abbott earlier in the day.\n\n\"This is an incident that goes against everything we stand for, with our values, our commitment to an even and fair playing field,\" Avery told a media conference.\n\nAvery said the NZOC's focus in on supporting the Fern's from both a \"wellbeing and performance standpoint\" as the team prepares for Friday morning's opener.\n\n\"They haven't had a smooth build-up and this is something they have to overcome.\n\n\"To say it's an unwanted distraction is an understatement.\"\n\nThe Ferns team departed for France in a state of turmoil, after coach Jitka Klimkova stepped aside from the Paris campaign following a failed \"restorative process\" to rebuild relationships in the team. The move came after Klimkova was in June cleared by an employment investigation - although the details of what kicked off the investigation remain a mystery.\n\nLate last night, in the midst of the extraordinary twists and turns of the spying saga came a further blow.\n\nFootball Ferns captain Ali Riley, who was seeking to join a select group of women to compete at a fifth Olympic Games, was {"uri": "8241495970", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:08:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:08:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:07:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://worldsoccertalk.com/news/canada-coach-to-miss-olympics-opener-amid-spying-controversy/", "title": "Canada coach to miss Olympics opener amid spying controversy", "body": "Canada women's head coach Beverly Priestman will not be on the sidelines for her team's opening 2024 Olympics match. The manager, however, is not sick or dealing with some sort of injury. Instead, Canada has come under fire for allegedly spying on their first opponents of the upcoming tournament.\n\nAn uncredited member of the Canadian women's national team allegedly flew drones over New Zealand's practice on two separate occasions. Both incidents occurred within the last week. The two teams face off on Thursday, July 25. It is the opening match of Group A in the competition. Hosts France and Colombia are also in the group as well.\n\nAccording to reports, the drone was first spotted by New Zealand team members on July 19. Some assumed the incident was perhaps just an accident. Nevertheless, the drone was once again spotted over New Zealand's training facility three days later. Olympic officials were immediately made aware of the situation.\n\nFrench authorities then detained the drone operator, believed to be Joseph Lombardi. Lombardi is an uncredited analyst with Canada Soccer. Canada has since removed him from the team. Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to Priestman, is also returning home. Lombardi supposedly reports directly to Mander regularly.\n\nDue to the series of incidents, Priestman has officially announced that she has \"voluntarily withdrawn\" from the match against New Zealand. \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" stated Priestman.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interest of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee also announced that they are \"deeply shocked and disappointed\" by the incident. Team officials also revealed that Canada has personally apologized for the events and is undergoing an internal investigation on the matter.\n\nThe Canucks are the reigning Olympic champions after their triumph at the tournament in 2021. Canada topped powerhouse Sweden in the final in Japan on penalty kicks. New Zealand, on the other hand, finished bottom of Group G during the previous games, a group that also featured the USWNT. Canada currently ranks eighth in the world by FIFA, 20 spots above New Zealand.\n\nThe upcoming matchup between the two teams will be the opening women's soccer match of the 2024 Summer Olympics. After facing New Zealand, Canada will play hosts France on July 28. Priestman will be back on the sidelines for the game. The Canucks will then finish off Group A with a matchup against 22nd-ranked Colombia on July 31.", "source": {"uri": "worldsoccertalk.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "World Soccer Talk"}, team amid drone spying scandal  | TSN", "body": "Bev Priestman will not coach the Canadian women's soccer team for the remainder of the Paris Olympics after the Canadian Olympic Committee announced Thursday that they were sending her home due to a suspension by Canada Soccer amid a drone spying scandal.\n\nAssistant coach Andy Spence, who filled in for Canada's opening 2-1 win over New Zealand on Thursday, will coach Canada for the remainder of the tournament as the program looks to defend their gold medal from three years ago in Tokyo.\n\n\"Over the past 24 hours, additional information has come to our attention regarding previous drone use against opponents, predating the Paris 2024 Olympic Games,\" Canada Soccer CEO & General Secretary Kevin Blue said in a statement. \"In light of these new revelations, Canada Soccer has made the decision to suspend Women's National Team Head Coach, Bev Priestman for the remainder of the Paris 2024 Olympic Games, and until the completion of our recently announced independent external review.\"\n\nTSN Senior Correspondent Rick Westhead reported Thursday evening that, according to sources, coaching staff and contractors working with Canada's men's and women's national soccer teams have been engaged for years in efforts to film the closed-door training sessions of their opponents, including during the women's gold-medal winning Olympic tournament in 2021.\n\nAhead of their opening match, two members of Canada Soccer's staff were dismissed on Wednesday for allegedly flying drones over New Zealand practices while Priestman voluntarily removed herself from the touchline for Thursday's match.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players {"uri": "8243677571", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:49:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:49:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:48:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/25/g-s1-13417/canada-new-zealand-spy-drone-womens-soccer-paris-olympics", "title": "Canada beats New Zealand in women's soccer after Olympic spy drone scandal", "body": "PARIS -- Canada, the defending women's Olympic soccer champion, defeated New Zealand 2-1 on Thursday.\n\nIt would've been a routine group match were it not for an espionage scandal hanging over the tournament.\n\nEarlier in the week, staff from Canada's team, ranked No. 8 in the world, were accused of using drones to spy on training sessions held by New Zealand, the No. 28-ranked team.\n\nThe fallout has been swift.\n\nOn the eve of the match between the two teams, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) said it fired two employees -- one of which was dealt an eight-month prison sentence for flying an illegal drone -- and its head coach Bev Priestman said she would voluntarily sit out Thursday's game against New Zealand.\n\nThe COC identified the two staffers removed as Joseph Lombardi, an analyst with the team, and Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach. The COC reportedly confirmed that it was Lombardi who flew the drone over the New Zealand trainings.\n\nIn a statement on Wednesday, Priestman apologized to New Zealand's players and staff, as well as Team Canada.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said.\n\nLate Monday morning, the supervisor of the Olympic training sites in Saint-Etienne alerted police to the presence of a drone hovering above Auguste Dury stadium, where the New Zealand team had been practicing, according to a statement from the Saint-Etienne prosecutor's office.\n\nWithout naming Lombardi, the prosecutor's office said that the drone's pilot, a 43-year-old Canadian, was taken into custody and questioned.\n\nOn two separate occasions, he \"had effectively filmed the closed-door training of the New Zealand women's team, with the help of a drone,\" the statement read.\n\nThe footage taken on July 22 show the New Zealand players applying instructions given to them by their trainer, as well as images taken on July 20 -- a previously unknown instance that he admitted during questioning -- when they were training in the Michon stadium in Saint-Etienne.\n\nHe told officers during that the videos \"had helped him learn the tactics of the opposing team,\" according to the statement.\n\nThe prosecutor's office also questioned the assistant trainer from the Canadian team, whom the drone pilot had told about his visit to the New Zealand team's training site. She had no knowledge of the acts and was exonerated, the office said.\n\nThe man was charged with maintaining an unmanned aircraft over a prohibited area, an offense that carries a maximum prison sentence of one year and a fine of 45,000 euros ($49,000).\n\nAccompanied by a lawyer, the prosecutor's statement read, the man accepted a sentence of 8 months in prison, as well as the confiscation of his drone and other electronic equipment seized from his hotel room.\n\nMeanwhile, Canada Soccer will conduct an independent external review of the incident and the sport's international governing body FIFA has launched disciplinary proceedings.\n\nThe Kiwis used the drama as motivation during Thursday's game against Canada, scoring the opening goal.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": It was later approved by a judge.\n\nLombardi, 43, was listed ahead of the Games as one of six team coaches and is from Brampton. He has been involved with the women's national team since 2013, according to his Canada Soccer profile, and has also assisted the men's team since 2018.\n\nLombardi is the head coach of the women's \"A\" team at the Ontario National Development Centre.\n\nJasmine Mander, an assistant coach , has also been removed from the Olympic team and sent home. It was just such a great feeling. So I'm really looking forward to hopefully feel that again.\"\n\nThe Olympics begin Friday, but it's been an embarrassing debut for the Canada's women's soccer team who are now embroiled in a major scandal. The team is being accused of using drones to spy on the New Zealand soccer team during their practice.\n\nAn analyst and an assistant coach with Canada Soccer were removed from the Canadian Olympic Team and \"sent home immediately\" from the prelude to this year's Paris games, according to the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC).\n\n\"Everyone's so surprised of what's going on right now,\" said Fitzgerald's friend Carina Sharara.\n\n\"So it's giving everyone stress and confusion. I mean, this is the biggest story in the Olympics now.\"\n\nSecurity for the games has ramped up, including a ban on drones. France's prime minister told French media that security is intercepting an average of six drones per day.\n\n\"It's not very on brand for the Canadian women's soccer team to, to be using a drone to spy on in a competing team,\" said technology analyst Carmi Levy.\n\n\"Considering that France had already announced restrictions on drone flights in, and around Olympic venues, in the lead up to the The two sides face each other on Thursday in their first match at the Olympic Games which will now have extra spice to it.\n\nPriestman, a Brit who previously worked as Phil Neville's assistant with the Lionesses, will not be on the touchline in Saint-Etienne, having decided to hand the reins to assistant Andy Spence in a self-issued punishment. There's a ban on flying drones. Systems are in place to allow us to very quickly intercept [drones] and arrest their operators.\"\n\nCanada won gold in Tokyo after claiming back-to-back bronze medals at the 2012 and 2016 Olympic Games. {"uri": "2024-07-433274103", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:20:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:20:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:20:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1147002/members-of-canadas-olympic-team-expe", "title": "Two members of Canada's Olympic team expelled for drone espionage", "body": "The Canadian women's football team has been embroiled in controversy after it was discovered that last week they used drones to spy on their opponents. Two members of the team's coaching staff were expelled, and the head coach decided to step aside for the opening match.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) reported this Wednesday that an unaccredited member of Canada's support staff was detained by French authorities for flying a drone over New Zealand's training facilities. The New Zealand committee had previously filed a complaint with the police, which led to the clarification of the facts.\n\nThe convicted individual is named Joseph Lombardi, a technical analyst who is part of the Canadian setup but does not have official accreditation for the Paris Olympic Games. Lombardi admitted to using the drone to capture the opposing coach's instructions. \"I acknowledge that my actions were a serious breach of ethics. I deeply regret compromising the integrity of the competition and apologise to everyone affected,\" he stated in his declaration.\n\nThe prosecutor of Saint Etienne handling the case, David Charmatz, sentenced the accused to eight months in prison, although without incarceration. Charmatz explained that examination of the drone showed that, in addition to recording the New Zealand team on Monday, it had also done so two days earlier at another stadium in the area. The sentence also includes the confiscation of the drone.\n\nIn response to the incident, the COC decided yesterday to expel Lombardi from the Canadian Olympic team and send him back to Canada immediately. The same measures have been taken with assistant coach Jasmine Mander, who received the espionage report. Although Mander denied any involvement in the matter and was cleared of complicity, the COC processed her disassociation to maintain trust in the team, the integrity of the sport, and its ethical standards.\n\nIn response to the scandal, head coach Bev Priestman, who led the team to gold in Tokyo 2020, decided to voluntarily step away from the bench for the first match against New Zealand taking place this afternoon. \"Although I did not personally direct the actions of those involved, as head coach, I am responsible for the team's behaviour. I apologise to the players and staff of New Zealand. This situation does not reflect the values we uphold,\" Priestman declared, assuming responsibility.\n\nFor their part, the COC emphasised that despite the incident, the team has been transparent and cooperative during the investigations. Additionally, the staff will undergo mandatory training in sports ethics. \"Transparency and cooperation have been key throughout this process. We will continue to review the situation and take further action if necessary,\" said a spokesperson for the organisation.\n\nCarla Qualtrough, Canadian Minister of Sport and Physical Activity, also commented on this uncomfortable episode. \"Fair play is the highest principle in sport. I fully support the sanctions and Coach Priestman's decision to step aside for the first match. These decisions are crucial to maintaining the integrity of the game and respecting the Olympic spirit,\" Qualtrough wrote on social media.\n\nThe scandal has also affected the atmosphere within the Canadian team just before their crucial match against New Zealand. Defender Vanessa Gilles commented on the situation, saying, \"Obviously, it's not ideal to enter such an important tournament under these circumstances. However, we are professionals and are committed to doing our best. New Zealand claims the staffer recorded their practice with a drone.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee said in a statement that it formally lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit and asked Canada for a full review.\n\nThe COC also said it is reviewing next steps with the IOC, Paris 2024, Canada Soccer and FIFA, and will provide a further update Wednesday.\n\nSecurity for the Olympic Games has ramped up in recent weeks. France's Prime Minister Gabriel Attal told the French newspaper Le Monde Monday that security is intercepting an average of six drones per day.\n\nWhile tourists wanting to take pictures are believed to be flying most of the devices, Attal says it's important to remind people there's a ban on using drones.\n\n\"We can't allow anything to slip past us,\" he said.\n\nLe Monde also reported that other anti-aircraft defences are in place, including a 150-kilometre radius around Paris, which will be completely closed off Friday during the opening ceremony, and 18,000 French troops have been deployed to secure this summer's Olympic Games.\n\nCanada and New Zealand kick off the Olympic competition Thursday at 11 a.m. EDT. Two Canadian Women's Soccer Coaches Sent Home After Illegal Drone Use", "body": "Two Canadian Olympic women's assistant soccer coaches have been dismissed by the team after two incidents of reportedly using drones to spy on New Zealand's team ahead of their first match against each other.\n\nCanadian team soccer analyst Joseph Lombardi and assistant coach Jasmine Mander were sent home from the Paris Olympics after New Zealand saw Lombardi using a drone during one of their private soccer practices, presumably to get an illegal and unfair advantage on the team's game plan. New Zealand team officials immediately contacted the International Olympic Committee, which alerted French law enforcement and took the two Canadian assistant soccer coaches into custody while also revealing that there was a separate drone spying incident as well.\n\nAlthough it's unclear if the Canadian teams knew what the two coaches were doing (plausible deniability, anyone?) Canadian head coach Bev Priestman voluntarily stepped down from coaching the team's first Olympic match against New Zealand.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said via a statement. \"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe IOC is continuing its investigation, but already some are wondering if the Canadian women - who won their first women's soccer Olympic gold medal during the last Summer Olympics, were also illegally spying on their opponents.\n\nThe incident is being likened to 2007's NFL Spygate scandal in which the New England Patriots were caught videotaping the rival New York Jets defensive coaches' signals from the opposing sideline during a game between the two teams. The NFL and Commissioner Roger Goodell would end up fining Patriots head coach Bill Belichick the maximum allowed penalty of $500,000, the team $250,000 and a forfeit of their 2008 NFL Draft first-round pick for having knowledge of the spying incident.\n\nMeanwhile, as the Olympic Committee's investigation continues, we'll hopefully soon find out to what extent Canada was illegally using drones to cheat.\n\nWe'll also see if the tape and subsequent game plan was passed to Team Canada and if it has an advantage when it plays New Zealand in the first round of the Olympics.", "source": Assistant coach Andy Spence will lead the team. Canada's opening match against New Zealand is scheduled for Thursday in Saint-Etienne.\n\nIn response to the complaint, Canada Soccer sent assistant coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi home. Priestman issued an apology to New Zealand, emphasizing that the incident did not reflect the team's values. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise.\n\n\"As an immediate next step, Canada Soccer will proceed with an independent external review. This review will address the circumstances of the current matter, and more broadly, will seek to understand the historical culture of competitive ethics within all of our programs.\n\n\"The outcome of this review will be shared publicly and corrective actions, if necessary, will be taken. We will maintain prompt and transparent communication on this matter.\"\n\nA statement from the COC said Mander and Lombardi would be sent home immediately and Canada Soccer staff would undergo \"mandatory ethics training\".\n\nCanada Soccer has always sought to prioritise integrity and fair competition, and we understand that competing with honesty is a baseline expectation for all Canadians. We failed to meet those expectations in this case, and for that, we apologise\n\nPriestman said: \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\n\n\"In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe COC said it was told a non-accredited member of the Canada Soccer support team had {"uri": "8242031823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:31:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:31:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:30:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/sports/olympics-and-paralympics/canada-got-caught-flying-a-drone-over-a-soccer-practice-so-why-is-bev-priestman/article_cdcce57c-49b9-11ef-a73a-7f7682a5f675.html", "title": "Bruce Arthur: Canada got caught flying a drone over a soccer practice. So why is Bev Priestman still the coach?", "body": "PARIS -- Bev Priestman cannot coach Canada at these Olympics, at the least. She is the coach of the defending gold-medal women's soccer team, but she cannot coach here, not after the drone scandal that rocked Canada before the team played its first match in France. Not now.\n\nAnd yet, it appears she will. There is also a question of whether Priestman should coach Canada again at all, of course, but that's a question that can't be answered until after the Olympics.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nThe scandal broke late Tuesday night: A Canada team staffer named Joey Lombardi was arrested earlier this week for flying a drone over a New Zealand practice, in advance of the Canada-New Zealand opening match Thursday in Saint-\u00c9tienne.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThere is a drone ban around Paris; it is well-publicized at a Games where security is being taken very seriously. French president Emmanuel Macron said the other day six drones per day are being intercepted around Olympic sites; the communications director of the Brazilian team was nabbed for using a drone near the Olympic Village.\n\nIt turns out Lombardi took drone footage of two New Zealand practices. According to a prosecutor's statement obtained by the CBC, New Zealand spotted the drone and stopped practice, Lombardi was located and arrested, and sung like a canary. He said he was spying to learn about tactics; assistant coach Jasmine Mander, to whom Lombardi reports, claimed to know nothing about his actions to police. Lombardi, meanwhile, pled to an eight-month suspended sentence that mostly seems to mean he leaves France. Mander has served with the national team since Tokyo 2021; Lombardi worked with the women's team at the 2023 Women's World Cup, and has served on staff at six FIFA under-20 or under-17 tournaments. Neither is new to Canada Soccer.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee's version of consequences, though, is where this stops short. Lombardi and Mander were kicked off the team and hustled onto the next plane home; Canada Soccer staff were ordered to undergo ethics training; and the COC accepted Priestman's offer to sit out coaching the New Zealand game, with assistant Andy Spence in her place.\n\nWhen asked why he believed Priestman's denial of involvement, Canadian Olympic Committee CEO David Shoemaker more or less said they didn't have evidence the obtained footage was ever used, that he believed Priestman's denial, and that it was a fact that she was not involved. He also said, \"winning the right way is the only way for us.\"\n\nIs it? The COC, which in fairness is largely a marketing and logistics and lobbying operation, doesn't seem to have wondered how Mander could have acted without Priestman's authorization and approval. In an interview with The Canadian Press in Saint-\u00c9tienne, she said, \"By no means did I direct the individuals,\" but that stretches credulity to the breaking point. You can plausibly accept that this is relatively common practice in soccer, even beyond the drone accusations levelled at Canada's men's team before a match with Honduras in 2021. It's possible and even probable that Canada isn't alone in the soccer spy game.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut it's very hard to imagine a team staffer -- an assistant to an assistant coach -- going out to a New Zealand practice and launching a drone to spy on the team without approval, on the staff of a detail-oriented head coach who has a budget so limited she nearly left the program late last year and who searches for every advantage. Where was that drone information going to end up? Who is to say Lombardi didn't talk about what he saw with the team? And for that matter, why did Lombardi bring a drone to Paris in the first place? Whose drone was it?\n\nFIFA announced it was opening disciplinary proceedings against Priestman, Mander and Lombardi; Canada Soccer said it would launch an independent investigation.\n\nLook, lately Canada has been good for at least one very bad decision per non-Beijing 2022 Games. In Pyeongchang, a Canadian ski cross racer, his wife, and a coach drunkenly stole a bright red Humvee after a night out and drove it back to the Olympic Village, wearing their bright red Canada jackets. But that was easy: They were sent home. In Tokyo three years ago, there was a late outbreak of forbidden co-country athlete partying, hotel room trashing and mascot theft, which was apparently started by Canadians. Again, that's easy: You send them home.\n\nHere, relieving Bev Priestman of her duties for the defending gold medallists would require the confidence that she is truly in charge of her staff, which shouldn't be much of a leap, but it's one the Canadian Olympic Committee is unwilling to make. Canada got caught cheating at the Olympics, and decided the responsibility was as narrow as it can plausibly be. They should hope it doesn't become some kind of national shame.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Star"}, "authors": [{"uri": "bruce_arthur@thestar.com", "name": {"uri": "8242707618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "09:02:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T09:02:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T09:01:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/olympics/2024/07/25/lit-a-fire-in-our-bellies-new-zealanders-motivated-after-canada-drone-scandal", "title": "\"Lit a fire in our bellies,\" New Zealanders motivated after Canada drone scandal", "body": "SAINT-ETIENNE, France - The motivation to upset the reigning Olympic women's soccer champions was already high for New Zealand forward Indiah-Page Riley and her teammates.\n\nA Canada Soccer drone scandal on the eve of the tournament opener has only heightened that desire.\n\n\"I think this kind of lit a fire in our bellies,\" Riley said.\n\nThe lead-up to Thursday's game between eighth-ranked Canada and 28th-ranked New Zealand at the Paris Olympics has been dominated by off-field developments.\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee complained to the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit after it said drones were flown over a pair of pre-tournament practice sessions.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Canadian Olympic Committee said Canadian assistant coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi were \"sent home immediately\" and that it had accepted the decision of head coach Bev Priestman to remove herself from coaching the opening match.\n\nFIFA, the sport's governing body, said its disciplinary committee has opened proceedings against all three individuals and Canada Soccer. The domestic federation is also undergoing an external review, and the COC said it may take further action if necessary.\n\n\"Whether it's enough or not, I think that the integrity of the result and the game is undermined by this,\" said New Zealand interim head coach Michael Mayne. \"In my opinion, if you're replacing the coach, that's one thing. But does that change the game plan going in?\"\n\n\"They ultimately have had a chance to look at our footage.\"\n\nPriestman said she was \"highly disappointed\" to learn about the use of drones and added that \"by no means did I direct the individuals.\"\n\nShe volunteered to stay off the sideline for the match because she's \"ultimately accountable for this team.\"\n\nIn the COC statement, Priestman apologized on behalf of the Canadian program to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on her squad. She repeated the apology when she spoke to the media after a team training session Wednesday.\n\n\"This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" she said.\n\nAssistant coach Andy Spence will be in charge on the Canadian sidelines in the Group A opener at Geoffrey-Guichard Stadium.\n\n\"Will there be a little extra spice in this (match)? Maybe,\" said Mayne. \"But again, we're playing a game of football here. It's the preparation you do for certain moments. Will it change much of what we're going to do? Probably not. The reality is, again, since learning this, we don't have any time.\n\n\"We found out 48 hours before the game that we're in this position. We're still looking forward to the challenge, however it looks.\"\n\nRiley said her teammates spotted a drone \"that was pretty high up\" at a training session on Monday. One player first thought it was a bird, she said, but the sound of the device made it clear.\n\n\"We'd heard you weren't allowed to use drones, and it's a no-fly zone,\" she said. \"So it was a bit of a shock.\"\n\nMayne noted that drone footage from a training session can give viewers the \"ultimate tactical view.\"\n\n\"You're above everybody, so you can literally see all the patterns and things we're working on,\" he said. \"If we're working on specifics for this game, if you have access to that, then it's pretty telling.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, {"uri": "8241845677", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:30:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:30:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:29:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/football/top-stories/eight-month-suspended-prison-for-canada-football-staff-over-paris-olympics-drone-scandal/articleshow/111996678.cms", "title": "Eight-month suspended prison for Canada football staff over Paris Olympics drone scandal | Football News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: Ahead of the Pais Olympics 2024, two members of the Canadian women's football team's coaching staff were implicated in a controversy involving espionage tactics against the New Zealand team.\n\nJoey Lombardi, a 43-year-old analyst for the Canadian team, received a suspended eight-month prison sentence after admitting to operating a drone to observe a New Zealand training session in Saint-Etienne.This admission came during a court appearance in Saint-Etienne on Wednesday, as confirmed by the court to AFP.\n\nThe assistant coach involved in the incident was identified as Jasmine Mander, who was in a reporting line to Lombardi. Following these events, Bev Priestman, the head coach of the Canadian team, announced her decision to abstain from participating in the team's opening match of their Olympics gold medal defence against New Zealand.\n\nThis series of events unfolded after French authorities detained a staff member for piloting the drone over New Zealand's training, an act aimed at gathering intelligence on their tactical preparations.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) has been informed of a second similar incident involving New Zealand, prompting an official complaint from the latter to the IOC integrity unit, seeking clarification and action from Canada.\n\nIn response, the COC has engaged with both the IOC and FIFA. \"The COC is in contact with the IOC and in contact with FIFA. Canada Soccer has been transparent and cooperative throughout the process. The COC will continue to review this matter and may take further action if necessary,\" the COC said.\n\nBev Priestman expressed her stance on the matter, stating her belief that her presence on the bench for the upcoming match against New Zealand would be inappropriate.\n\nShe extended an apology to the New Zealand Football team and staff, as well as to the players of Team Canada, admitting, \"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologise to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for. I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our programme. Accordingly, to emphasise our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday.\"\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. {"uri": "8241869627", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:52:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:52:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:51:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.sportsnet.ca/article/canadian-olympic-womens-soccer-drone-scandal-an-utter-embarrassment/", "title": "Canadian Olympic women's soccer drone scandal an utter embarrassment", "body": "Our Commonwealth friends in New Zealand were, justifiably, having a field day with the Canadian drone scandal on Wednesday.\n\nThanks to a team analysts being caught for using drones, not once but twice, at New Zealand Olympic women's soccer team practices, this Canadian version of spygate managed to far overshadow the traditional happy news of the country unveiling its flag-bearers for Friday's opening ceremony in Paris.\n\nThat's a shame for sprinter Andre De Grasse and weightlifter Maude Charron, two excellent choices by the Canadian Olympic Committee who have nothing to do with this debacle.\n\nWhy 43-year-old Canadian analyst Joseph Lombardi, who has been involved with Canada Soccer for more than a decade, or anyone associated with the reigning Olympic champs felt the need to spy on a New Zealand squad ranked far below Canada in the FIFA rankings is a wonderful question.\n\nBecause of this, Canada has been humiliated on the international sporting stage heading into the women's soccer team's now much-anticipated opener Thursday against New Zealand.\n\n\"Hardly likely that the Football Ferns are going to threaten the Canadians on form,\" former New Zealand men's international soccer player David Chote said on the Sports Fix podcast in his country on Newstalk ZB. \"It is a massive surprise to see them taking to the skies with drones to try to work out what the Football Ferns might be up to. ... Cheap shot, really.\"\n\nLater, Chote said: \"I think the Canadians are embarrassed and the Football Ferns have the moral high ground.\"\n\nThe COC announced Lombardi and the assistant coach he reports to are being sent home, while head coach Bev Priestman was removing herself from Thursday's match.\n\nBut, frankly, that doesn't seem like enough. FIFA has opened an investigation and further sanctions could be forthcoming.\n\nIt's hard to fathom why Priestman, whether she had any knowledge of this or not, should coach another game at this Olympics. She's the head coach, so essentially the CEO, of the program.\n\nDavid Shoemaker, the CEO of the COC, was asked at least three times during a video news conference on Wednesday why he didn't suspend Priestman.\n\n\"I was persuaded by the fact that Bev Priestman had no involvement, no knowledge of the incident,\" Shoemaker said of a coach who guided Canada to Olympic gold in her first major tournament with the squad after getting the job in 2020.\n\n\"Those who had direct involvement were removed from Team Canada.\"\n\nPerhaps noticing the mood of the Zoom room at the end of the press conference, Shoemaker, unprompted, encouraged FIFA and Canada Soccer (which announced it is conducting an independent review) to \"do what they are setting out to do.\"\n\nWhile they do that, New Zealand can have a little chuckle. And, by the way, Shoemaker said New Zealand also has asked the powers that the Canadians not be awarded points in the standings if they win the game.\n\n\"If you're for the Football Ferns, you take it as a badge of pride,\" New Zealand sports commentator Elliott Smith said on Sports Fix.\n\n\"...I don't know why exactly Canada would bother.\"\n\nNo matter what you think of Ben Johnson and the drug-tainted field at the 1988 Olympics, he was seemingly trying to gain an edge on some of the world's best by using performance-enhancing drugs.\n\nThe New Zealand team, conversely, is not an international power. It has never made it out of the group stage at a World Cup and has done so at the Olympics just once. What's more, New Zealand made an abrupt coaching change just last month.\n\nCanada, meanwhile, has won women's soccer medals at the past three Olympics before crashing out early at last year's World Cup.\n\nAs for Lombardi being listed originally as an unaccredited analyst, that is simply administrative talk that means nothing. Shoemaker said sports associations are given out only so many accreditations and it simply becomes a numbers game.\n\nLombardi, who was given an eight-month suspended sentence by French authorities, was listed on the press release when the Olympic team was announced. He also worked under John Herdman with previous Canadian men's teams, among other assignments. He is not some intern.\n\nFor Canada Soccer, this is a return to the bad old days. There was such optimism earlier this month when new men's coach Jesse Marsch, hired by new CEO Kevin Blue, guided that squad to a surprising semifinal appearance at Copa America.\n\nFor years, it was the men's program spinning its wheels while the women succeeded on the world stage -- in spite of constant off-field bumbling by Soccer Canada.\n\nBlue, through zero fault of his own, now has a major problem on his hands.\n\nOn Thursday, the soccer world will be rooting for New Zealand.", "source": {"uri": "sportsnet.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sportsnet"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242088192", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:39:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:39:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:38:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/sport/523091/olympics-spying-nz-football-ask-for-canada-not-to-be-awarded-points", "title": "Olympics spying: NZ Football ask for Canada not to be awarded points", "body": "New Zealand Football has asked that Canada not be awarded any points if they win Friday morning's game between the two teams as the Olympics spying scandal deepens.\n\nThe call comes after it was confirmed there was a second drone spying attempt on the Football Ferns from the Canadian team, three days before the first incident.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) is confident the women's team head coach Bev Priestman had no knowledge of the spying ahead of their gold medal title defence at the Paris Games.\n\nThe COC said it accepted Priestman's decision to remove herself from Friday morning's (NZT) opening match against New Zealand while two Canadian team staff members were sent home.\n\nDavid Shoemaker, the CEO of the COC, was asked repeatedly during an online media availability how Priestman avoided suspension and why he was comfortable with her resuming her coaching duties after Thursday's game.\n\n\"I was persuaded by the fact that Bev Priestman had no involvement, no knowledge in the incident,\" Shoemaker told reporters. \"Those who had the direct involvement in the incident we removed from Team Canada.\n\n\"There is no room for that in Team Canada. It doesn't conform to our standards of fair play and our values at the Canadian Olympic Committee.\"\n\nShoemaker said if any facts were to become known in the future suggesting Priestman was involved then the COC reserves the right to impose further sanctions.\n\nCanada Soccer is launching an independent external review into the matter while global soccer's governing body FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\nShoemaker also said he felt there was no need for Priestman to miss more than one game since, according to him, she was not in possession of any footage from New Zealand's training sessions.\n\n\"We thought about all the repercussions for Bev,\" said Shoemaker. \"At the end of the day the drone footage related to the filming of two New Zealand practices remained in the hands of the pilot of the drone and the advantage that I guess was intended to be obtained was not obtained.\"\n\nShoemaker also said that while he is not aware of any calls for the women's team to be disqualified from the Olympics he did say New Zealand Football registered a complaint to FIFA, asking that Canada not be awarded any points if they win.\n\nNew Zealand Football have released their first statement on the spying incident.\n\nThe statement does not confirm whether New Zealand Football has asked for Canada not to receive any points should they win, though NZF CEO Andrew Pragnall said they are seeking urgent action from world governing body FIFA.\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament.\n\n\"We note that there have been some admissions by the Canadian National Olympic Committee, and they have taken their own sanctions against the Canadian team, however, considering the seriousness of the situation, and the potential implications to the sporting integrity of the entire tournament, we have referred the matter to the FIFA {"uri": "8243713646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:29:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:29:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:28:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/joseph-lombardi-canada-soccer-drone-1.7275499", "title": "'Unaccredited analyst' at centre of Olympic drone scandal is senior Canada Soccer official | CBC News", "body": "The Canada Soccer staffer at the centre of the Olympic Games drone scandal appears to have a more formal, senior role in the organization than what officials previously let on this week, according to online records reviewed by CBC News.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) on Wednesday identified Joseph Lombardi as an \"unaccredited analyst with Canada Soccer\" who had been removed from the team and was to be \"sent home immediately\" amid allegations that someone connected to the women's team had twice used a drone to watch and record New Zealand's team while they practised.\n\nThe COC said in the same statement it had also removed from the team and sent home Jasmine Mander, an assistant coach to whom Lombardi reported.\n\nFrench prosecutors said police had on Monday morning arrested a man matching Lombardi's description near the stadium in Saint-\u00c9tienne, where New Zealand's team was practising. They found footage of that practice and of an earlier one.\n\nBut a COC news release issued on July 1 listed Lombardi as an official member of the women's national team's six-person coaching staff, led by head coach Bev Priestman.\n\nCanada Soccer spokesperson Paulo Senra confirmed on Thursday afternoon that Lombardi remains the director of the federation's Women's Excel program, described on its website as a means for players to progress from youth levels to the national team.\n\nIn a video posted online last month by Ontario Soccer, the provincial body's manager of match official development, David Barrie, said Lombardi \"served as Canada national's team staff coach, performing... analysis for both the men's and women's national team programs -- senior and youth levels.\"\n\nAccording to a staff list posted online for a CONCACAF Nations League qualifying match in 2019, Lombardi served as \"performance analyst support\" for the men's national team, under then-head coach John Herdman.\n\nA Canadian Press report from 2018 referred to Lombardi as a \"key member of Herdman's team.\"\n\nIn 2021, the Honduran men's team stopped a training session in Toronto ahead of its World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media at the time.\n\n\"I'd imagine there's probably a lot of people in Canada that fly drones, I'm sure,\" Herdman told reporters in September 2021. \"And when a big team like Honduras turn up I'm sure people are probably interested in what they're doing when they come into our country.\"\n\nPriestman served as assistant coach to Herdman, when he led Canada's women's national team. Both coaches were raised in Consett, a small town in the north of England.\n\nPriestman has apologized for the drone flights and said she did not \"direct\" those responsible. She withdrew from Olympic coaching duties for one game and did not attend her team's 2-1 win over New Zealand on Thursday.\n\nAsked by CBC Sports on Wednesday whether she was aware of the drone use, Priestman did not directly respond.\n\n\"I would just like to apologize to our country but also to New Zealand,\" she said. \"There's deep ills regarding this moment, and those don't necessarily sit directly with me, but ultimately I am accountable for any action that happens inside this camp.\"\n\nCOC chief executive officer David Shoemaker said earlier he believes Priestman had \"had no involvement, no knowledge\" of the flights.\n\n\"Those who had the direct involvement in the incident we removed from Team Canada,\" he said.\n\nSoccer's world governing body, FIFA, says it has opened disciplinary proceedings against Lombardi, Mander and Priestman.\n\n\"Did she know about this? Unfortunately, if she did, I feel like maybe she should be sent home,\" said Carrie Serwetnyk, a former member of the women's national team who was inducted into Canada's soccer hall of fame.\n\nFrench prosecutors said the man who was arrested had accepted a suspended sentence of eight months' imprisonment, after he was charged with maintaining an unmanned aircraft over a prohibited {"uri": "2024-07-432910781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:58:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:58:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:52:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://wakingthered.com/2024/07/24/16800/canadas-gold-medal-defence-marred-by-spygate-scandal-on-eve-of-olympic-tournament-opener-vs-new-zealand/", "title": "Canada's gold medal defence marred by Spygate scandal on eve of Olympic tournament opener vs. New Zealand", "body": "You thought there were a lot of layers to the New England Patriots' Spygate scandal? Cue Canada Soccer.\n\nA non-accredited member of the Canadian women's national team staff, identified as Joseph Lombardi, flew a drone over New Zealand's private training session, violating Olympic, FIFA, and French laws and labelling the defending Olympic champions as cheaters in the eyes of the world on the eve of their tournament opening match.\n\nFrench authorities detained Lombardi, and on Wednesday, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) announced that he committed two offenses of spying on New Zealand sessions, resulting in an eight-month delayed prison sentence for breaking drone laws on July 20 and July 22.\n\nEarly Wednesday morning, the COC confirmed that both Lombardi and his primary report, longtime assistant Jasmine Mander, had been removed from the team's staff. Head coach Bev Priestman also volunteered to sit out the match against New Zealand on Thursday.\n\nTo say things have not gone according to plan would be an understatement. On Thursday, as Canada takes the field for the first time in their gold medal defence, the world will be against them.\n\nRelated Read: Canada kick off gold medal defence amid spy controversy and Olympic chaos\n\nThe International Olympic Committee (IOC) expressed support for the COC's actions after the incident. However, the CanWNT and its staff could face further repercussions. According to COC CEO David Shoemaker, the New Zealand Olympic Committee has requested that Canada receive no points if they win the match.\n\nYikes.\n\nFIFA will also investigate the situation, noting that Priestman, Mander, and Lombardi might have breached Olympic and FIFA competition regulations.\n\nIn 2021, John Herdman's CanMNT faced similar drone-related accusations from Honduras before a World Cup qualifier.\n\nThe COC stands by Priestman, who claimed she had no involvement with the drones, did not see any footage, and that stepping back from the opening match demonstrates her commitment to fair play.\n\nLegally, the COC has provided Lombardi and Mander with ombudspersons to explain their rights, and Global Affairs Canada has offered additional legal and consular support, particularly to Lombardi, who faces a delayed eight-month prison sentence.\n\nLombardi was tried under Appearance on Recognition of Guilt after facing a public prosecutor on charges of \"maintaining an unmanned aircraft over a prohibited area,\" according to a CBC translation from the Saint-Ettiene prosecutor. He accepted the suspended eight-month sentence in the presence of his lawyer.\n\nFrench law offers little recourse against the Canadian team from a footballing standpoint, and the COC has also provided mental health support for Mander and Lombardi. However, the sporting repercussions could be significant.\n\nCanada will enter its Olympic opener with assistant coach Andy Spence at the helm. Spence, who joined the CanWNT in 2022, previously coached Everton's WSL team and served as an assistant with England's U19 and U21 sides.\n\nDespite Spence's capabilities, the loss of Lombardi and Mander, along with Priestman's absence, creates an unwelcome distraction. This is especially troubling for a team that has excelled in Olympic performances since their bronze medal run in London 2012 and enters as reigning champions, particularly after a disappointing 2023 World Cup marred by labor disputes with Canada Soccer.\n\nThe looming threat of a points-less victory, should a decision be reached between the NZOC, IOC, and FIFA before kickoff, adds to the tension.\n\nMoving forward, multiple organizations are conducting thorough investigations. The IOC and FIFA are looking into the matter at the NZOC's request, while the COC defers to Canada Soccer, which has announced an independent external investigation.\n\nThe CanWNT finds itself in an unexpected and challenging position as they aim for a fourth consecutive Olympic medal and a gold defense. For women's soccer players, it's already a grueling period, with the prospect of playing six matches in 18 days while missing the Opening Ceremony and much of the Olympic fanfare.\n\nThe Opening Ceremonies take place on Friday, but for CanWNT the tournament couldn't have started much worse.", "source": {"uri": "wakingthered.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Waking The Red"}, "authors": [], overshadows women's footbal", "body": "Women's competitions begin ahead of Friday's break for the opening ceremony.\n\nWomen's sports take centre stage on day 2 of the Paris Olympics on Thursday, with several games in football and handball.\n\nBut the football games come in the wake of a spying scandal that hit reigning Olympic gold medalists, Canada, with two of their staff members - assistant coach Jasmine Mander and football Joseph Lombardi - immediately sent back home.\n\nEarlier this week, New Zealand complained to the International Olympic Committee (IOC) about a series of incidents involving drones flying over their training ground.\n\nCanada later confirmed that a non-accredited member of their staff was detained after a drone was spotted above training, and issued a heartfelt apology to the Kiwi Olympic Committee.\n\n\"The Canadian Olympic Committee stands for fair play and we are shocked and disappointed,\" the statement said. \"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee.\"\n\nIt's not the first time a Canadian football team has been involved in a drone controversy involving an international rival's training session.\n\nIn 2021, in Toronto, Honduras stopped a training session ahead of their men's World Cup qualifier against Canada after spotting a drone above the field, according to reports in Honduran media.\n\nIn men's sports, there will be the first knockouts with the rugby sevens quarter-finals later in the evening.\n\nArchery will open individual sports at the Assistant coach Andy Spence will serve as the team's interim coach throughout the rest of the Olympics.\n\nThough a Canada soccer staffer was caught flying a drone over New Zealand training earlier this week in France, which is what sparked the scandal in the first place, the issue has apparently been going on for quite some time. According to TSN, both the men's and women's national teams have \"relied on drones and spying for years.\" They even apparently used them to film closed door training sessions of opponents during their gold medal run in the 2021 Olympics in Tokyo.\n\nA Canadian soccer staffer, Joseph Lombardi, was detained by French police earlier this week after he was caught flying a drone over New Zealand practices multiple times ahead of their group stage game on Thursday. French police searched his hotel room and found drone footage from two closed training sessions, which he told police \"had helped him to learn the tactics of the opposing team.\" Lombardi was charged with flying an unmanned aircraft over a prohibited area, and he accepted an eight-month suspended sentence.\n\nThe incident prompted multiple investigations. Lombardi and assistant coach Jasmine Mander, who is Lombardi's boss, were both removed from the Canadian delegation and sent home as punishment. Priestman self-imposed a one-game suspension, and she was not on the sidelines for Thursday's win over New Zealand.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for the conduct in our program,\" Priestman said in {"uri": "8241460918", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:47:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:47:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:45:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/olympics/olympics-2024-drone-gate-claims-first-victims-canada-coach-stood-down-from-football-ferns-game/RLJCMXXD3NCFBLPTUK5UQ4F7S4/", "title": "Drone spying scandal claims first victims as Canada staff sent home", "body": "After discovering a second drone incident at New Zealand training on July 19th - to complement the already known one from Monday - for which an individual was detained by St Etienne police - two Canadian staff members have been sent home from the Olympics.\n\nAnalyst Joseph Lombardi is already on a plane back, while assistant coach Jasmine Mander is also gone. Head coach Bev Priestman - who has previous links to New Zealand - has also stood down from Thursday's match against the Ferns.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said. \"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee have also said their staff will undergo mandatory ethics training.\n\nThe inside word here is that the COC are scrambling, desperate to avoid any further sanctions, with financial penalties likely. A Canadian journalist admitted it was highly embarrassing.\n\nThe Herald can also reveal that Fifa may become involved. Though the Olympics comes under the IOC, Fifa is responsible for elements of the football program and it appears likely the matter may be referred to the all powerful Fifa Integrity unit.\n\nThe Herald attempted to question COC officials in Paris on Tuesday afternoon but their large office at the main press centre was empty, with padlocks across the door.\n\nThe motivation is still unclear - and that is the biggest lingering question. The NZOC and chef de mission Nigel Avery declined to respond to the Herald's question, when asked if this was a matter of Lombardi going rogue, or something more sinister and pre-planned.\n\n\"It's a great question but we just don't know,\" said Avery. \"We know an amount of information and are investigating further.\"\n\nThe drama started on 11:40pm on Tuesday night with the NZOC press release. The Herald had heard rumours of something happening in Saint Eitenne on Tuesday afternoon but was unable to confirm exactly what.\n\nNZOC head of communications Ashley Abbott defended the process, when asked why it had taken so long to inform the public and media.\n\nIt takes a while to be able to understand exactly what had happened,\" said Abbott. \"On the 22nd, a drone was flown over the New Zealand team football training, in Saint Etienne. The New Zealand team support staff noticed the drone and reported it to the police. That person was detained.\"\n\nAbbott said Team Canada confirmed that Monday's footage had been used for scouting purposes. Meanwhile, the NZOC want answers from Canada, and have lodged the incident with the IOC integrity unit.\n\n\"This incident is against that we stand for, with our values, with our commitment to an even and fair field of play,\" said Avery. It's not the topic we want to be talking about. Extremely disappointed and shocked, Integrity is one of our five key pillars. It's also taking away from us from an energy perspective. Concerned about our team; haven't had a smooth buildup so far and this is another thing to overcome.\"\n\nAbbott and Avery said there had been numerous meetings with the Canada Olympic Committee - they have apologised to us, they are deeply embarrassed, shocked.\"\n\nThey didn't want to speculate on possible outcomes - saying that the IOC will go through their own processes..\n\nAvery also said it was quite complex. \"It wasn't in the field of play, it's wrong to speculate.\"\n\nThere have been other security breaches using drones in France, but they have been related to teams going outside their training zone. Drones are not permitted at all in Paris but are allowed in most of the other venues, including where the Football Ferns and Oly-Whites are based.\n\nAbbott said the footage from Monday was around five minutes, though it could have been longer. \"That footage is with police.\"\n\nIt's a bit of a riddle why Canada even bothered. They are the reigning Games champions while the Ferns are relative minnows, only here via one of the easiest Olympic qualification paths in world sport (playing amateur Oceania teams). New Zealand hasn't beaten Canada since 1987, and have been on the wrong end of some heavy scorelines since then.", "source": {"uri": "nzherald.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "NZ Herald"}, THE CANADIAN PRESS/Chris YoungPARIS - Bev Priestman's time at the Paris Olympics ended before the opening ceremony. The Canadian Olympic Committee has removed the head coach of its women's national soccer head coach for the remainder of the Games amid a drone spying scandal. The COC added in a statement released at 1:24 a.m. local time that assistant coach Andy Spence will lead the defending gold medallists for the remainder of the tournament. Canada's camp was thrown into disarray this week after two team staffers were sent home for allegedly using a drone to spy on a New Zealand practice. Priestman denied any involvement, but did not attend Thursday's 2-1 victory over New Zealand as FIFA - soccer's world governing body - and the International Olympic Committee investigate. {"uri": "8242523598", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:59:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:59:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T06:59:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/olympics/paris-2024/news/paris-2024-olympics-canadian-olympic-committee-bev-priestman-canada-football-new-zealand-drone-scandal-incident/article68444070.ece", "title": "Paris 2024 Olympics: Canadian Olympic Committee head says women's football coach had no knowledge of drone incident", "body": "The Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) is confident women's football head coach Bev Priestman had no knowledge of the spying incident that has engulfed her squad in scandal ahead of its gold medal title defence at the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\nThe COC said on Wednesday it accepted Priestman's decision to remove herself from Thursday's opening match against New Zealand while two Canadian team staff members, assistant coach Jasmine Mander and Canada football analyst Joseph Lombardi, were sent home amid allegations of drone use at two New Zealand practices.\n\nDavid Shoemaker, the CEO of the COC, was asked repeatedly during an online media availability how Priestman avoided suspension and why he was comfortable with her resuming her coaching duties after Thursday's game.\n\n\"I was persuaded by the fact that Bev Priestman had no involvement, no knowledge in the incident,\" Shoemaker told reporters. \"Those who had the direct involvement in the incident we removed from Team Canada,\" he said.\n\n\"There is no room for that in Team Canada. It doesn't conform to our standards of fair play and our values at the Canadian Olympic Committee,\" he added.\n\nShoemaker said if any facts were to become known in the future suggesting Priestman was involved then the COC reserves the right to impose further sanctions.\n\nALSO READ | Paris 2024 Olympics: Why is football an under-23 tournament in the Summer Games?\n\nCanada Soccer is launching an independent external review into the matter while global football's governing body FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\nShoemaker also said he felt there was no need for Priestman to miss more than one game since, according to him, she was not in possession of any footage from New Zealand's training sessions.\n\n\"We thought about all the repercussions for Bev,\" said Shoemaker. \"At the end of the day the drone footage related to the filming of two New Zealand practices remained in the hands of the pilot of the drone and the advantage that I guess was intended to be obtained was not obtained,\" he said.\n\nShoemaker also said that while he is not aware of any calls for the women's team to be disqualified from the Olympics he did say New Zealand Football registered a complaint to FIFA, asking that Canada not be awarded any points if it wins on Thursday.\n\nLatest on SportstarParis 2024 Olympics: Canadian Olympic Committee head says women's football coach had no knowledge of {"uri": "8243279186", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:05:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:05:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:04:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://worldsoccertalk.com/olympics/new-zealand-asks-fifa-to-punish-canada-after-spying-incidents/", "title": "New Zealand asks FIFA to punish Canada after spying incidents", "body": "New Zealand soccer officials are asking for Canada to face punishment for their role in a spying controversy. An uncredited Canadian women's national team member recently flew a drone over New Zealand's practice. The issue, however, was not an isolated incident. The drone interrupted the Football Ferns' training on two separate days.\n\nTeam New Zealand contacted French authorities and Olympic officials following the second incident. An investigation remains ongoing, but authorities quickly apprehended the drone operator. As a result, the Canadian member and an assistant coach have both been removed from the team.\n\nCanada's head coach, Beverly Priestman, also recently announced that she would not be on the sidelines for the upcoming matchup between the two teams. Canada faces New Zealand in their opening 2024 Olympics game on Thursday.\n\nDespite the self-imposed suspension, New Zealand Football CEO Andrew Pragnell is calling for more regarding the situation. The executive claims to have contacted FIFA directly and asked the governing body to take \"urgent action\" on the matter.\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" Pragnell said in a statement released on Thursday.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament.\"\n\n\"We note that there have been some admissions by the Canadian National Olympic Committee, and they have taken their own sanctions against the Canadian team, however, considering the seriousness of the situation, and the potential implications to the sporting integrity of the entire tournament, we have referred the matter to the FIFA Disciplinary Committee seeking urgent action.\"\n\nWhile FIFA investigates the issue, the drone operator in question has already received their punishment from French police. According to reports, authorities arrested the uncredited team Canada member earlier in the week. Authorities confiscated the drone and found video of New Zealand's practice from two different days. Police say that the footage \"would have allowed him to know the tactics of the opposing team.\"\n\nThe Canadian drone operator picked up an eight-month suspended prison sentence for their actions. A suspended sentence means that the offender likely will not serve the aforementioned time in jail. Instead, it works almost like probation. If the defendant goes on to break similar laws in the near future, they could serve out their sentence behind bars. The move is typically a deterrent against future potential crimes.\n\nCanada and New Zealand face off on Thursday, July 25 in Saint-Etienne. The matchup is likely to be contentious and will be immensely important to both sides. The two teams are in Group A alongside hosts France. FIFA currently ranks Les Bleues second in the world. They are one of the tournament's favorites as the host. Losing Thursday's game would put either Canada or New Zealand behind the eight-ball in the competition.", "source": {"uri": "worldsoccertalk.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "World Soccer Talk"},
