Here's all you need to know", "body": "Canada's Olympic contingent is amid a massive fiasco after their women's football team coach withdrew from the opening game against New Zealand and two team staff were sent home following a spy drone scandal.Canada's women's football team participating at the Paris Olympics 2024 is currently in a major fix as their head coach has withdrawn from their opening match and two team staff have been sent home after a spy drone scandal. According to The Telegraph's report, Canadian team staff allegedly recorded training of their rivals, New Zealand, against whom defending champions Canada will play their opening game. After France authorities detained the staff on grounds of unfair activities, the team's head coach withdrew from the opening game and the two accused staff members were sent back immediately.\n\nCanada' Olympic authorities also apologized following the capture of the team's staff by France authorities, which has now become a point of controversy, right before the commencement of the Paris Olympics 2024.\n\nCanadian Olympic Committee (COC) recently issued a public statement apologizing for this incident and has acknowledged the detaining of a 'non-accredited' team staff, following a complaint by New Zealand Football, says The Telegraph's report. A disciplinary committee is seriously looking into the allegations and complaints around the use of unfair means during such a prestigious event like the Paris Olympics.\n\nMeanwhile, there are also claims that at least six flying drones are being intercepted by French authorities everyday, according to a statement by French Prime Minister Gabriel Attal, mostly around the sites where the main events are to take place. action from FIFA over drone incident", "body": "July 25 (Reuters) - New Zealand Football CEO Andrew Pragnell called on FIFA to take urgent action over a spying scandal involving Olympic champions Canada at the Paris Games and said failure to do so could tarnish the sporting integrity of the entire tournament.\n\nCanada women's coach Bev Priestman removed herself from opening match duties while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games on Wednesday amid allegations of drone use at two New Zealand practice sessions.\n\nCanada, who won their first Olympic title three years ago in Tokyo, open their campaign in Paris against Group A opponents New Zealand later on Thursday.\n\nCanada Soccer has said it will launch an independent review into the matter while FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" Pragnell said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament.\"\n\nCanadian Olympic Committee CEO David Shoemaker said he was confident Priestman had no knowledge of the spying incident but added that if any facts were to become known suggesting she was involved, then the body would impose further sanctions.\n\n\"We note that there have been some admissions by the Canadian National Olympic Committee, and they have taken their own sanctions against the Canadian team,\" Pragnell added.\n\n\"However, considering the seriousness of the situation, and the potential implications to the sporting integrity of the entire tournament, we have referred the matter to the FIFA disciplinary committee seeking urgent action.\"\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee has also reported the drone incident to the police and {"uri": "8241993545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:50:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:50:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:49:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/3029066-scandal-in-canadian-womens-soccer-coach-cleared-amid-spy-allegations", "title": "Scandal in Canadian Women's Soccer: Coach Cleared Amid Spy Allegations | Sports-Games", "body": "The Canadian Olympic Committee has cleared women's soccer head coach Bev Priestman of any involvement in a spying incident that has led to scandal ahead of their gold medal defense. Though Priestman will miss the opening match against New Zealand, disciplinary actions were taken against two staff members.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) is confident women's soccer head coach Bev Priestman had no knowledge of the spying incident that has engulfed her squad in scandal ahead of their gold medal title defense at the Paris Olympics. The COC said on Wednesday it accepted Priestman's decision to remove herself from Thursday's opening match against New Zealand while two Canadian team staff members were sent home amid allegations of drone use at two New Zealand practices.\n\nDavid Shoemaker, the CEO of the COC, was asked repeatedly during an online media availability how Priestman avoided suspension and why he was comfortable with her resuming her coaching duties after Thursday's game. \"I was persuaded by the fact that Bev Priestman had no involvement, no knowledge in the incident,\" Shoemaker told reporters. \"Those who had the direct involvement in the incident we removed from Team Canada.\n\n\"There is no room for that in Team Canada. It doesn't conform to our standards of fair play and our values at the Canadian Olympic Committee.\" Shoemaker said if any facts were to become known in the future suggesting Priestman was involved then the COC reserves the right to impose further sanctions.\n\nCanada Soccer is launching an independent external review into the matter while global soccer's governing body FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings. Shoemaker also said he felt there was no need for Priestman to miss more than one game since, according to him, she was not in possession of any footage from New Zealand's training sessions.\n\n\"We thought about all the repercussions for Bev,\" said Shoemaker. \"At the end of the day the drone footage related to the filming of two New Zealand practices remained in the hands of the pilot of the drone and the advantage that I guess was intended to be obtained was not obtained.\" Shoemaker also said that while he is not aware of any calls for the women's team to be disqualified from the Olympics he did say New Zealand Football registered a complaint to FIFA, asking that Canada not be awarded any points if they win on Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8242997965", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "11:58:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T11:58:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T11:57:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://thesportsgrail.com/who-are-joseph-lombardi-and-jasmine-mander-of-the-canada-womens-football-team-caught-spying-on-new-zealand-using-drone-during-olympics-2024/", "title": "Who are Joseph Lombardi and Jasmine Mander of the Canada women's football team caught spying on New Zealand using drone during Olympics 2024", "body": "Joseph Lombardi and Jasmine Mander of the Canada women's football team used a drone to spy on New Zealand during the Olympics 2024\n\nThe Canada Women's National Team is currently under scrutiny after one of their assistant coaches Joseph Lombardi was caught spying on the New Zealand Women's National Team, using a drone during their training sessions.\n\nThe shocking incident come just right ahead of their Paris Olympics 2024 Group A opener match.\n\nCanada manager Bev Priestman was previously blamed for the incident but after further investigations, Joseph Lombardi and Mander emerged as the culprist.\n\nMander is the assistant coach to whom Lombardi reported and she is a 29-year-old from Richmond, B.C. She was an assistant on the 2021 gold medal-winning team in Tokyo and a former kinesiology student at the University of British Columbia, Mander began her coaching career as a teenager, attending a FIFA regional coaching workshop in Canada in 2014.\n\nMander's brother, Amar Mander, is reportedly a team physiotherapist for the New Zealand women's team.\n\nAhead of the Paris 2024 Olympics opening soccer match between Canada WNT and the New Zealand WNT, Canadian coaching staff and team analyst Joseph Lombardi was caught and arrested for spying on the opposing team during one of their training sessions. According to a statement from the New Zealand Olympic Committee, Jitka Klimkova's side had reported to police after they spotted a drone flying near their training ground. The French authorities eventually responded and quickly detained the pilot, who was later identified as Lombardi.\n\nJoseph Lombardi is a Canadian soccer coach who was born on May 24, 1981 in Brampton, Ontario, Canada. Lombardi is one of the coaching staff members of the Canadian WNT, working as a technical coach under Bev Priestman. Joseph earned his Canada Soccer Coaching B Diploma in 2006, and then his Canada Soccer Coaching A Diploma in 2009.\n\nJoseph Lombardi is currently 43 years old and stands at a height of 173 cm.\n\nAfter obtaining his coaching certifications, Lombardi served as a regional coach with the Ontario Soccer Association, He later served as a coach for the Canada Soccer women's national youth program in 2012. During this time, he made contributions to six FIFA youth tournaments from 2012 to 2022.\n\nHe also notably served as a part of the team staff at the latest FIFA Women's World Cup in Australia and New Zealand back in 2023. Lombardi was most recently serving as a technical coach under Bev Priestman for the Canada Women's national team. Aside from his roles with the WNT, Lombardi has also worked for the CanMNT. He served under former coach John Herdman and Eric Tenllado for the U15s.\n\nParis authorities have previously issued a strict no-drone flying policy around the city and some specific places. As such, the French police have booked Joseph Lombardi for \"flying an unmanned aircraft over a prohibited area.\" Moreover, Lombardi himself admitted to the wrongdoing. Following the turn of events, authorities have sentenced to 8 months in jail along with a \u20ac45,000 fine.\n\nInterestingly, the Canadian coach had previously flew the drone on July 19 as well. Following further investigations, authorities found out that another assistant coach named Jasmine Mander was also involved. As a result, she got removed from the team. Jasmine is a native of Richmond, B.C. and played a key role in the 2021 gold medal-winning team in Tokyo.", "source": {"uri": "thesportsgrail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The SportsGrail"}, involving Olympic champion Canada at the Paris Games and said failure to do so could tarnish the sporting integrity of the entire tournament.\n\nCanada women's coach Bev Priestman removed herself from opening match duties while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games on Wednesday amid allegations of drone use at two New Zealand practice sessions.\n\nCanada, which won its first Olympic title three years ago in Tokyo, opens its campaign in Paris against Group A opponents New Zealand later on Thursday.\n\nCanada Soccer has said it will launch an independent review into the matter while FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\nALSO READ | Paris 2024 Olympics: Why is football an under-23 tournament in the Summer Games?\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" Pragnell said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament.\"\n\nCanadian Olympic Committee CEO David Shoemaker said he was confident Priestman had no knowledge of the spying incident but added that if any facts were to become known suggesting she was involved, then the body would impose further sanctions.\n\nALSO READ | Paris 2024 Olympics: Canadian Olympic Committee head says women's football coach had no knowledge of drone incident\n\n\"We note that there have been some admissions by the Katie Kitching of New Zealand in action with Jade Rose of Canada.\n\nCanada is making news at the Olympics already - but not the good kind. On Wednesday, two Canadians - analyst Joseph Lombardi and assistant coach Jasmine Mander - were sent home and removed from the women's soccer team after a member of the support team was caught spying with a drone on the New Zealand women's team practice. Lombardi was also given a suspended prison sentence from French officials, which he accepted.\n\nTeam Canada Head Coach Bev Priestman opted to voluntarily sit out the first game against New Zealand. Fifa is now investigating Priestman, Lombardi, and Mander.\n\nThe drone scandal couldn't entirely distract, however, from the news that singer Celine Dion was seen in Paris, fueling speculation that she could perform at the Olympics. Dion was diagnosed with Stiff Person Syndrome in 2022, which has left her unable to perform.\n\nShe won't be the only artist catching attention in Paris, though. Snoop Dog will carry the Olympic torch on Friday.\n\nThe US is expected to win 123 medals and lead the count at the Paris games, while Canada is anticipated to bring home 22, putting them just outside being reported around the world", "body": "The news of the Canadian drone incident at the Olympics is being reported widely by international news agencies.\n\nThe Football Ferns have complained after a drone operated by a Canadian support staff member was caught flying over their training practice.\n\nA person was detained by police and Team Canada has issued an apology, saying it is investigating the circumstances surrounding the incident.\n\nThe New York Times, through its sporting sub-site The Athletic, said the drone incident had provided some \"unexpected drama\".\n\nReporter Meg Linehan said it was not clear yet what would be the consequences of allegedly trying to record another team's training session.\n\nLinehan pointed out security forces had been on heightened alert for drones, though many were put up by tourists.\n\n\"Drones have been a story across Paris 2024, with French prime minister Gabriel Attal saying Tuesday that an average of six drones per day have been intercepted at Olympic sites.\"\n\nUSA Today said the Paris Games had not started yet and were facing controversy.\n\n\"The 2024 Olympic Games in Paris haven't even had an opening ceremony yet, and we're already dealing with a potential cheating scandal.\"\n\nThe Daily Mail called it an \"Olympic spy storm\" and reported the incident as \"Canadian Soccer is facing cheating allegations entering the Paris Olympics\".\n\nAn Associated Press story was picked up by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the state broadcaster.\n\nESPN's report focused on the statements by the New Zealand Olympic Committee and the Canadian Olympic Committee, including it was \"reviewing next steps\" with the International Olympic Committee, the Paris organising committee and FIFA.\n\nMany Canadian news outlets carried the story prominently, filed by the Canadian press agency. It highlighted the Canadian Olympic Committee's statement that the person flying the drone was a \"non-accredited\" member of Canada Soccer's support team.\n\nThe agency, like many other media reports including RNZ, also noted the gap between the two teams in world rankings.\n\n\"Canada, the defending Olympic women's soccer champion, is scheduled to open its tournament against 28th ranked New Zealand on Friday in Saint-Etienne.\"\n\nSome news outlets around the world - like the Guardian - carried a Reuters story on the drone. Canada women's coach Bev Priestman removed herself from opening match duties while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games on Wednesday amid allegations of drone use at two New Zealand practice sessions.\n\nCanada, who won their first Olympic title three years ago in Tokyo, open their campaign in Paris against Group A opponents New Zealand later on Thursday. Canada Soccer has said it will launch an independent review into the matter while FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" Pragnell said in a statement on Thursday. \"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament.\"\n\nCanadian Olympic Committee CEO David Shoemaker said he was confident Priestman had no knowledge of the spying incident but added that if any facts were to become known suggesting she was involved, then the body would impose further sanctions. \"We note that there have been some admissions by the Canadian National Olympic Committee, and they have taken their own sanctions against the Canadian team,\" Pragnell added.\n\n\"However, considering the seriousness of the situation, and the potential implications to the sporting integrity of the entire tournament, we have referred the matter to the FIFA disciplinary committee seeking urgent action.\" New Zealand's Olympic Committee has also reported the drone incident to the police and the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff {"uri": "8243375821", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:15:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:15:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:13:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.nl/tech-is-already-making-this-olympics-a-mess/", "title": "Tech is already making this Olympics a mess", "body": "Errant drones and soccer refereeing tech are already sparking chaos at this year's Olympics. Canada women's soccer coaches apologized after flying a drone over a New Zealand practice session. And in men's soccer, a goal was called off 90 minutes after the match concluded.\n\nFrom errant drones to long-delayed refereeing calls, technology is sparking dramatic scenes at this year's Olympic Games in Paris -- even before they've even formally begun.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) apologized after a women's soccer team staff member was caught flying a drone over a training session of soon-to-be opponents New Zealand Football.\n\nThe Canadian team's staff member was apparently trying to spy on the practice by recording it, the COC said in its statement.\n\n\"We offer our heartfelt apologies to New Zealand Football, to all the players affected, and to the New Zealand Olympic Committee,\" the organization wrote.\n\nThe New Zealand Olympic Committee said in its own statement that it was \"deeply shocked and disappointed.\"\n\nCOC later confirmed two staffers -- an unaccredited analyst and assistant coach -- were being sent home immediately, and head coach Bev Priestman would \"remove herself\" from the New Zealand match Thursday.\n\nThat's not the only mishap thus far.\n\nIn the first game of the Olympic men's soccer tournament between Argentina and Morocco, VAR (video assistant referee) technology and rowdy crowds resulted in an equalizing goal being disqualified -- an hour and a half after the match had already concluded, The Athletic reports.\n\nThe game appeared to have been over after Argentina's late goal, and Morocco fans stormed the field. But with the stadium emptied, VAR referees determined the play was offside, ruling out the goal.\n\nThe contentious game then resumed in an empty stadium.\n\nArgentina head coach Javier Mascherano referred to the fiasco as a \"circus,\" according to The Athletic -- a sentiment that Argentine soccer legend Lionel Messi appeared to echo in an Instagram Story.\n\nThe Olympic Games formally kick off on Friday, with the Opening Ceremony starting at 1:30 p.m. ET.\n\nRead the original article on Business Insider\n\nDit artikel is oorspronkelijk verschenen op z24.nl", "source": {"uri": Women's Soccer Team Days Before Olympic Showdown", "body": "Canada's women's soccer team is gearing up to defend its gold medal at the Olympics in Paris, but some major drama is already brewing after medals they managed to secure in London and Rio and managed to do exactly that by staging an impressive run that ended with them topping Sweden in a shootout in the gold medal game.\n\nAs a result, expectations are pretty high heading into the 2024 Summer Olympics, but things took a very interesting turn thanks to what unfolded in France on Monday.\n\nCanada and New Zealand will kick off the women's tournament when they face off at Stade Geoffroy-Guichard in the city of Saint-Etienne on Thursday in a game where the team from the Great White North is listed as the heavy favorite (New Zealand failed to exit the group stage in Japan, and its quarterfinals appearance in London remains its best Olympics result to date).\n\nAccording to the National Post, we have a fresh new SpyGate on member of Canada's support staff.\n\nNew Zealand understandably decided to file a complaint with the integrity committee operated by the IOC, and while they haven't taken any official action as of this writing, the Canadian Olympic Committee swiftly dismissed the staffer in question (as well as assistant coach Jasmine Mander) after discovering a drone had also been used for similar purposes last week.\n\nCanada head coach Bev Priestman also issued a self-imposed punishment by announcing she won't be on the sidelines when her team faces off against New Zealand and also issued a formal {"uri": "8242003268", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:00:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:00:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:00:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.thestar.com.my/sport/football/2024/07/25/olympics-soccer-coc-head-says-priestman-had-no-knowledge-of-drone-incident", "title": "Olympics-Soccer-COC head says Priestman had no knowledge of drone incident", "body": "(Reuters) - The Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) is confident women's soccer head coach Bev Priestman had no knowledge of the spying incident that has engulfed her squad in scandal ahead of their gold medal title defence at the Paris Olympics.\n\nThe COC said on Wednesday it accepted Priestman's decision to remove herself from Thursday's opening match against New Zealand while two Canadian team staff members were sent home amid allegations of drone use at two New Zealand practices.\n\nDavid Shoemaker, the CEO of the COC, was asked repeatedly during an online media availability how Priestman avoided suspension and why he was comfortable with her resuming her coaching duties after Thursday's game.\n\n\"I was persuaded by the fact that Bev Priestman had no involvement, no knowledge in the incident,\" Shoemaker told reporters. \"Those who had the direct involvement in the incident we removed from Team Canada.\n\n\"There is no room for that in Team Canada. It doesn't conform to our standards of fair play and our values at the Canadian Olympic Committee.\"\n\nShoemaker said if any facts were to become known in the future suggesting Priestman was involved then the COC reserves the right to impose further sanctions.\n\nCanada Soccer is launching an independent external review into the matter while global soccer's governing body FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\nShoemaker also said he felt there was no need for Priestman to miss more than one game since, according to him, she was not in possession of any footage from New Zealand's training sessions.\n\n\"We thought about all the repercussions for Bev,\" said Shoemaker. \"At the end of the day the drone footage related to the filming of two New Zealand practices remained in the hands of the pilot of the drone and the advantage that I guess was intended to be obtained was not obtained.\"\n\nShoemaker also said that while he is not aware of any calls for the women's team to be disqualified from the Olympics he did say New Zealand Football registered a complaint to FIFA, asking that Canada not be awarded any points if they win on Thursday.\n\n(Reporting by Frank Pingue in {"uri": "8242515356", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:54:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:54:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T06:54:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2024/0725/1461696-paris-2024-nz-football-seek-urgent-action-from-fifa/", "title": "Paris 2024: NZ Football seek urgent action from FIFA", "body": "New Zealand Football CEO Andrew Pragnell called on FIFA to take urgent action over a spying scandal involving Olympic champions Canada at the Paris Games and said failure to do so could tarnish the sporting integrity of the entire tournament.\n\nCanada women's coach Bev Priestman removed herself from opening match duties while an assistant coach and a team analyst were kicked out of the Games on Wednesday amid allegations of drone use at two New Zealand practice sessions.\n\nCanada, who won their first Olympic title three years ago in Tokyo, open their campaign in Paris against Group A opponents New Zealand later on Thursday.\n\nCanada Soccer has said it will launch an independent review into the matter while FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" Pragnell said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament.\"\n\nCanadian Olympic Committee CEO David Shoemaker said he was confident Priestman (above) had no knowledge of the spying incident but added that if any facts were to become known suggesting she was involved, then the body would impose further sanctions.\n\n\"We note that there have been some admissions by the Canadian National Olympic Committee, and they have taken their own sanctions against the Canadian team,\" Pragnell added.\n\n\"However, considering the seriousness of the situation, and the potential implications to the sporting integrity of the entire tournament, we have referred the matter to the FIFA disciplinary committee seeking urgent action.\"\n\nNew Zealand's Olympic Committee has also reported the drone incident to the police and the International Olympic But this Olympics scandal isn't going away", "body": "SAINT \u00c9TIENNE, France -- New Zealand women's soccer coach Michael Mayne didn't blame the loss on Canada's spying scandal, which was pretty decent of him. New Zealand went up 1-0 on a shocking early corner, surrendered a goal right before the half -- \"coach killer,\" Mayne called it, grimly -- and gave up the winner in the 79th minute to Evelyne Viens. Canada beat New Zealand 2-1 to open their Olympics as defending gold medallists, because Canada always beats New Zealand. Like, pretty much always.\n\nThe Star In Paris Opinion Bruce Arthur: Canada got caught flying a drone over a soccer practice. So why is Bev Priestman still the coach?\n\nRelieving the women's coach of her duties would require the confidence that she is in charge of her staff, which shouldn't be much of a leap. But\n\nAnd Mayne acknowledged the scandal was tough for his players. He, like them, was disappointed in Canada. He was asked about Canada coach Bev Priestman's story, which is that a member of her staff decided to spy on another team without telling the head coach, twice. Mayne was asked what would he would do if that happened on his staff.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"Yeah, it wouldn't,\" said Mayne. He's an affable, bearlike, unshaven bloke, but he was deadly serious about that.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThis was the game Priestman offered to sit out after Canada staffer Joey Lombardi was arrested and convicted of flying a drone over the stadium while the Kiwis were practicing. Lombardi and his direct superior, assistant coach Jasmine Mander, were kicked off the team and sent home. The Canadian Olympic Committee accepted Priestman's explanation, which was that she didn't tell her staff to spy on another team.\n\nWhich means in the best-case scenario, Priestman lost control of her staff to an alarming degree. In the slightly worse scenario, she created an environment where she didn't HAVE to tell her assistants to spy on other teams, even at the Olympics.\n\nAnd of course, that leaves the worst-case scenario, which is that of course Priestman knew, that this was not a one-off event, and that if you are spying on a New Zealand team that Canada hasn't lost to since 1987, then maybe you just spy on pretty much anybody. Maybe, on a team whose budget was never too generous and which has recently been cut, you do anything you can to gain an edge.\n\nThis also doubles, unfortunately, as the most likely scenario. Priestman still hasn't been asked how in the world she couldn't have known.\n\nBecause this would be an embarrassment for any Canadian Olympic team, but it's worse when it's the defending champions. That gold medal was the high point in Canadian soccer history. It's been a rough couple years -- at war with their federation over equal treatment and compensation, budget and staff cuts, testimony before Parliament, a lawsuit, all as extra sponsorship and broadcasting money is sucked away by a brutally limiting long-term contract that Canada Soccer signed two years before she took the job. According to sources, Priestman nearly left late last year: there were rumours she was a candidate to coach Team USA, and also looked at at least one pro job.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut that gold medal in Tokyo happened, and now this team has been tarnished in some people's eyes; it doesn't matter if everybody cheats, because not everyone got caught at the Olympics, and Canada did. For the record, the interim coach, assistant Andy Spence, said he had no knowledge of the spying scheme. Mayne, for his part, said the corner that New Zealand scored on wasn't new: it was part of the package the Ferns had worked on during one of the spying sessions. He noted that he couldn't alter too much, anyway.\n\nOlympics And Paralympics Canada's soccer drone scandal is wild. There's been plenty of wacky and weird Olympic drama over the years\n\nPooping in a river. Faking a motorcycle crash. Being attacked by a priest. The Olympics have a long history of bizarre scandals.\n\n\"We had one (practice) session, you can't change too much: it's next to impossible,\" said the Ferns coach. \"So you can tweak a couple things. But the reality is, it's like, do we change a lot and maybe come out and not be as prepared?\"\n\nLook, Canada was better: bigger, faster, more skilled, more cohesive. Clo\u00e9 Lacasse finished a one-touch passing symphony from Ashley Lawrence, Jesse Fleming, and Nichelle Prince just before halftime, and you could almost see Canada exhale. The second half was dominant, and Fleming finally sent a long-distance ball right on the money to Viens for the winner. Mayne gave Canada full marks, as did his players.\n\nBut he was also asked if it felt like the integrity of the competition had been compromised, and he said, \"It's hard not to have that feeling. It is hard.\"\n\nMake no mistake: Priestman has been a jewel in this country, on and off the field. It wasn't just John Herdman who built the program back from the dark ages. Priestman has succeeded under difficult circumstances.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nBut this scandal isn't going away. There's a FIFA investigation, and a Canada Soccer investigation, and if the Canadian Olympic Committee hadn't been bowled over by Priestman's denial of responsibility behind the scenes -- her indignation, her embarrassment, her conviction -- then the COC might have made sure her presence didn't tar whatever this team does here.\n\nBut when she coaches again at these Games, it will.", {"uri": "2024-07-432439584", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:10:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:10:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:05:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://dailyhive.com/vancouver/france-fifa-canada-olympics-scandal", "title": "Canada staff member threatened with prison for Olympic scandal", "body": "The 2024 Paris Olympics have barely gotten underway, and Canada already appears to be popping up as a bit of a nuisance for the host country.\n\nOn Tuesday, the news broke that the New Zealand women's national soccer team had flagged a drone flying over one of their training sessions. The drone was eventually linked back to the Canadian contingent.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee sent home Canada Soccer staff members Joseph Lombardi and Jasmine Mander as a result of the incident, but that might actually be the least of their concerns.\n\nIn a press release put out today by a French prosecutor, (and as translated by CBC's Devin Heroux), more details emerged of Lombardi being arrested and his subsequent acceptance of an eight-month suspended prison sentence, meaning he wouldn't likely have to serve it should conditions of probation be followed.\n\n\"Analysis of the images captured by the interested party showed New Zealand players applying instructions given by their coach, but also images captured previously, on July 20, when they were training in the same circumstances at the Michon stadium in Saint-Etienne,\" the release read. \"[Lombardi's] custody was extended by the public prosecutor's office, allowing him to explain that the videos had enabled him to learn the tactics of the opposing team. He also admitted to the acts committed on July 20, which had initially been kept under wraps.\"\n\nThe FIFA Disciplinary Committee also announced today that it \"has opened proceedings against Canada Soccer, Ms. Beverly Priestman, Mr. Joseph Lombardi and Ms. Jasmine Mander due to the potential breach of article 13 of the FIFA Disciplinary Code and article 6.1 of the Regulations Olympic Football Tournaments Games of the XXXIII Olympiad Paris 2024 - Final Competition,\" a statement read. \"The matter will be submitted for the consideration of the Disciplinary Committee in the next days.\"\n\nCanada and New Zealand meet in their opening match of the tournament on Thursday at 11 am ET/8 am PT. Canada enters the tournament as defending gold medallists, defeating Sweden in the Tokyo 2020 Olympics Final.\n\nIn related news, the Associated Press reported that \"about 1,000 people suspected of {"uri": "2024-07-433598569", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:28:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:28:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:26:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4823529422283173, "url": "https://wrif.com/2024/07/25/canada-womens-soccer-coach/", "title": "Canada Women's Soccer Coach Stepping Down From Olympics Opener", "body": "Canada Women's soccer coach is stepping down from the team's opening game at the Paris Olympics against New Zealand. It's all over a reported drone scandal!\n\nThe 2024 Paris Olympics hasn't even officially started and there's already an alleged cheating scandal. Drones were spotted flying over closed practices sessions leading to an investigation. Now, the defending Gold Medal champions could be in some trouble!\n\nWhy Is Canada Women's Soccer Coach Stepping Down From Opener?\n\nThe Summer Olympics are always a great watch. You get the track and field events, basketball, gymnastics, swimming, and more! One of those sports included under said \"more\" category would be soccer. In the Tokyo Olympics, the Canada women's soccer team captured the Gold Medal defeating Sweden in the Finals. However, their road to a repeat just got a little more difficult.\n\nAccording to AP News, an investigation was started after New Zealand complained about drones flying over their closed practice sessions earlier in the week. Following the investigation, two staff members on Canada women's soccer team, Assistant Coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi, were sent home, per AP. Now, Coach Bev Priestman is reportedly voluntarily removing herself from the opener against New Zealand in the name of sportsmanship. Assistant Coach Andy Spence will lead the team in Bev's absence.\n\nPriestman tells AP, \"By no means did I direct the individuals. I'm still learning the details and obviously this is all unfolding. But again, I think the important thing right now is to look forward, put the actions in place and take the sanctions.\" The Associated Press reports that a French court sentenced a 43-year-old Canadian man to an 8-months suspended sentence for filming 2 of New Zealand's training sessions with a drone. That man identified himself as an independent sports analyst for the Canadian federation.\n\nInterestingly, this isn't the first time a drone with a Canada connection has been spotted filming a practice session. The Associated Press reports Honduras had to stop a training session in 2021 in Toronto because a drone was spotted flying above the pitch. Canadians are supposed to be famous for being kind and friendly. This doesn't seem to fit that description. It's good to see Canada taking the Olympics seriously and clearly they want to win some medals. However, you have to win them honorably! "body": "The police and Fifa have been urged to take action over concerns that Olympics champions Canada have spied on New Zealand's training sessions ahead of Paris 2024.\n\nNew Zealand Football boss Andrew Pragnell has accused the Canada women's team of using a drone to gather information in preparation for their tournament opener on Thursday.\n\nThe incident has now been reported to Fifa, while New Zealand's Olympic Committee has alerted the police and the International Olympic Committee's integrity unit.\n\n\"There is no place for this type of action in football and it is critical that urgent action is undertaken to address this integrity breach,\" Pragnell said in a statement on Thursday.\n\n\"To hear now that the Canadian team had filmed secret footage of our team training at least twice is incredibly concerning and if not treated urgently could have wider implications for the integrity of the tournament.\"\n\nCanada coach Bev Priestman will not be fulfilling her opening match duties after her assistant coach and team analyst were booted out of the Games on Wednesday amid drone flying allegations.\n\nWith Fifa initiating its disciplinary proceedings, Canada Soccer have expressed their commitment to cooperate by launching an independent review into the matter.\n\nCanada won their first gold medal in football by defeating Sweden in a dramatic penalty shootout after reaching the final of the Tokyo Olympics in 2021.\n\nYet, despite the champions demonstrating a willingness to resolve the situation, New Zealand are hoping for a more definitive decision to be made in the next few days.\n\n\"We note that there have been some admissions by the Canadian National Olympic Committee, and they have taken their own sanctions against the Canadian team,\" Pragnell added.\n\n\"However, considering the seriousness of the situation, and the potential implications to the sporting integrity of the entire tournament, we have referred the matter to the Fifa {"uri": "8243837778", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-26", "time": "00:11:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-26T00:11:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-26T00:11:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://nationalpost.com/sports/olympics/coc-removes-womens-soccer-coach-bev-priestman-amid-olympic-drone-spying-scandal", "title": "COC removes women's soccer coach Bev Priestman amid Olympic drone spying scandal", "body": "If you are a Home delivery print subscriber, unlimited online access is included in your subscription. Priestman denied any involvement, but did not attend Thursday's 2-1 victory over New Zealand as FIFA -- soccer's world governing body -- and the International Olympic Committee investigate.\n\nCanada Soccer CEO and general secretary Kevin Blue said in the COC release \"additional information has come to our attention regarding previous drone use against opponents, predating the Paris 2024 Olympic Games.\"\n\nHe added Priestman is suspended from her duties until the end of the tournament and the completion of the organization's independent external review.", "source": {"uri": "https://smartcdn.gprod.postmedia.digital/nationalpost/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/oly-soc-canada-priestman-20240725-e1721952280303.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9757777", "eventUri": "eng-9757777", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1450980392156863, "wgt": 117, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243784479", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:59:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:59:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:58:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.tsn.ca/soccer/canada-s-men-s-and-women-s-soccer-teams-have-relied-on-drones-and-spying-for-years-sources-say-1.2153674", "title": "Canada's men's and women's soccer teams have relied on drones and spying for years, sources say | TSN", "body": "Coaching staff and contractors working with Canada's men's and women's national soccer teams have been engaged for years in efforts to film the closed-door training sessions of their opponents, including during the women's gold-medal winning Olympic tournament in 2021, two sources with first-hand knowledge of the activity told TSN.\n\nThe filming also included at least one training session before a women's national team game against Panama in July 2022, when Canada was attempting to qualify for the Women's World Cup in Australia, one of the sources said. In that case, the source said, a Canadian contractor was caught attempting to film a private Panama training and a complaint was made by the Panamanian Football Federation to Canada Soccer and to Concacaf, the soccer confederation that governs the sport in North and Central America and the Caribbean.\n\nThe historical spying allegations come with the Canada's women's soccer team program under intense scrutiny at the Olympics in Paris.\n\nThe Canadian Olympic Committee said on Wednesday that assistant coach Jasmine Mander and analyst Joseph Lombardi had left the team and returned to Canada after Lombardi was caught using a drone to spy on two of New Zealand's closed training sessions. On Thursday, Canada beat New Zealand 2-1 in their Olympic tournament opener.\n\nLombardi was caught by French police on Monday, after they saw him retrieve a drone that had been flying over the New Zealand team's training, The Globe and Mail reported. The Globe reported that police retrieved footage of a second New Zealand training session from the drone and also obtained text messages between Lombardi and Mander. The text messages reportedly showed that Mander was aware of Lombardi's activities.\n\n\"This is awful, the worst-case scenario,\" said Amy Walsh, a former women's national team player who now co-hosts a podcast about soccer called Footy Prime. \"I feel sick to my stomach, genuinely nauseated. I understand when you get to a high-level people will be ruthless and do whatever they can to gain a competitive advantage but this is so far over the line.\n\n\"The players are benefitting from the coaches cheating. There's a certain amount of blind trust players have that coaches are doing things the right way and this is the ultimate betrayal.\"\n\nStaff and contractors connected to the men's national team have also filmed the closed training sessions of competitors, one of the sources told TSN, adding that Canada used a drone to record a U.S. training session before a Nov. 15, 2019, game in Florida. The U.S. won that game 4-1.\n\nTwo years later, Honduras stopped a training session in Toronto during World Cup qualifiers after someone spotted a drone overhead.\n\n\"I'd imagine there's probably a lot of people in Canada that fly drones, I'm sure,\" then-Canada coach John Herdman said at the time. \"And when a big team like Honduras turn up I'm sure people are probably interested in what they're doing when they come into our country. So I know for sure we won't be heading into people's countries too early because with drones these days, people can obviously capture footage. You've got to be really careful. So yeah, you got to be careful in CONCACAF. It's a tricky place.\"\n\nSome staff and contractors were told the filming was part of their jobs and that they could lose their positions with the federation if they did not go along with the demands, one of the sources said in a series of interviews with TSN on Wednesday and Thursday.\n\n\"In a couple of scenarios, people have been pushed and have been told, 'You have to give 110 percent and this is part of the job so if you don't feel comfortable with doing this, you do not have a place on the team',\" the source said. \"It's not something that's talked about and it's not something there are a lot of text messages about because of how sensitive this is. Some of the people who have had to do the filming or review the filming have said to a few staff members how uncomfortable it was for them.\"\n\nBoth sources asked for anonymity because they said they were afraid the federation would retaliate against them. It's unclear whether any players were aware of the strategy to record practices.\n\nOne of the sources said the spying included a Team Canada coach filming two of Japan's closed-door training sessions during the 2021 Summer Olympics in Tokyo. Canada tied Japan 1-1 in its first game during those Olympics.\n\n\"It was a little bit tricky during that time, given the fact that we were under a lot more restrictions, but there were ways to kind of sneak out of the hotel without people knowing,\" the source told TSN. \"In Tokyo, a lot of the facilities were a little bit more open so in some cases, you could see from behind bushes or behind fences or behind trees. It wasn't that complicated, because they didn't have the big mesh walls. So as long as you were close enough to the facility, you're able to see if you're in a hidden location.\"\n\nThe source said they weren't aware if spying occurred in other games during those Olympics.\n\nTwo years after the Tokyo Olympics, a Canada Soccer contractor who was scheduled to travel to Australia for the 2023 World Cup was told their responsibilities would include trying to record training sessions of opposing teams. When the contractor said they wouldn't agree to do that, their trip was canceled and a Canada Soccer staff member flew there in their place to do the recording, the source said.\n\nTSN has reviewed text message correspondence of a women's national team coach discussing secret filming of their opponents' training sessions ahead of games in 2022 against Costa Rica, South Korea and Trinidad.\n\nOne of the sources said the strategy for filming opposing teams' practices in Canada was relatively easy because Canada Soccer staff knew where they were practicing and what hotels they were staying in.\n\n\"When you're abroad, it requires a little bit more research. When you are in Concacaf events, you do have the ability of finding out where the rest of the teams are training because Concacaf, FIFA, and the Olympics, they all publish where the teams are training in one way or another,\" the source said. \"You also know just by looking at the social medias from the other teams and seeing what pictures they are posting.\"\n\nBoth sources said there is a lot to be learned from filming an opponent's practice.\n\n\"You get to know their formations, their starting lineup,\" one of the sources said. \"You also look at who is taking a penalty kick and their set pieces.\"\n\n\"Most people see this as cheating, which it is,\" one of the sources said. \"Some of our coaches just see it as a competitive advantage and justify it by saying everyone does it, which is also not true. Not everyone cheats and neither should we.\"\n\nIn an interview on Wednesday with a CBC reporter, women's team head coach Bev Priestman did not answer directly when she was asked if she was aware of the drone filming.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada. This does not represent the values that our team stands for,\" Priestman said in a statement on Wednesday. \"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program. Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\" Both FIFA and Canada Soccer announced investigations into the allegations of spying on Wednesday. Canada Soccer said its investigation would be conducted by an independent third party and would focus on the drone incident in France and more broadly, the historical ethical practices of both the men's and women's national team programs. The investigation findings will be made public, Canada Soccer said.", "source": {"uri": "tsn.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "TSN"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242334396", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "04:24:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T04:24:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T04:23:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5655833/2024/07/25/canada-olympic-spying-history-soccer-football/", "title": "A history of spying in football: Drones, interns at training and kit men in ceilings", "body": "Yeah, you're right. Probably not, given their long history of judging corruption, state boycotts and widespread doping.\n\nBut the news which broke on Tuesday, three days before the opening ceremony and hours before the first action in the 2024 Games' football tournament, meant that the cherished Olympic values of fair play stood in tatters even before organisers emblazoned that message across the Parisien sky and the River Seine.\n\nThat it was Canada who performed such an egregious breach of the rules -- by all stereotypes a country known for its people being polite, respectful, laidback and just terribly nice -- only adds to the ironic drama.\n\nThere are five rings in the Olympic logo -- take just two of them intertwined, and they resemble a pair of binoculars.\n\nSo this is what happened...\n\nOn Tuesday, at a training session ahead of their opening match of the group stage in Saint-Etienne on Thursday, staff members from the New Zealand women's football team noticed a drone hovering above them.\n\nThey called the on-site police, who detained the device's operator, who was later revealed to be a staff member from the Canadian team, the reigning Olympic women's champions, and their opponents in that opener today.\n\nIn an initial statement, the Canadian Olympic Committee (COC) apologised -- but more was to come.\n\nThe following day, it became clear that there had been two drone incidents, with the other taking place five days earlier, on July 19. Now facing severe sanctions, the COC needed to act.\n\nJoseph Lombardi, an \"unaccredited analyst\", and Jasmine Mander, a member of the coaching staff who oversees Lombardi, have been removed from the team and sent home and Canada's English head coach Beverly Priestman has voluntarily stepped down from being on the touchline for the New Zealand game.\n\n\"On behalf of our entire team, I first and foremost want to apologize to the players and staff at New Zealand Football and to the players on Team Canada,\" Priestman said. \"This does not represent the values that our team stand for.\"\n\nThat final sentence is a little difficult to justify, given that spying on another team's training is hardly an accidental action -- nobody finds themselves flying a $2,000 piece of tech over their next opponents -- twice -- by mistake. Rather, it comes as a product of culture and command.\n\n\"I am ultimately responsible for conduct in our program,\" Priestman added. \"Accordingly, to emphasize our team's commitment to integrity, I have decided to voluntarily withdraw from coaching the match on Thursday. In the spirit of accountability, I do this with the interests of both teams in mind and to ensure everyone feels that the sportsmanship of this game is upheld.\"\n\nThis may be new to the Olympics -- but spying in football is old business.\n\nTeams sending scouts to watch the next side they are going to play at training probably predates the invention of the offside rule. In fairness, though, we do not know if ancient Olympian Theagenes of Thasos sent emissaries to watch Arrichion of Phigalia working on his moves.\n\nIn international football, France men's manager Didier Deschamps noticed a drone above his players as they trained at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil -- it was never discovered which, if any, of their group-stage rivals Ecuador, Honduras and Switzerland it belonged to.\n\nGo back two more decades and ahead of a vital away World Cup qualifier against Norway in 1993, England manager Graham Taylor was so convinced his team were being watched that he moved their training base to a military facility. The issue? That new location was near the house of the chief sportswriter of one of Norway's leading newspapers, who subsequently published their tactics the next morning. England lost, 2-0, in Oslo, ended up missing out on the 1994 World Cup, and Taylor got sacked.\n\nSimilarly, in a case of paranoia outweighing perspective, the Chilean football federation once sent up their own device to destroy a drone hovering over their session before a match against Argentina. It was perhaps football's first case of aerial warfare since Roy Keane's infamous tackle on Alfie Haaland. In this case, it turned out the questionable drone was a surveying tool being used by a Chilean telecommunications company.\n\nBut there is one example of spying which did emanate from South America -- when, in early 2019, Leeds United's Argentine head coach Marcelo Bielsa admitted sending an intern to watch the following weekend's opponents Derby County work on their formation, set pieces and so on. It was not the first time.\n\n\"We watched training sessions of all the opponents before we played them,\" Bielsa, now Uruguay's head coach said. In Argentina, this practice was common apparently, and one he had continued after coming to work in Europe.\n\nDerby and Frank Lampard, their manager at the time, were furious. When Bielsa rang the former Chelsea and England midfielder to explain himself, there was no apology -- but instead, in broken English, he attempted to remove any ambiguity around the circumstances.\n\nLeeds won the ensuing match, 2-0 -- and the following week, Bielsa held an unprecedented press conference for local journalists, 66 minutes long, in which he used a PowerPoint presentation to demonstrate the full extent of the analysis he carried out on opposition clubs.\n\nFor Bielsa, who held open training sessions throughout his time at Athletic Bilbao in Spain, watching teams going through their tactical preparations like this was not spying, but simply gathering information.\n\nIt was later pointed out by Leeds fans that, as a player, Lampard has been part of a Chelsea side which profited from similar, um, info-gathering missions.\n\nIn an interview with UK newspaper the Telegraph, former Chelsea manager Andre Villas-Boas admitted that, in his time as an assistant at the London club under Jose Mourinho, he would \"travel to training grounds, often incognito, and look at our opponents' mental and physical state before drawing my conclusions\". Chelsea won the Premier League title twice with Mourinho and Villas-Boas in situ.\n\nGiven the amount of information that rival clubs can draw on, some coaches are simply not too bothered by allegations of spying. In 2018, German Bundesliga side Werder Bremen used a drone to spy on Hoffenheim -- but Hoffenheim's coach Julian Nagelsmann, now manager of Germany's national team, brushed off its impact.\n\n\"I'm not really angry at the analyst doing his job,\" Nagelsmann said, before adding it was \"commendable\" that Bremen were going to such lengths to try to win.\n\nSimilarly, in the aftermath of the Leeds incident, former striker Gary Taylor-Fletcher recalled an incident from his Lincoln City side's 2003-04 League Two play-off semi-final second leg away to Huddersfield Town.\n\nWhile the Lincoln players were receiving their half-time team talk, Taylor-Fletcher tweeted, a polystyrene ceiling tile broke and then fell down -- revealing the sizable heft of longtime Huddersfield kit man Andy Brook listening from the cavity above. Lincoln went on to lose the tie, while their opponents lost their dignity -- but did end up getting promoted. And Taylor-Fletcher can't have been too annoyed because, a year later, he left Lincoln for... Huddersfield.\n\nFootball is not alone in this sort of espionage -- and other sports can be much more high-tech.\n\nThe McLaren Formula 1 team were given the largest fine in sporting history -- $100million -- and thrown out of the sport's 2007 Constructors' Championship after senior engineer Mike Coughlan received technical design documents which had been leaked from rivals Ferrari.\n\nThere have also been several high-profile incidents in American football.\n\nAlso in 2007, the New England Patriots, the most successful NFL team of recent years with six Super Bowl wins since the turn of the century, were punished for recording the defensive signals given to players during a game by coaches of the New York Jets. New England's legendary head coach Bill Belichick was fined $500,000 -- the maximum allowed by the league, and the most in NFL history -- while the team were denied their first-round pick in the following year's player draft.\n\nDoes cheating prosper? Well, New England won all 16 games in the 2007 regular season -- but were surprisingly beaten in the Super Bowl by the New York Giants.\n\nAnd it's not just the professionals in the gridiron game. Last October, the University of Michigan's head coach Jim Harbaugh was suspended over a similar sign-stealing scandal which quickly escalated to involve allegations also levelled at several other college teams. Harbaugh was banned for several games, but Michigan went on to win the U.S. college national championship on his return. Harbaugh has since moved on to become head coach of the NFL's Los Angeles Chargers.\n\nSo this is the bottom line: teams cheat.\n\nIn a multimillion (or even billion) dollar/pound/euro industry, marginal gains like those detailed here are worth the risk of detection. For every Canada, Leeds and Michigan caught, there are clubs and sides whose operatives get away with it.\n\nWidespread but not necessarily endemic, it is both serious and not serious, funny and infuriating, the natural by-product of a game being taken as lifeblood.\n\nBack in the ancient Olympics, contemporary accounts reveal athletes being bribed to say they were from certain city-states rather than others -- facing a potential punishment of public flogging if they were caught.\n\nThings have not really changed -- and the punishment, at least to the guilty party's public reputation, is not so different either.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jacob_whitehead@nytimes.com", "name": "Jacob Whitehead", "type": {"uri": "8243453823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:16:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:16:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:15:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4117647111415863, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/sports/olympics/article-canada-vs-new-zealand-olympic-soccer-july-25/", "title": "Canada beats New Zealand 2-1 in women's soccer, maintaining focus as drone spying scandal looms over team", "body": "One day after they were roiled by pre-Olympic controversy, the Canadian national women's soccer team began their gold-medal defence Thursday with a nervy 2-1 victory over New Zealand.\n\nUnder different circumstances, you might call going down early to an inferior side and then fighting back to win a great way to start. But maybe not in this situation. Despite having four times as many shots as their opponent, Canada often looked out of sorts.\n\nAmazingly, New Zealand's goal -- it's only quality attempt on net -- came via a corner kick. That would be the sort of set play it might help to know about before a match is played.\n\nOn Wednesday, Canadian officials admitted that one of the women's team's staffers spied on two New Zealand practices via drone. The staffer was arrested, charged, plead guilty and then sent home by the Canadian Olympic Committee. His superior, an assistant coach, was also dismissed.\n\nHead coach Bev Priestman was not in attendance at nearly empty Stade Geoffrey-Guichard for Thursday's match. Priestman volunteered to suspend herself for the first game \"in the spirit of accountability.\"\n\nShe is due to return to coach the team's next game on Sunday against host France. {"uri": "8242054417", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:01:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:01:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:58:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.3921568691730499, "url": "https://theprint.in/sport/olympics-soccer-coc-head-says-priestman-had-no-knowledge-of-drone-incident/2190082/", "title": "Olympics-Soccer-COC head says Priestman had no knowledge of drone incident", "body": "David Shoemaker, the CEO of the COC, was asked repeatedly during an online media availability how Priestman avoided suspension and why he was comfortable with her resuming her coaching duties after Thursday's game.\n\n\"I was persuaded by the fact that Bev Priestman had no involvement, no knowledge in the incident,\" Shoemaker told reporters. \"Those who had the direct involvement in the incident we removed from Team Canada.\n\n\"There is no room for that in Team Canada. It doesn't conform to our standards of fair play and our values at the Canadian Olympic Committee.\"\n\nShoemaker said if any facts were to become known in the future suggesting Priestman was involved then the COC reserves the right to impose further sanctions.\n\nCanada Soccer is launching an independent external review into the matter while global soccer's governing body FIFA has begun disciplinary proceedings.\n\nShoemaker also said he felt there was no need for Priestman to miss more than one game since, according to him, she was not in possession of any footage from New Zealand's training sessions.\n\n\"We thought about all the repercussions for Bev,\" said Shoemaker. \"At the end of the day the drone footage related to the filming of two New Zealand practices remained in the hands of the pilot of the drone and the advantage that I guess was intended to be obtained was not obtained.\"\n\nShoemaker also said that while he is not aware of any calls for the women's team to be disqualified from the Olympics he did say New Zealand Football registered a complaint to FIFA, asking that Canada not be awarded any points if they win on Thursday.\n\n(Reporting by Frank Pingue in
